channel.title: Summer Says
channel.description: Books-A-Million’s top trendspotter has gathered all her favorite finds in one place

item.title: Nickel and Dimed
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The bestselling, landmark work of undercover reportage, now updated. Acclaimed as an instant classic upon publication, Nickel and Dimed has sold more than 1.5 million copies and become a staple of classroom reading. Chosen for "one book" initiatives across the country, it has fueled nationwide campaigns for a living wage. Funny, poignant, and passionate, this revelatory firsthand account of life in low-wage America--the story of Barbara Ehrenreich's attempts to eke out a living while working as a waitress, hotel maid, house cleaner, nursing-home aide, and Wal-Mart associate--has become an essential part of the nation's political discourse. Now, in a new afterword, Ehrenreich shows that the plight of the underpaid has in no way eased: with fewer jobs available, deteriorating work conditions, and no pay increase in sight, Nickel and Dimed is more relevant than ever.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The author goes “undercover” as an unskilled laborer to expose how minimum wage workers really live in our country. Ehrenreich shines a light on the working poor and gives us a heartrending look into their everyday lives. Brimming with insight, wit and passion, this book will change the way you view what it means to be one of America's working poor.

- Summer

item.title: A Fine Balance
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: With a compassionate realism and narrative sweep that recall the work of Charles Dickens, this magnificent novel captures all the cruelty and corruption, dignity and heroism, of India. The time is 1975. The place is an unnamed city by the sea. The government has just declared a State of Emergency, in whose upheavals four strangers--a spirited widow, a young student uprooted from his idyllic hill station, and two tailors who have fled the caste violence of their native village--will be thrust together, forced to share one cramped apartment and an uncertain future. As the characters move from distrust to friendship and from friendship to love, A Fine Balance creates an enduring panorama of the human spirit in an inhuman state.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This book will break your heart. It's a gripping tale of 1975 India, in a nameless city, under Indira Ghandi's “State of Internal Emergency.” The main characters suffer injustice, cruelty and tragedy, but they soldier on. A beautiful, moving work about the resiliency of the human spirit.

- Summer

item.title: Barefoot Contessa Brownie Mix
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
“I tested this recipe so many times that I am positive it is the best brownie recipe you will find.” – Ina Garten
This Barefoot Contessa brownie mix is rich, dark and chewy… these brownies are incredible! And this box mix makes them easy to bake. Great to have on hand to make a fabulous dessert for guests or when you’re craving a sweet treat.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Whip up decadent, delicious brownies with a hint of coffee, just like celebrity chef Ina Garten, the “Barefoot Contessa,” would make. Your guests won't believe these brownies came from a mix, so why tell them?

- Summer

item.title: Prodigal Summer
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Barbara Kingsolver's fifth novel is a hymn to wildness that celebrates the prodigal spirit of human nature, and of nature itself. It weaves together three stories of human love within a larger tapestry of lives amid the mountains and farms of southern Appalachia. Over the course of one humid summer, this novel's intriguing protagonists face disparate predicaments but find connections to one another and to the flora and fauna with which they necessarily share a place.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Prodigal Summer is an ode to the beauty of nature – and human nature. The author deftly weaves three stories about the people who live and work in an isolated corner of southern Appalachia into a beguiling narrative brimming with wit, poetry and romance.

- Summer

item.title: The Message Bean
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Greeting cards: bean there, done that! Send a message the uncommon way with a message bean. Once watered, the bean will germinate in about seven days and when it opens up, the receiver will see the laser-edged message on the bean. A gift that keeps on growing. Sold individually. Available in Happy Birthday, Thank You, Get Well, Best Wishes and Good Luck.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
These beans might not be magic, but they’re certainly unique. A special message is inscribed onto one side of the bean, and a picture on the other. Water the soil, and in a week or two, up pops the little bean and your special message.

- Summer

item.title: Red Cap "Sailing Ship" Journal
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Red Cap Cards was founded in Beverly Hills, California by Hal Mertz and illustrator Carrie Gifford. All of our products have been designed, printed and packaged with tender loving care here in sunny California. We hope you find as much delight and joy in the world or Red Cap as we do creating it...

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Hard-bound journals have a comfortingly old-fashioned feel; add the charming illustrations of illustrator and former children’s theater director Carrie Gifford and you have a special diary that feels like an heirloom before you've even written in it.

- Summer

item.title: Garden-in-a-Bag
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The Garden-in-a-Bag collection provides a great selection of herbs, flowers, fruits and veggies, and beautiful greens that can be grown indoors, right in the leak-proof bag. And the best part is that they are so fun and easy to grow! All you need to do is mix in the enclosed packet of seed and add water. Before long, you will have extremely flavorful herbs, tasty tomatoes and strawberries, beautiful and fragrant flowers, and attractive greens. Give them and grow them any time of year!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Even your least green-thumbed friends will appreciate this gift. Simply mix the enclosed seed packet with water right in the leak-proof bag and grow fresh herbs indoors.

- Summer

item.title: Keel's Simple Diary
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In a world where products are out as soon as they're in, where communicating without wires doesn't come without strings, and even our accessories need accessories, we need simple tools. A book that helps us look inside because we are overloaded outside.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Artist and author Philipp Keel created these unconventional and completely genius diaries for those of us who struggle with keeping a journal. Instead of blank pages, you get prompts, queries and quirky illustrations to help you make order from the chaos of daily life. Available in a variety of bold, cheerful colors.

- Summer

item.title: Secrets to Happiness
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Holly Frick has just endured the worst kind of breakup: the kind where you're still in love with the person leaving you. While her wounds are still dangerously close to the surface, her happily married best friend confesses over a bottle of wine that she is this close to having an affair. And another woman comes to Holly for advice about her love life--with Holly's ex. Holly decides that if everyone around her can take pleasure wherever they find it, so will she. As any self-respecting 30ish New York woman would do, she brings two males into her life: a flawed but endearing dog, and a good natured, much younger lover. She's soon entangled in a web of emails, chance meetings, and misguided good intentions and must forge an entirely new path to Nirvana. From the author of The Big Love, Secrets to Happiness is a big-hearted, knife-sharp, and hilariously entertaining story about the perils of love and friendship, sex and betrayal--and a thoroughly modern take on our struggle to be happy.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
After her husband leaves her and her career founders, 35-year-old writer Holly Frick wonders if she'll ever be happy again. The novel follows Holly and her circle of sophisticated friends as they navigate romantic entanglements in an elusive – but wickedly funny – search for happiness.

- Summer

item.title: The Elephant Keeper
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: England, 1766: After a long voyage from the East Indies, a ship docks in Bristol, England, and rumor quickly spreads about its unusual cargo--some say a mermaid is on board. A crowd forms, hoping to catch a glimpse of the magical creature. One crate after another is unpacked: a zebra, a leopard, and a baboon. There's no mermaid, but in the final two crates is something almost as magical--a pair of young elephants, in poor health but alive. Seeing a unique opportunity, a wealthy sugar merchant purchases the elephants for his country estate and turns their care over to a young stable boy, Tom Page. Tom's family has long cared for horses, but an elephant is something different altogether. It takes time for Tom and the elephants to understand one another, but to the surprise of everyone on the estate, a remarkable bond is formed. The Elephant Keeper, the story of Tom and the elephants, told in Tom's own words, moves from the green fields and woods of the English countryside to the dark streets and alleys of late-eighteenth-century London, reflecting both the beauty and the violence of the age. Nicholson's lush writing and deft storytelling complement a captivating tale of love and loyalty between one man and the two elephants that change the lives of all who meet them.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Set in 18th century England, the story follows Tom Page, stable boy to a nobleman who purchases two young elephants on a whim. Tom volunteers to care for the elephants and a remarkable bond develops as the novel explores the deep relationship between man and beast.

- Summer

item.title: The World According to Garp
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This is a comic and compassionate coming-of-age novel that established John Irving as one of the most imaginative writers of his generation. A worldwide bestseller since its publication in 1978, Irving's classic is filled with stories inside stories about the life and times of T. S. Garp, novelist and bastard son of Jenny Fields - a feminist leader ahead of her time.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This is the larger-than-life tale of T.S. Garp, a writer who lives in a world inhabited by talking bears and transvestite football players. Irving packs these and other wild characters and weird events into this modern day classic while taking readers on the path of Garp's life from conception to death. He enthralls us every step of the way with a story that is, as Garp's stuttering writing teacher puts it, "rich with lu-lu-lunacy and sorrow."

- Summer

item.title: Loving Frank
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In this ambitious debut novel, fact and fiction blend together brilliantly. While scholars have largely relegated Mamah to a footnote in the life of America’s greatest architect, author Nancy Horan gives full weight to their dramatic love story and illuminates Cheney’s profound influence on Wright.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Mamah Borthwick Cheney was Frank Lloyd Wright’s muse and mistress for seven years. Both were married with children and their affair shocked early-1900s society. Loving Frank is a fictional recreation of the love affair based on years of research by the author, and a poignant look at two flawed but fascinating people.

- Summer

item.title: Wildflower
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Wildflower is a compelling work of narrative nonfiction in which the shocking death of a dedicated environmentalist becomes a broader story of a beautiful, breathtaking country in peril. In January 2006, Joan Root, a sixty-nine-year-old naturalist, Oscar-nominated wildlife filmmaker, and staunch conservationist, was murdered by two masked men armed with an AK-47 shortly after midnight in her bedroom on the shore of Kenya's beautiful Lake Naivasha. Was it a random robbery gone bad, as the local police seemed to think, or was it a cold-blooded contract killing carried out at the behest of enemies Root had made in her efforts to protect Kenya's wildlife? Veteran journalist Mark Seal set out to investigate this gripping real-life murder mystery–and instead found an unforgettable story not only of a tragic death but of the remarkable life that preceded it.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Joan Root was an Oscar-nominated wildlife filmmaker who dedicated her life to conservation efforts in Africa. This biography paints an intimate portrait of this remarkable woman, from her passionate and ill-fated marriage to fellow filmmaker Alan Root to her tragic, brutal and still-unsolved murder.

- Summer

item.title: Luxe City Guides
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: For six years LUXE City Guides has quietly changed the face of travel guides, starting from scratch we re-thought the whole concept of why and how we all travel, of what we need when we get there and most importantly, what we don't. LUXE is now famous for its super-svelte format, and its take no prisoners attitude, avoiding all the padding, photos, graphics and blah of other guides and getting straight to the meat. The result – ultra-smart travel companions stacked with priceless information for the discerning, value-conscious and busy traveller.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Stylish, short and compact, these clever city guides give you the lowdown on the high points of select cities. The LUXE Guides are filled with reviews from actual city residents so you won’t look like a tourist, but a savvy traveler.

- Summer

item.title: Bel Canto
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A novel that is as lyrical and profound as it is unforgettable, Bel Canto engenders in the reader the very passion for art and the language of music that its characters discover. "A strange, terrific, spellcasting story."–San Francisco Chronicle

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Opera singer Roxane Coss has been lured to a South American embassy for the birthday party of a wealthy Japanese industrialist. During the party, terrorists invade, taking 58 people hostage. As the standoff stretches on, the line between terrorist and hostage begins to blur, and surprising relationships bloom.

- Summer

item.title: On Chesil Beach
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: From the acclaimed author of Atonement comes a novel of remarkable depth and poignancy. Set in 1962, On Chesil Beach captures with understanding and compassion the innocence of a young newlywed couple at a time when marriage has been presumed to be the outward sign of maturity and independence.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Young Edward and Florence are newlyweds on their honeymoon -- the wedding night does not go well. The novel explores what it means to be young and in love and how "by doing nothing ... the entire course of a life can be changed."

item.title: The Dive from Clausen's Pier
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Like the best work of Jane Hamilton and Sue Miller, Packer's emotionally thrilling, critically acclaimed, bestselling novel combines assured narrative drive with vibrant psychological realism and unblinking moral complexity.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Carrie Bell is 23, engaged to her long-time boyfriend and seriously questioning what she wants from life. After her fiancé is injured diving from a pier and becomes a quadriplegic, Carrie must decide where her destiny lies. The book asks, what do we owe those we love?

- Summer

Crossword puzzle lovers will find Zip-It an exciting way to challenge their skills. Ultra portable, it’s simply 24 ivory dice letter cubes used to create a crossword grid. Score is kept by sliding the zipper of the game’s pouch. First person to score 10 shouts “Zip It!”

– Summer

Dominique Browning was the editor of House and Garden for many years, and her elegant writing was always a high spot in the magazine. Then she lost her job of over a decade. In this contemplative memoir, Browning relates the struggles of losing her job and finding out what she really loves in life. A beautifully written story of learning to slow down and appreciate what comes.

-Summer

She’s back! J.K. Rowling’s newest novel may not be about a wizarding world, but it’s safe to say it’s a magical experience for her legions of fans. Rowling’s first novel for adults concerns the little English hamlet of Pagford, and an unexpected death that sets the town reeling. Black comedy, surprising twists and thoughtful writing make Rowling’s latest another soon-to-be classic. - Summer

item.title: Ahab's Wife
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: An epic-scale, brilliant and compelling saga, inspired by a brief passage in Moby Dick, chronicling the life of Captain Ahab's wife.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This amazing work of historical fiction begins with an intriguing opening line: “Captain Ahab was not my first husband nor my last.” This is the Moby-Dick saga told from the perspective of Una Spencer, the young, beautiful wife of the doomed Captain Ahab, and she does not simply wait patiently on the widow's walk for her husband's ship to return.

- Summer

item.title: The Member of the Wedding Party
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The novel that became an award-winning play and a major motion picture and that has charmed generations of readers, Carson McCullers's classic is now available in small- format trade paperback for the ﬁrst time. Here is the story of the inimitable twelve-year-old Frankie, who is utterly, hopelessly bored with life until she hears about her older brother's wedding. Bolstered by lively conversations with her house servant, Berenice, and her six-year-old male cousin -- not to mention her own unbridled imagination -- Frankie takes on an overly active role in the wedding, hoping even to go, uninvited, on the honeymoon, so deep is her desire to be the member of something larger, more accepting than herself.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Frankie is 12 and wants something, anything, to happen to her. She's hovering between childhood and adulthood, desperate to fit in. Her emotions reach the boiling point during the summer her brother gets married. A masterful coming-of-age story.

- Summer

item.title: Marley & Me
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: When the Grogan family is ready for a dog, they choose Marley, a yellow furball of a puppy who quickly grows into a large, rowdy Labrador retriever. Marley has a zest for life, and as he grows, so does his enthusiasm. He has an appetite for whatever he can get his paws on—from fine jewelry to underwear—and the one thing he always finds is trouble. Marley even gets kicked out of obedience school! Can this rambunctious pup ever learn how to be a good boy?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Marley is a very, very bad dog. He chews drywall, careens through screen doors, gets kicked out of obedience school – and teaches his owners about the meaning of unconditional love.

- Summer

item.title: Trouble
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A vibrant story of female friendship and midlife sexual awakening from the acclaimed author of The Great Man. Josie is a Manhattan psychotherapist living a comfortable life with her husband and daughter--until, while suddenly flirting with a man at a party, she is struck with the sudden realization that she must leave her passionless marriage. A thrillingly sordid encounter with a stranger she meets at a bar immediately follows. At the same time, her college friend Raquel, a Los Angeles rock star, is being pilloried in the press for sleeping with a much younger man who happens to have a pregnant girlfriend. This proves to be red meat to the gossip hounds of the Internet. The two friends escape to Mexico City for a Christmas holiday of retreat and rediscovery of their essential selves. Sex has gotten these two bright, complicated women into interesting trouble, and the story of their struggles to get out of that trouble is totally gripping at every turn. A tragicomedy of marriage and friendship, Trouble is a funny, piercing, and moving examination of the battle between the need for connection and the quest for freedom that every modern woman must fight.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
A middle-aged woman walks away from her marriage and engages in a journey of self-discovery. She reconnects with an old college friend and finds some new ways to get into trouble. Sultry and fun.

- Summer

item.title: A Fortunate Age
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Like The Group, Mary McCarthy's classic tale about coming of age in New York, Joanna Smith Rakoff's richly drawn and immensely satisfying first novel details the lives of a group of Oberlin graduates whose ambitions and friendships threaten to unravel as they chase their dreams, shed their youth, and build their lives in Brooklyn during the late 1990s and the turn of the twenty-first century.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Oberlin graduates and friends Sadie, Beth, Lil and Emily move to New York and find that life in the real world is more complicated than college prepared them for. A fine debut novel that explores the lives of women coming of age in the 21st century.

- Summer

item.title: The Last Summer (of You and Me)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
From the New York Times bestselling author of The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants comes a glorious novel of unrequited love, longing and the meaning of friendship.
Riley and Alice, two sisters now in their twenties, and as fiercely different as they are loyal, have spent every summer at their parent's modest beach house on New York's Fire Island. Each year, they return to the house and community they have known since they were children–and to Paul, the boy next door. But this summer marks a season of change: budding love and sexual interest, an illness, and a deep secret force all three to confront the increasing complexities of their lives and friendships.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Sisters Riley and Alice and neighbor Paul are childhood friends in their twenties spending one last summer on Fire Island. Romance blossoms between Paul and one of the sisters, while the other sister faces a serious illness. Love, secrets and tragedy force the three to leave their childhoods behind.

- Summer

item.title: The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Winner of the 2008 Dayton Literary Prize for Fiction Oscar is a sweet but disastrously overweight ghetto nerd who—from the New Jersey home he shares with his old world mother and rebellious sister—dreams of becoming the Dominican J.R.R. Tolkien and, most of all, finding love. But Oscar may never get what he wants. Blame the fukú—a curse that has haunted Oscar’s family for generations, following them on their epic journey from Santo Domingo to the USA. Encapsulating Dominican-American history, The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao opens our eyes to an astonishing vision of the contemporary American experience and explores the endless human capacity to persevere—and risk it all—in the name of love.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Oscar is a child of Dominican immigrants and an ultra nerd growing up a New Jersey suburb. He desperately wants a girl to like him, but he's convinced it's hopeless because his family is cursed. Determined to find love despite the obstacles, Oscar is such a unique and engaging hero you can’t help but root for him.

- Summer

item.title: Red Cap Cards - Leonard Spider's Birthday
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Red Cap Cards was founded in Beverly Hills, California by Hal Mertz and illustrator Carrie Gifford. All of our products have been designed, printed and packaged with tender loving care here in sunny California. We hope you find as much delight and joy in the world or Red Cap as we do creating it...

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
These enchanting cards are more than a way to send a message – they're unique works of art by illustrator and former children’s theater director Carrie Gifford. Her offbeat style will delight the young and young at heart.

- Summer

item.title: Pyromaniac Journal
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Contemporary Japanese pop artist Yoshitomo Nara elevates these journals with a cast of cute and mischievous children. His colorful characters may inspire your own works of genius.

item.title: Gang Leader for a Day
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: First presented in Freakonomics, the story of a young sociologist who embedded himself in Chicago's most notorious gang and captured the world's attention. Gang Leader for a Day is the fascinating full story of how Sudhir Venkatesh gained entrance into the lives of a group of drug-dealers and went on to witness–and participate in–events that have rarely been described in print. A brazen, page-turning, and fundamentally honest view of the highly corrupt struggle to survive in an urban war zone, it is also an emotional and complicated look at the friendship that develops between the sociologist and a gang leader, two ambitious men a universe apart.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
While a graduate student in sociology, Sudhir Venkatesh -- first introduced in Freakonomics --  befriends J.T., the leader of one of Chicago's most notorious gangs, at the height of the crack epidemic. In return, he gets an unprecedented look at both life in the gang, and life in this inner city war zone. The morally ambiguous connection of the gang with the community and the complicated friendship between between Venkatesh and J.T. make for a powerfully authentic tale.

- Summer

item.title: Cutting for Stone
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A sweeping, emotionally riveting first novel--an enthralling family saga of Africa and America, doctors and patients, exile and home.
Marion and Shiva Stone are twin brothers born of a secret union between a beautiful Indian nun and a brash British surgeon at a mission hospital in Addis Ababa. Orphaned by their mother's death in childbirth and their father's disappearance, bound together by a preternatural connection and a shared fascination with medicine, the twins come of age as Ethiopia hovers on the brink of revolution. Yet it will be love, not politics--their passion for the same woman--that will tear them apart and force Marion, fresh out of medical school, to flee his homeland. He makes his way to America, finding refuge in his work as an intern at an underfunded, overcrowded New York City hospital. When the past catches up to him--nearly destroying him--Marion must entrust his life to the two men he thought he trusted least in the world: the surgeon father who abandoned him and the brother who betrayed him.
An unforgettable journey into one man's remarkable life, and an epic story about the power, intimacy, and curious beauty of the work of healing others.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Conjoined twins Marion and Shiva Stone are separated at birth and almost simultaneously orphaned. The boys share a fascination with medicine and come of age as Ethiopia hovers on the brink of revolution, but their love for the same woman tears them apart. An epic story that examines the role of fate in our lives.

- Summer

item.title: Jane Eyre
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A novel of intense power and intrigue, Jane Eyre has dazzled generations of readers with its depiction of a woman's quest for freedom. This updated edition features a new introduction discussing the novel's political and magical dimensions. Having grown up an orphan in the home of her cruel aunt and at a harsh charity school, Jane Eyre becomes an independent and spirited survivor–qualities that serve her well as governess at Thornfield Hall. But when she finds love with her sardonic employer, Rochester, the discovery of his terrible secret forces her to make a choice. Should she stay with him whatever the consequences or follow her convictions, even if it means leaving her beloved?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The heroine of Bronte’s classic becomes governess at Thornfield Hall and falls passionately in love with its master, the wealthy, brooding Edward Rochester. But what dark secret is he hiding, and who or what is haunting the mansion's gloomy halls? Can Jane's love for Rochester survive almost insurmountable obstacles? A book that only gets richer and more rewarding with each reading.

- Summer

item.title: The Sartorialist
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Scott Schuman just wanted to take photographs of people that he met on the streets of New York who he felt looked great. His now-famous and much-loved blog, thesartorialist.com, is his showcase for the wonderful and varied sartorial tastes of real people across the globe. This book is a beautiful anthology of Scottas favorite images, accompanied by his insightful commentary. It includes photographs of well-known fashion figures alongside people encountered on the street whose personal style and taste demand a closer look. From the streets of New York to the parks of Florence, from Stockholm to Paris, from London to Moscow and Milan, these are the men and women who have inspired Scott and the many diverse and fashionable readers of his blog. After fifteen years in the fashion business, Scott Schuman felt a growing disconnect between what he saw on the runways and in magazines, and what real people were wearing. His blog, The Sartorialist. was his attempt to redress the balance. Since its beginning, the blog has become hugely admired and influential in the fashion industry and beyond. Thesartorialist.com is consistently named one of the top blogs in the world. A self-taught photographer, Schuman shoots for publications including French Vogue, American GQ, Fantastic Man and Elle, and a growing list of advertising clients. Scott has also shown his work at the New York photo gallery The Danziger Projects and appeared in the GAP Style Icon campaign in the fall of 2008. He has been named the number one fashion photography trend by American Photo magazine, as well as one of Time magazine's top 100 design influencers.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Photographer Scott Schuman captures real people with fantastic style on the street. With a keen eye for interesting detail, Schuman elevates random passersby (and a few famous figures as well) into timeless icons of fashion. Will inspire you to look into your own closet with fresh eyes. Also, be sure to check out his amazing blog at www.thesartorialist.blogspot.com.

- Summer

item.title: Traveling with Pomegranates
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
An introspective and beautiful dual memoir by the #1 "New York Times" bestselling novelist and her daughter Sue Monk Kidd has touched millions of readers with her novels "The Secret Life of Bees" and "The Mermaid Chair" and with her acclaimed nonfiction. In this intimate dual memoir, she and her daughter, Ann, offer distinct perspectives as a fifty-something and a twenty-something, each on a quest to redefine herself and to rediscover each other.
Between 1998 and 2000, Sue and Ann travel throughout Greece and France. Sue, coming to grips with aging, caught in a creative vacuum, longing to reconnect with her grown daughter, struggles to enlarge a vision of swarming bees into a novel. Ann, just graduated from college, heartbroken and benumbed by the classic question about what to do with her life, grapples with a painful depression. As this modern-day Demeter and Persephone chronicle the richly symbolic and personal meaning of an array of inspiring figures and sites, they also each give voice to that most protean of connections: the bond of mother and daughter. A wise and involving book about feminine thresholds, spiritual growth, and renewal, "Traveling with Pomegranates" is both a revealing self-portrait by a beloved author and her daughter, a writer in the making, and a momentous story that will resonate with women everywhere.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
In their moving spiritual memoir, middle-aged Kidd and her 20-something daughter take us on a journey of rediscovery and reconnection. While traveling together through Greece, Turkey and France, mother and daughter grapple with their own different and difficult transformations and come to a new appreciation of each other.

- Summer
Sue Monk Kidd and Ann Kidd Taylor

item.title: Where the Wild Things Are
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In the forty years since Max first cried "Let the wild rumpus start," Maurice Sendak's classic picture book has become one of the most highly acclaimed and best-loved children's books of all time. Now, in celebration of this special anniversary, introduce a new generation to Max's imaginative journey where a naughty little boy, sent to bed without his supper, sails to the land of the wild things and becomes their king.
Caldecott Medal Winner: Picture Book 1964

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
One night, “Max wears his wolf suit and makes mischief” – so he's sent to bed without supper. In his room, a forest grows, along with an ocean and a boat that takes Max to where the wild things are. Amusing, poignant, and at times a bit dark, Where the Wild Things Are is that rare children's book that I loved as a child and continue to love as an adult.

- Summer

item.title: You or Someone Like You
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Anne Rosenbaum leads a life of quiet Los Angeles privilege, the wife of Hollywood executive Howard Rosenbaum and mother of their seventeen-year-old son, Sam. Years ago Anne and Howard met studying litera-ture at Columbia--she, the daughter of a British diplo-mat from London, he a boy from an Orthodox Jewish neighborhood in Brooklyn. Now on sleek blue California evenings, Anne attends halogen-lit movie premieres on the arm of her powerful husband. But her private life is lived in the world of her garden, reading books.
When one of Howard's friends, the head of a studio, asks Anne to make a reading list, she casually agrees--though, as a director reminds her, "no one reads in Hollywood." To her surprise, they begin calling: screen-writers; producers, from their bungalows; and agents, from their plush offices on Wilshire and Beverly. Soon Anne finds herself leading an exclusive book club for the industry elite. Emerging gradually from her seclu-sion, she guides her readers into the ideas and beauties of Donne, Yeats, Auden, and Mamet, with her brilliant and increasingly bold opinions. But when a crisis of identity unexpectedly turns an anguished Howard back toward the Orthodoxy he left behind as a young man, Anne must set out to save what she values above all else: her husband's love.
At once fiercely intelligent and emotionally grip-ping, "You or Someone Like You" confronts the fault lines between inherited faith and personal creed, and, through the surprising transformation of one exceptional, unfor-gettable woman, illuminates literature's power to change our lives.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Anne, an English Ph.D. leading a quiet life of privilege, is married to Howard, a Hollywood producer, when she suddenly finds herself hosting a book club for Hollywood's rich and powerful that becomes the talk of the town. When their son Sam returns from a trip to Israel, Howard reconnects to his Jewish heritage, all but cutting himself off from his wife and son. Anne must reckon with her own beliefs to forge a new relationship with her beloved husband. A provocative look at religion, culture, and art that illustrates how literature has the power to change our lives.

- Summer

item.title: Mini Notes:
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Whether they are dropped in a friend's bag, left on a workmate's desk, or clipped to a birthday gift, mini greeting cards are sure to spread smiles and good cheer!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Spread some cheer with these pocket-sized greeting cards adorned with the illustrations of artist Susie Ghahremani.

- Summer

item.title: Grady McFerrin Stationery Box
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: 9-1/2 x 6-3/4 x 1-1/4 in 30 writing sheets and 30 envelopes (6 designs repeating 5 times) color illustrations

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Brooklyn artist Grady McFerrin's vibrant artwork makes correspondence more fun.

- Summer

item.title: Gratitude: A Journal
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Keep a daily record of life's little blessings with this keepsake gratitude journal filled with a year’s worth of insightful prompts, inspiring quotes, and ample room for reflecting on all the things that make life great.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
In our hectic lives, it's easy to lose sight of the fact that every day is a gift. Jot down the little (and big) things you're grateful for in this beautiful keepsake journal.

- Summer

item.title: Treetops Journal
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Artist Susie Ghahremani's adorable owls, birds and trees decorate this journal.

item.title: Orla Kiely A6 Multi-Stem Journal
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Orla Kiely's colorful, retro-inspired flower stems give this hardbound journal panache.

item.title: What Would Keith Richards Do?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Here, at last, the wisdom of this indefatigable man is recorded and set forth. These are his visionary words: "I would rather be a legend than a dead legend." Or "Whatever side I take, I know well that I will be blamed." And–indeed–"I've never had a problem with drugs, only with policemen."
Not merely a compendium of wisdom, this book is also a complete guide to the inner workings of a complex and inspired belief system, and the life of a man sanctified by fame. "What Would Keith Richards Do? "reminds us to learn from our mistakes, let our instincts lead us, and above all, do what Keith has done better than anyone–survive.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The Rolling Stones' Keith Richards is many things –  a phenomenal guitarist, songwriter and record producer, to name just a few. But philosopher? This tongue-in-cheek book pokes a little fun at the usual self-help titles while presenting some choice quotes to illustrate why Keith Richards is a true prophet. It doesn't hurt that Richards' pearls of wisdom are often hysterically funny.

- Summer

item.title: Beautiful People
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Long before he became a celebrity in his own right–as the author of best-selling books, as the style arbiter of VH1 and "America's Top Model," and the marketing genius behind Barney's New York–Simon Doonan was a "scabby knee'd troll" in Reading, England. In Beautiful People, Doonan returns to the working-class neighborhood of his youth, and chronicles the misadventures of the Doonan clan in all their wacky glory. Readers meet his mother Betty, whose gravity-defying, peroxide hairdo signified her natural glamour; his father Terry, an amateur vintner who turned parsnips into the legendary Chateau Doonan; his grandfather D.C., a hard-drinking betting man who plotted to win his fortune by turning Simon into a jockey; and his demented grandma Narg and schizophrenic Uncle Ken, both of whom lived upstairs.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Campy, tart and utterly memorable – like the author himself. Doonan, who is creative director at Barneys and famous for his outrageous window displays, looks back on his childhood with his wacky family in suburban England. Doonan longs to escape the tedium of small-town life, and sets out to find the “beautiful people” of his mother's magazines. This is a laugh-out-loud memoir written with heart.

- Summer

item.title: The World in Vogue
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This one-of-a-kind book of 300 photographs of some of the most celebrated actors, artists, models, First Ladies, and social figures draws on stories that have appeared in the pages of "Vogue "over the past four decades, as well as photographs from those stories that have never been published. These trendsetters and newsmakers are captured by such famous photographers as Cecil Beaton, Jonathan Becker, Eric Boman, Horst P. Horst, Edward Steichen, Irving Penn, Richard Avedon, Francois Halard, Helmut Newton, Stephen Meisel, Snowdon, Toni Frissell, Bruce Weber, Herb Ritts, and Annie Leibovitz. Not only did these photographers take dazzling portraits--in studios or on location--that caught these iconic figures in classic, playful, or dramatic moments but they also documented their parties, weddings, houses, and gardens. Writers like Hamish Bowles, Paul Rudnick, Truman Capote, Francis Wyndham, Jeffrey Steingarten, Joan Juliet Buck, William Norwich, Gloria Steinem, Georgina Howell, Vicki Woods, Marina Rust, Michael Specter, and Jonathan Van Meter tell you the stories behind these figures and events.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The icons of our age – actors, First Ladies, socialites, models and other celebrities – are gloriously captured in this essential coffee table book. Photographs from Irving Penn, Cecil Beaton, Richard Avedon, Annie Liebovitz and other greats star alongside the writings of Truman Capote and Gloria Steinem, celebrated gardens around the world, ultra-glam weddings and the best parties of the past few decades. The absolute best from the pages of Vogue from 1960 to the present – a must for fans of photography and high fashion.

- Summer

item.title: Happy Go Lucky
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The film chronicles the daily comings and goings of 30-year-old Poppy, whose positive, easy-going outlook epitomizes the title. Poppy is a primary school teacher who lives in London with her best friend, Zoe (Alexis Zegerman). We follow Poppy through her daily routines: going clubbing with her friends, preparing exercises for her class, going to the chiropractor, and taking flamenco lessons.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Sally Hawkins is Poppy, an irrepressibly bubbly teacher who is both enchanting and maddening. After her bicycle is stolen, Poppy takes driving lessons from Scott, who was some serious anger problems. Poppy never wavers from her optimistic outlook on life, even as she finds that not everyone appreciates her cheerful nature.

- Summer

item.title: Dan In Real Life
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Advice columnist Dan Burns (Carell) has his hands full with three daughters that he's not willing to let grow up. The girls still grieve for their mother who died four years ago, and Dan hasn't made any attempts to date. So he's pleasantly surprised when he meets Marie (Juliette Binoche) at a bookstore when he goes to his parents' Rhode Island home for the annual family reunion. But his joy is short-lived when he discovers that she is dating his brother (Dane Cook), forcing Dan to hide his feelings and chemistry with Marie.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Dan Burns is a lonely widower, father of three girls and advice columnist who doesn't always follow his own relationship rules. While on a visit to his family, he meets Marie and – as in all good movies about romance – complications ensue. Steve Carell is marvelous as Dan.

- Summer

item.title: Once
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The Irish romance ONCE may be a musical, but it is miles away from the traditional Hollywood idea of people bursting into song. Glen Hansard (frontman for indie rock band The Frames) plays the guy, a street musician who is playing for change when he meets the girl (Marketa Irglova), an immigrant from the Czech Republic. The pair immediately bond over their shared love of music (he is a guitarist, and she plays the piano), and the film chronicles their tentative relationship.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
What an amazing little film! Billed simply as Guy and Girl, the two main characters are a man who's had his heart broken and a woman who helps him open up and follow his dream. Filled with beautiful music created by the film's stars, neither of whom were professional actors. You think you know where the movie is going, but it surprises you in genuine, heartfelt ways.

- Summer

item.title: Elegy
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: ELEGY is consumed by the ideas of love and mortality. The hero of this drama is an aging writer and professor played by Ben Kingsley. David Kepesh (Kingsley) is a minor literary celebrity in New York City who shies away from commitment, happy with his casual relationship with a businesswoman (Patricia Clarkson) who is rarely in town. But a date with a stunning grad student named Consuela (Penelope Cruz) surprisingly turns into a long-term romance, changing David from a confident Lothario into a jealous boyfriend. His age and her beauty haunt their romance until David begins to push her away.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Rarely has a May-December romance been treated with such sophistication. David Kepesh is a middle-aged college professor and womanizer who falls for Consuela, a 24-year-old student. Despite their age gap, she is the one who is wise and mature beyond her years. His actions are ruled by his fear of commitment and that she will leave him for a younger man. A thoughtful, elegant film.

- Summer

item.title: The Hangover
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Groom-to-be Doug (Justin Bartha, NATIONAL TREASURE) has planned an epic night in Las Vegas with his two best friends, Phil (Bradley Cooper, YES MAN) and Stu (Ed Helms, THE OFFICE), and his fiancée's awkward brother, Alan (comedian Zach Galifianakis). But it turns out that they partied a little too hard: Phil, Stu, and Alan wake up the next morning with a missing groom, a tiger in the hotel-room bathroom, a baby in the closet, and no memory of the night before.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Three friends celebrate their friend Doug's impending wedding with a bachelor party none of them will ever forget. When they can't find the groom-to-be the next morning, just hours away from the ceremony, none of them can remember the events from the night before. As they look for clues and try to figure out why there is both a tiger and a baby in their hotel suite, we get one of the funniest movies of the decade.

- Summer

item.title: Into The Wild
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Jon Krakauer's bestselling nonfiction book about the life of Chris McCandless is finally brought to the big screen in INTO THE WILD. Directed by Sean Penn, the film opens in 1992, when Chris (Emile Hirsh) is a promising college graduate. Shortly after graduation, Chris gives his life savings to charity, burns all of his identification, and begins hitchhiking across America, his ultimate goal being Alaska. Citing passages from his heroes, Thoreau and Jack London, he is determined to escape society and get back to nature. He blows from town to town like a tumbleweed, hopping trains, camping with aging hippies (Catherine Keener and Brian Dierker), working briefly with a farmer (Vince Vaughan), and befriending a widowed leather worker (Hal Holbrook). He revels in his newfound freedom, but meanwhile, his parents (Marcia Gay Harden and William Hurt) have no idea where he is, and are sick with worry. While their relationship with Chris was already troubled, they are nonetheless devastated by his disappearance. Chris's sister, Carine (Jane Malone), narrates much of the film, offering her reflections on the effect Chris's absence has on his family. Chris finally makes it to Alaska, where he hikes out to a remote campsite and discovers an abandoned bus. He manages to survive there for a few months living off the land, but he eventually runs out of supplies and becomes trapped, leading to his tragic end. INTO THE WILD bounces around chronologically, jumping back and forth from the start of Chris's journey to his final few weeks living aboard the bus. This works to great effect as the storylines begin to merge and the tension and dread mount, and we see the fate that will eventually befall Chris. Penn obviously had great admiration for his subject, and while the film appears to differ from the book in places, it nevertheless paints a heartbreaking portrait of this young man's short but fascinating life.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Christopher McCandless rejects the materialism of his life and sets out for Alaska to find life's true meaning. He comes to realize that nature is as harsh as the world he thought he left behind, and tries to return to his friends and family. Engrossing and heartbreaking.

- Summer

item.title: Annie Hall
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Woody Allen's masterpiece and a breakout role for Diane Keaton as Annie. As love blossoms between Jewish Alvy Singer and WASP Annie Hall, it does not always run smooth, but it's delightful to watch. Allen basically plays himself, and Keaton gives us a playful, unforgettable ditz.

item.title: Walk the Line
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In Depression-era Arkansas, Cash (Joaquin Phoenix) shows a strong interest in music, escaping from his no-frills life and strict father (Robert Patrick) through hymns and listening to the radio. The film follows Cash through his first marriage with Vivian Cash (Ginnifer Goodwin) and into the early stages of his touring career alongside such musicians as Jerry Lee Lewis, Carl Perkins, Roy Orbison, Elvis Presley, and most importantly, June Carter (Reese Witherspoon). As Cash's success grows, so does his relationship with drugs, alcohol, and Carter, putting a strain upon his family life. From his initial audition with Sam Phillips of Sun Records on through his legendary 1968 concert at Folsom Prison, Cash is transformed from a hesitant singer riddled with demons to a man whose uniquely bold style would make music history.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Joaquin Phoenix doesn't just play Johnny Cash, he embodies him. He and Reese Witherspoon, as June Carter, did all their own singing and the results are astonishingly good. The chemistry between the two stars is sizzling. One of the best biopics I've ever seen.

- Summer

item.title: Sophie's Choice
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Alan J. Pakula's handsome production charts the course of an eccentric and intense love triangle in 1947 Brooklyn, New York. Meryl Streep won an Academy Award for her carefully nuanced performance and perfect accent as Sophie, a Polish survivor of WWII concentration camps who harbors a devastating secret.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Meryl Streep plays Polish immigrant Sophie in this shattering drama that sealed her reputation as America's most formidable actress. Southern writer Stingo shares a Brooklyn boarding house with Sophie and her mercurial lover Nathan. As Sophie relates the horrors of a Nazi concentration camp through flashbacks, we realize the truth of her “choice.” One of the most gut-wrenching movies ever made, but Meryl is luminous.

- Summer

This young singer-songwriter has been compared to Otis Redding and Van Morrison, but he's got a unique sound all his own. His raspy vocals and meditative lyrics give each song true emotional impact. You'll feel your own heart breaking right along with his.

- Summer

Feist has a lovely, delicate voice that shines in her beautifully crafted songs. She's a superb songwriter, and really puts thought into how her music builds and crests – the listener is never bored. This is an album I like to linger over.

- Summer

Rachael Yamagata has a beautiful, smoky voice that stops you in your tracks. Her songs are about lost love approached with meditative reflection and maturity, not anger. Music to capture the soul.

- Summer

item.title: Aimee Mann: One More Drifter in the Snow
item.dc:creator: admin

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Aimee Mann updates holiday standards with bittersweet longing. Her version of these classic songs acknowledge that Christmas is a time of joy, but also a time to remember the people you've lost along the way.

- Summer

item.title: Ella Wishes You a Swinging Christmas
item.dc:creator: admin

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Ella takes classic Christmas songs we all know by heart and injects them with fresh spirit and sass. The album is vibrant and fun, a must for every holiday party.

- Summer

item.title: Sting: If On a Winter's Night
item.dc:creator: admin

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Sting is a master of evoking a mood, feeling and introspection. He's at his absolute best with this latest album, featuring songs that evoke the magic and quiet beauty of winter and the holiday season. A reflective journey that's sure to become a classic.

- Summer

item.title: Love Actually
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Written and directed by Richard Curtis and produced by Duncan Kenworthy (the team behind NOTTING HILL and FOUR WEDDINGS AND A FUNERAL) this zingy British comedy weaves a vivid crazy quilt of interlocking or unrelated vignettes all dealing with the subject of love over the Christmas holidays in London.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
One of my favorite romantic comedies is also a perfect holiday movie. Set during Christmas in London, we follow the trials, tribulations and delights of a wonderful cast of characters as they search for – or try to hold on to – love. Hugh Grant leads the cast as a British Prime Minster and Emma Thompson plays his sister in her typical revelatory fashion, but everyone is simply a joy to watch.

- Summer

item.title: Sketch! Jimi Crayon
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A new series of high-quality blank sketchbooks for graffiti fans and artists. Each sketchbook has a screen-printed board cover depicting an exclusive artwork by internationally acclaimed artists: Dalek (USA), Darbotz (Indonesia), Jimi Crayon (UK), and ESOW (Japan).

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This high-quality, hardback blank sketchbook features specially commissioned cover art from Jimi Crayon, a graffiti artist in the UK. A very cool gift for the artist in your life.

- Summer

item.title: Paris, Je T'aime
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Eighteen different directors and a slew of indie actors come together for PARIS, JE T'AIME, a cinematic homage to the City of Lights. Each director presents his or her own short story set in a different Parisian quarter, each one featuring a different cast of characters.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
A collection of 18 short films set in different arrondissements in Paris, directed by some of the very best directors in the world. Each vignette is a gem, an ode to finding love in Paris or just falling in love with Paris itself. Some are sad, some are comic but all are brilliantly acted and deeply moving.

- Summer

item.title: Away We Go
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Director Sam Mendes (AMERICAN BEAUTY) may invoke plenty of indie-comedy tropes in this comic venture, but AWAY WE GO is a tender, sweet, and surprisingly funny addition to the genre. Verona De Tessant (Maya Rudolph, SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE) is six months pregnant, but she and her boyfriend, Burt Farlander (John Krasinski, THE OFFICE), aren’t tied down to their current house in Colorado. A sense of adventure and the desire to find a place to call home propels the couple across North America, stopping in Arizona, Wisconsin, Montreal, and Miami, where they learn the how-to's (and how-not-to's) of parenting from friends and family.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
John Krasinski and Maya Rudolph are charming as Burt and Verona, a young expectant couple searching for a place to put down roots. Their quest reconnects them with friends and relatives, some of whom have some very strange ideas of child raising. It's a different kind of road movie, with two extremely likeable people in the center who you grow to care about very much.

- Summer

item.title: Julie & Julia
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Meryl Streep and Amy Adams take a comedic turn with this adaptation of Julie Powell's beloved bestseller.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Julie Powell wants to be a writer and gets the genius idea of cooking her way through Julia Child's Mastering the Art of French Cooking and blogging about it. We laugh and cringe through Julie's year of tribulations, interspersed with terrific scenes of Julia Child's life in Paris and the writing of her masterpiece. Meryl Streep is sublime as Julia Child.

- Summer

item.title: La Vie en Rose
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: According to Marlene Dietrich, chanteuse Edith Piaf's voice was "the soul of Paris." This French drama explores the often troubled life of the singer as her fame took her from the City of Lights to America to the South of France.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The story of French superstar singer Edith Piaf is so heartbreaking. She was brought up in a brothel, joined the circus with her father, sang for her supper on the streets and was often frail, sickly and using drugs. But what a voice! Marion Cotillard gives a bravura performance, and she makes us love Piaf even when she is willful, destructive and selfish.

- Summer

item.title: Waitress
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This charming comedy from late director-writer-actress Adrienne Shelly is the perfect mix of sweet and sour. FELICITY'S Keri Russell stars as Jenna, a waitress stuck in a marriage to a less-than-lovable lout (Jeremy Sisto, SIX FEET UNDER). When she learns she's pregnant with his baby, she seeks solace in two things: pie-baking and an extramarital affair with her hunky but nervous OB-GYN Dr. Pomatter (Nathan Fillion, SERENITY). Her relationship with her doctor gives her something to look forward to as her husband grows ever more controlling and her baby bump gets larger. Like Jenna's perfect pie recipes, WAITRESS is a heavenly combination of ingredients.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Jenna is unhappily married to Earl and works in a diner where she creates pies with imaginative titles based on her life. When she becomes pregnant, she's more determined than ever to escape Earl. She starts an affair with her married obstetrician, but it's her genius with pies (and the help of some kind friends) that helps her win her happy ending. Beautifully written and acted.

- Summer

item.title: Mad Men
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Matthew Weiner, a writer and executive producer for THE SOPRANOS, may have set this series in the picture-perfect 1960s, but his characters are just as scheming as the mobsters on his last show. MAD MEN takes place on Manhattan's Madison Avenue at the fictional ad agency of Sterling Cooper.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
If you haven't been watching this show, you're missing out on the best series on television. Catch up on all the drama of Sterling Cooper's dapper advertising executives in the early 1960s and the lives of their family, friends and lovers. Smart writing, excellent casting and loving attention to detail make this period in America come alive.

- Summer

item.title: Brothers & Sisters
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The family drama heats up in season three of BROTHERS & SISTERS, the ABC hit that follows the ups and downs of the warm but wily Walker clan.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The Walker family of Pasadena has its share of problems, just like every other family. But most family problems are not this mesmerizing. The best part of the show is the amazing ensemble cast, including Sally Field as the matriarch Nora Walker. Be warned, this show quickly becomes addictive.

- Summer

item.title: 30 Rock
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Set behind the scenes at TGS, a fictional NBC sketch comedy series, 30 ROCK follows showrunner Liz Lemon (Tina Fey) as she contends with her program’s flighty stars, Tracy Jordan (Tracy Morgan) and Jenna Maroney (Jane Krakowski), and runs interference between network exec Jack Donaghy (Alec Baldwin) and her own unruly writing staff.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Simply the funniest show on television. Comedy genius Tina Fey writes, stars and executive produces in this critically acclaimed series that also stars Alec Baldwin as a network executive and Tracy Morgan as an unpredictable movie star. Insanely good, with brisk pacing and rapid-fire jokes.

- Summer

The lovely, haunting music created by the stars of Once, Markéta Irglová and Glen Hansard, is beautifully integrated in the film but makes a fine standalone album. Each song feels like the musicians have opened up their souls for all to hear. Beautifully expressive.

If you're new to Nina Simone's music, this is the album for you. Nina Simone sang about some heavy themes – race, slavery, sexuality – but her songs are accessible. No singer before or since has put listeners under her spell quite like Nina Simone.

Mellow and country-tinged, this is Neil Young at his best. The lyrics are powerful, personal and true. It's hard to believe it's been over 35 years since this album came out. It's still as fresh and meaningful as ever.

- Summer

Master pianist/keyboardist Herbie Hancock collaborated with some of the biggest names in music to create an uplifting musical experience from beginning to end. It's wonderful to hear Hancock's elegant arrangements with such a diverse cast of musicians, including John Mayer, Santana, Annie Lennox and Joss Stone. A great introduction to Hancock for a new generation.

- Summer

One of the best parts of the holiday season is getting to hear these wonderful songs again. Whitney Houston's “Do You Hear What I Hear?” and Stevie Nick's “Silent Night” have become holiday classics, but every single track is a gem in its own right. There's something for everyone on this CD.

- Summer

item.title: "Bend the Rules" Gift Labels
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Craft phenomenon Amy Karol has created a sticker set of gift tags – featuring clever quotes and cheerful colors – that say what you're really thinking.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Sometimes a “warmest wishes” on the gift tag just doesn't cut it. That's why crafter and rule-bender Amy Karol designed these colorful gift tags with honest sentiments like “Please act surprised when you open this, okay?” With their non-traditional colors, you can place these labels on gifts year-round for an extra special touch.

- Summer

item.title: Barefoot Contessa Back to Basics
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Ina Garten's bestselling cookbooks have consistently provided accessible, subtly sophisticated recipes ranging from French classics made easy to delicious, simple home cooking. In "Barefoot Contessa Back to Basics," Ina truly breaks down her ideas on flavor, examining the ingredients and techniques that are the foundation of her easy, refined style.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
In her sixth cookbook, Garten reminds us that simple doesn't have to mean boring. Her recipes are delicious, appealing and accessible, emphasizing uncomplicated techniques and the absolute best ingredients.

- Summer

item.title: A Photographer's Life : 1990-2005
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: “ I don’ t have two lives, ” Annie Leibovitz writes in the Introduction to this collection of her work from 1990— 2005. “ This is one life, and the personal pictures and the assignment work are all part of it.” Portraits of well-known figures– Johnny Cash, Nicole Kidman, Mikhail Baryshnikov, Keith Richards, Michael Jordan, Joan Didion, R2-D2, Patti Smith, Nelson Mandela, Jack Nicholson, William Burroughs, George W. Bush with members of his Cabinet– appear alongside pictures of Leibovitz’ s family and friends, reportage from the siege of Sarajevo in the early Nineties, and landscapes made even more indelible through Leibovitz’ s discerning eye. The images form a narrative rich in contrasts and continuities: The photographer has a long relationship that ends with illness and death. She chronicles the celebrations and heartbreaks of her large and robust family. She has children of her own. All the while she is working, and the public work resonates with the themes of her life.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Leibovitz gives us a very intimate portrait of her life as one of the world's top photographers. Interspersed with her breathtaking celebrity photographs are photos of Leibovitz herself, her partner Susan Sontag and their family. The photos of Sontag especially are heartbreaking, and show's Leibovitz's genius as a documenter of life.

- Summer

item.title: Night Owl Paper Goods
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Design duo Jennifer Tatham and Alan Henderson created Night Owl Paper Goods to showcase their adorable folk arts-y drawings on wood. The birch covers of these mini notebooks and journals are sustainably harvested, and so cool looking you'll be thinking of things to jot down all day.

item.title: 15" Max Plush
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This adorably huggable plush version of Max from Where the Wild Things Are brings the book to life. A perfect gift for kids and adults who love the classic story.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
I never get tired of this hysterically funny classic, and it's become a beloved tradition to watch it with the whole family during the holidays.

- Summer

item.title: Well-Worded Bookmarks
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Bob's Your Uncle is a Boston Based gift and greeting card company founded by Martin and Michele Yeeles in 2001. Originally from England, they moved to the United States in 1993 "just for a year or two" and have been in Boston ever since. Martin is a graphic designer, Michele a former shoe designer.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The next time you give a friend a book (or lend them a favorite copy of yours), include a pack of these bold and colorful bookmarks. No more dog-eared pages! They're a perfect gift for those who like to read several books at a time.

- Summer

item.title: Valentino: The Last Emperor
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This documentary offers a fond look at world-renowned fashion designer Valentino Garavani. Vanity Fair writer Matt Tyrnauer sits in the director's chair, pulling back the curtains for an all-access tour of haute-couture culture, recording the corporate struggles and runway-set hilarity as Valentino prepares to retire from his clothing empire.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Valentino is one of fashion's great luminaries. This documentary features behind-the-scenes at his runway shows, at home with partner Giancarlo Giametti and preparing for a retrospective of his work. The fashion is on full, lavish display, but the loving relationship between Valentino and Giametti is the heart of the film.

- Summer

item.title: Grey Gardens
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Out in East Hampton, behind a cloud of overgrown foliage and weeds, there is a large decaying mansion which is home to Edith Bouvier Beale and her grown-up daughter Little Edie. Big and Little Edie are the aunt and first cousin of Jacquelyn Kennedy Onassis, and this documentary is a portrait of their unusual life together.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
When it was discovered that two of Jackie Kennedy's cousins were living in squalor in East Hampton, it caused a stir. But nothing compared to the stir – and cult following – caused by the documentary starring Big Edie and Little Edie Beale. They argue bitterly about the past and what stars they could have been if life hadn't intervened along the way. Little Edie is especially captivating, and her style and philosophy earned her a host of imitators and iconic status.

- Summer

Her rich, supple voice sounds both old – like the bluesy divas of yesterday – and completely new.  The songs are clean and spare, with a mix of British acoustic and American jazz and soul. Adele sings each song of love and loss with passion and conviction.

- Summer

This is probably the album that introduced most of us to reggae. Marley's genius was in combining sometimes political, sometimes romantic and often spiritual songs with a funky world beat for a uniquely listenable album. An essential CD for every music fan's collection.

– Summer

This is probably the album that introduced most of us to reggae. Marley's genius was in combining sometimes political, sometimes romantic and often spiritual songs with a funky world beat for a uniquely listenable album. An essential CD for every music fan's collection.

– Summer

item.title: Al Green: More Greatest Hits
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Al Green is one of the best soul singers and his silky voice is a treasure. This eclectic mix includes some of his best-known songs along with earlier work that you might not have heard.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Al Green is one of the best soul singers and his silky voice is a treasure. This eclectic mix includes some of his best-known songs along with earlier work that you might not have heard.

- Summer

Over-the-top, fun and original. Unlike a lot of fluffy, feel-good pop music, this one has real heart and soul behind it. Scissor Sisters made disco cool again.

– Summer

item.title: Ad Hoc at Home
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In the book every home cook has been waiting for, the revered Thomas Keller turns his imagination to the American comfort foods closest to his heart-flaky biscuits, chicken pot pies, New England clam bakes, and cherry pies so delicious and redolent of childhood that they give Proust's madeleines a run for their money. Keller, whose restaurants The French Laundry in Yountville, California, and Per Se in New York have revolutionized American haute cuisine, is equally adept at turning out simpler fare.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Keller is an award-winning and highly esteemed chef whose famed restaurants (like Ad Hoc, and his iconic French Laundry) don't always seemed geared for home cooks. With his latest cookbook, he takes the casual menu of Ad Hoc and makes family style meals seem like the ultimate in sophistication.

- Summer

item.title: Red Currant Candle
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Fill your home with the fragrance of the holidays. Red Currant is one of Votivo's most popular scents, and it's dressed up for the season in a beautiful box with silver accents.

item.title: The Bloom County Library, Volume One
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Berkley Breathed's Bloom County was one of the most popular and critically acclaimed newspaper strips of all time. Bloom County ran from December 8th, 1980 to August 6th, 1989 and was published in an astounding 1200 newspapers on a daily basis. The huge popularity of Bloom County spawned a merchandizing bonanza, as well as two spin-off strips, Outland and Opus. The Bloom County Library Volume 1 highlights the first time the entire run of the immensely popular Bloom County strip has been collected in beautifully designed hard cover books with exceptional reproduction.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The comic strip “Bloom County” was one of the most politically astute, fanciful and just plain funny comic strips ever. This volume covers the first three years as the strip finds its footing – and makes us all love a penguin named Opus. It's delightful to see the strip, and Breathed's artistic ability, evolve over time.

- Summer

item.title: The Daily Book of Art
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In today's fast-paced world, creative people are as eager as ever to pursue their artistic passions, but many of them simply don't have enough time. Catering to this modern dilemma, we've concocted the perfect remedy for over-burdened artists." The Daily Book of Art" includes a year's worth of brief daily readings and lessons about the visual arts that entertain as they inform. Ten exciting categories of discussion rotate throughout the course of a year, giving readers a well-rounded experience in the art world. From color psychology and aesthetic philosophy to the proverbial argument over whether elephants really can paint, art-starved readers will encounter a broad range of inspiring subjects. The book also features a ribbon bookmark so readers can keep their place throughout the year.

In today's fast-paced world, creative people are as eager as ever to pursue their artistic passions, but many of them simply don't have enough time. Catering to this modern dilemma, we've concocted the perfect remedy for over-burdened artists." The Daily Book of Art" includes a year's worth of brief daily readings and lessons about the visual arts that entertain as they inform. Ten exciting categories of discussion rotate throughout the course of a year, giving readers a well-rounded experience in the art world. From color psychology and aesthetic philosophy to the proverbial argument over whether elephants really can paint, art-starved readers will encounter a broad range of inspiring subjects. The book also features a ribbon bookmark so readers can keep their place throughout the year.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
If you're a visual artist, you know how difficult it can be to get inspired every single day. With this enlightening and entertaining book, inspiration is in abundance. Each day's reading includes a lesson and some thought-provoking ideas about art history and theory. Even if you're not a visual artist, this book can help unlock your creative potential.

- Summer

item.title: French Feasts
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In France, where eating is a national pastime, the long, leisurely Sunday lunch is a feast for the senses. It is this quality that acclaimed chef and author Stephane Reynaud captures so perfectly in his paean to traditional French cooking. Rustic and approachable, humorous and convivial, "French Feasts" features 299 recipes for beloved dishes like pates, gratins, savory tarts, and braised meats that are the essence of French weekend fare.From classic stews like navarin and boeuf bourguignon, to fois gras prepared six different ways, to creme brulee and gateau Basque, the recipes come from all over France and even some former colonies (couscous is a national favorite). The book also includes beautiful, earthy photographs, whimsical illustrations, profiles of local producers, and fact-filled sidebars--a guide to cognac and Armagnac, how to make the perfect croissant, and much more--that evoke the considerable pleasures of the French table.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This is not just a cookbook – it's a guidebook to family life in France. Besides the 299 recipes covering everything from fois gras and terrines to stews and tarts, Reynaud sprinkles the book with stories about great French cooks, whimsical illustrations, gorgeous photographs and even some song lyrics. A feast for the senses.

- Summer

item.title: A Gate at the Stairs
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In her dazzling new novel–her first in more than a decade–Moore turns her eye on the anxiety and disconnection of post-9/11 America, on the insidiousness of racism, the blind-sidedness of war, and the recklessness thrust on others in the name of love.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Moore is the master of witty, intricate wordplay and A Gate at the Stairs showcases her mastery to fine effect. I couldn't turn the pages fast enough as the story of Tassie unfolded. Moore handles themes of adoption, race, terrorism, class and other issues with humor and compassion in one of the best books of the year.

- Summer

item.title: The Artist's Way : A Spiritual Path to Higher Creativity
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The Artist’s Way is the seminal book on the subject of creativity. An international bestseller, millions of readers have found it to be an invaluable guide to living the artist’s life. Still as vital today—or perhaps even more so—than it was when it was first published one decade ago, it is a powerfully provocative and inspiring work. In a new introduction to the book, Julia Cameron reflects upon the impact of The Artist’s Way and describes the work she has done during the last decade and the new insights into the creative process that she has gained. Updated and expanded, this anniversary edition reframes The Artist’s Way for a new century.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This is an in-depth, insightful twelve-week program to reveal the untapped creative potential within all of us. By connecting spirituality with creativity, authors Julie Cameron and Mark Bryan guide the reader through overcoming creative blocks on the road to becoming a more confident and productive artist. If you are willing to commit and believe in yourself, this book can change your life.

- Summer

item.title: Rosie Flo's Garden Coloring Book
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Rosie Flo is having a garden party, and the wonderful clothes are all here. You're invited to join in the fun by creating just the right character to wear each costume. You draw the heads, legs, and arms, and then color and finish each scene exactly as you like. Look for dresses inspired by flowers and plants of all sorts and some charming fairies and gnomes, too.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
With Rosie Flo's coloring books, kids don't just color – they create! Add heads, arms and legs to create different characters for the whimsical costumes inspired by flowers, plants, fairies and gnomes. Fun for kids and adults alike.

- Summer

item.title: Nurse Jackie: Season One
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Take home all 12 episodes from the first season of NURSE JACKIE with this release also featuring cast and crew commentaries, "All About Edie," "Unsung Heroes," and "Prepping Nurse Jackie" featurettes, and nurse stories.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Usually television medical dramas give us the “doctor as God” viewpoint, but “Nurse Jackie” is about a nurse who is no saintly caregiver. She's got serious flaws – a drug problem and an adulterous relationship with her supplier, to name two – but Jackie is so compelling, so human. I adore Edie Falco's brilliant portrayal of Jackie, but the entire cast is terrific.

- Summer

item.title: Vicky Christina Barcelona
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Vicky (Rebecca Hall) and Cristina (Scarlett Johansson) are American best friends who have the luck of spending several summer months in the Spanish city of the title. Though the pair is inseparable, they clash over love: Vicky is engaged to the trustworthy Doug (Chris Messina), while Cristina is forever in search of new experiences and passions. When a fiery Spanish painter named Juan Antonio (Javier Bardem) proposes that the three fly off to Oviedo for the weekend with the goal of making love, the women are divided, but they both eventually agree to the trip. After unexpected events in Oviedo, they return to Barcelona where Juan Antonio's obsessive ex-wife (Pénélope Cruz) enters the picture. As the rule-bound Vicky, Hall—who has been largely unknown to American audiences before this film--gives a wonderfully witty performance that keeps pace with her more famous costars.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This is one of my favorite Woody Allen films. The Vicky and Cristina of the title are American tourists, seduced by Barcelona and one smooth-talking artist named Juan Antonio. When Juan Antonio's estranged (and maybe insane) wife Maria Elena gets added to the mix, it gets downright explosive. Romantic, sensual and highly recommended.

- Summer

item.title: Whatever Works
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The New York-based humor of Woody Allen and CURB YOUR ENTHUSIAM’s Larry David seems like a natural match, and the pair unite for the first time in this comedy. WHATEVER WORKS follows a rich man (David), who decides that he should be living a different, less status-based life.
