Evan Rachel Wood, Patricia Clarkson, Ed Begley Jr., and Michael McKean star in this film that marks Allen’s cinematic return to New York City.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
I don't think anyone plays a better grouch than Larry David. Paired with the genius of Woody Allen, David's caustic zingers are even more brilliant. David plays Boris, a nuclear physicist with more brains than heart, and Evan Rachel Wood plays a much younger Southern beauty queen who's just the opposite. Their quirky relationship makes for great comedy that is classic Woody Allen all the way.

- Summer

item.title: An Education
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Author Nick Hornby turns from novels to screenplays with this talent-driven drama. Carey Mulligan (BLEAK HOUSE) stars as Jenny, a young woman full of promise and intent to study at Oxford. But meeting an older man (Peter Sarsgaard) leads Jenny to believe that she can learn things outside the classroom, casting doubt on her future plans. Directed by ITALIAN FOR BEGINNERS’ Lone Scherfig, AN EDUCATION also stars Alfred Molina, Rosamunde Pike, Dominic Cooper, Olivia Williams, and Emma Thompson.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Carey Mulligan was rightly nominated for an Academy Award for her performance as Jenny, a British schoolgirl seduced by an older man. She's simply luminous, with a wisdom and intelligence beyond her years. I fell in love with her in this role, and can't wait to see what the future has in store for this talented actress.

- Summer

item.title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee
item.dc:creator: admin

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Robin Wright gives a luminous, moving performance as Pippa Lee, a middle-aged woman and devoted wife and mother. Her life seems perfect but a move to a quiet retirement village with her much older husband causes her life to unravel. The entire cast is fantastic, but it's the female performances – from a cast that includes Maria Bello, Blake Lively, Julianne Moore and Monica Bellucci – that I found riveting.

- Summer

item.title: The Lace Reader
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In Barry's captivating debut, Towner Whitney, a young woman descended from a long line of mind readers and fortune tellers, has returned to her hometown of Salem, Massachusetts, for rest and relaxation. Any tranquility in her life is short-lived, however, when her aunt drowns under mysterious circumstances.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The Whitney women of Salem, Massachusetts have the unique talent of reading fortunes in lace. Towner Whitney can not only read lace, but also minds. After the death of her twin sister, Towner left Salem, vowing never to read lace again. When Towner returns ten years later following the disappearance of her beloved great aunt, she must face the ghosts of her past.

- Summer

item.title: The Help
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Three ordinary women are about to take one extraordinary step.
Twenty-two-year-old Skeeter has just returned home after graduating from Ole Miss. She may have a degree, but it is 1962, Mississippi, and her mother will not be happy till Skeeter has a ring on her finger. Skeeter would normally find solace with her beloved maid Constantine, the woman who raised her, but Constantine has disappeared and no one will tell Skeeter where she has gone.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The Help follows the lives of three remarkable women in 1960s Jackson, Mississippi: Aibileen and Minny, who are black maids, and Skeeter, a white woman who has just graduated from Ole Miss with dreams of becoming a writer. When an editor tells Skeeter to write about what disturbs her, she finds her subject matter in the relationships between the black domestics and their white employers.

- Summer

item.title: The Poisonwood Bible
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Kingsolver's national bestseller paints an intimate portrait of a crisis-ridden family amid the larger backdrop of an African nation in chaos. Examine how the tragedy of the Price family mirrors the political unrest in the Congo, how the novel views religion and marriage, and how Kingsolver reconciles the demands of art with her belief that writing should support a political cause.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Fiery missionary Nathan Price takes his wife and four daughters into the heart of the Congo in the late 1960s. Their story is told through the voices of his four daughters, Rachel, Leah, Adah and Ruth May, and his wife Orleanna. As adventure and danger envelop the family you can be certain that salvation is the one think they will not uncover on this memorable journey.

- Summer

item.title: The Prophet
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A brilliant man's philosophy on love, marriage, joy and sorrow, time, friendship and much more. Originally published in 1923 - translated into more than 20 languages. With 12 full page drawings by Gibran.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
A collection of simple and lyrical pearls of wisdom dispensed by a fictional prophet named Almustafa to his people. It is impossible not to come away inspired after reading it.

- Summer

item.title: Up In The Air
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: After getting Oscar attention for JUNO, director Jason Reitman turns to this adaptation of Walter Kirn's comic novel. Academy Award-winner George Clooney stars as Ryan Bingham, a businessman on the verge of reaching five million frequent flyer miles when his company decides to cut back on travel. But his goal isn't the only thing just out of reach: he now won't be able to see a fellow frequent traveler (THE DEPARTED's Vera Farmiga) who has caught his eye.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
With corporate downsizing on every American's mind lately, this film couldn't have come along at a better time. George Clooney plays a man who lays people off for a living, spending 322 days on the road. Clooney is our generation's Cary Grant – he's got movie star good looks, charisma and the ability to make us laugh even when the subject is as serious as this one. I think this is one movie that will stand the test of time as a modern, must-see classic.

- Summer

item.title: Volver
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Pedro Almodóvar, the Oscar-winning writer-director of such international successes as TALK TO HER and WOMEN ON THE VERGE OF A NERVOUS BREAKDOWN, returns to his hometown of La Mancha in Spain for the tender VOLVER. Raimunda (Penélope Cruz) is trying to keep her family together despite her husband's (Antonio de la Torre) inability to keep his job; when a terrible incident occurs at home, Raimunda covers it up in order to protect her daughter, Paula (Yohana Cobo). Meanwhile, Raimunda's sister, Sole (Lola Dueñas), believes that their mother, Irene (Carmen Maura), has come back from the dead; Sole even has the resurrected Irene working in the illegal hair salon she has set up in her apartment. Sole and their neighbor Agustina (Blanca Portillo), who had been taking care of their aged aunt (Chus Lampreave), try to keep this secret from Raimunda, with both funny and heartbreaking results--and the revealing of yet more secrets. Once again Almodóvar, who won the Best Screenplay Award at Cannes for VOLVER, displays his unique talent for creating fascinating female characters in this intricate study of three generations of women.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
I am such a fan of Penelope Cruz. She always brings vulnerability and a considerable amount of heat to her roles. As Raimunda, Cruz is earthy, soulful and completely mesmerizing. While the movie is about mothers and daughters, and the resilient strength of women, it's no “chick flick.” See it for an amazing story populated by some of the world's best actresses.﻿

- Summer

item.title: Pirate Radio
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: British helmer Richard Curtis (LOVE ACTUALLY) directs a cast of his countrymen (plus lone American star Philip Seymour Hoffman) in this comedy set in Britain in 1966. While the BBC would allow only two hours of rock and roll to be played on its airwaves a week, pirate stations broadcast music to the pop-starved masses. THE BOAT THAT ROCKED also stars Bill Nighy, Nick Frost, Rhys Ifans, and Kenneth Branagh.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This movie is great, upbeat fun! It's set in Great Britain in the '60s when rock and roll was banned over the airwaves and rock stations broadcast from ships offshore. The cast is fantastic, the music is phenomenal. Don't miss it!

- Summer

item.title: Crazy Heart
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Jeff Bridges stars in this drama based on Thomas Cobb's first novel about an alcoholic country singer. The musician's career is going downhill as he watches his protégé's star ascend, but his encounters with a journalist (THE DARK KNIGHT's Maggie Gyllenhaal) might just keep him from hitting rock bottom. Oscar winner Robert Duvall costars and serves as one of the film's producers.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
I don't remember a time when I didn't have a crush on Jeff Bridges. He's always played guys you wanted to know, or wanted to be, and this movie is no exception. His down-on-his-luck country singer Bad Blake is frankly one of the most natural, tender, heartfelt performances I've ever seen. I can't say enough about this wonderful film. I guarantee it will move you.

- Summer

item.title: The Very Short Introduction Series
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Oxford's Very Short Introductions series offers concise and original introductions to a wide range of subjects–from Islam to Sociology, Politics to Classics, Literary Theory to History, and Archaeology to the Bible. Not simply a textbook of definitions, each volume in this series provides trenchant and provocative–yet always balanced and complete–discussions of the central issues in a given discipline or field. Every Very Short Introduction gives a readable evolution of the subject in question, demonstrating how the subject has developed and how it has influenced society.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The “Very Short Introduction” series packs a world of information into a handy pocket size. Whenever I want a good introduction to a complex topic or just need a refresher, these clear, concise books give me a solid framework. Written by experts, the books are both informative and entertaining – they're even used as textbooks in many universities.

- Summer

item.title: Bridge School Concerts, Vol. 1
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Bridge School Benefit is an annual non-profit charity concert held in Mountain View, California every October at the Shoreline Amphitheater. The concerts are all organized by musician Neil Young and his wife, Pegi. Proceeds benefit The Bridge School. The first concert was in October 1986, and, with the exception of 1987, the concert has been held every year since. As a practice, but not a rule, the performers use acoustic instruments. Young also personally performs every year.
This album is the first collection of songs in a 4-volume series.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
In 1986, music legend Neil Young gathered with some musician friends to play a benefit concert for The Bridge School, a school for children with several physical and speech impairments. Now in its 24th year, the annual benefit lineup still includes Young, along with luminaries of the music industry. It's a great cause to support, but the best reason to own this CD is its moving, heartfelt performances. Gorgeous, powerful live music with a great cause behind it – music doesn't get any better than this!

- Summer

item.title: Rosie Flo's Animals Coloring Book
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A zebra dress, a peacock skirt, a spiderweb gown, giraffe boots, and many other fantastic creations await you in this animal-themed Rosie Flo coloring book. You add the heads, legs, and arms for each costume, and then color the characters, their animals, and their surroundings any way as you see fit. You decide exactly how these wild fashions will come to life.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
English designer Roz Streeten created her line of "Rosie Flo" coloring books for her own daughters, and your daughters will love them, too. The whimsical illustrations of animal-themed dresses give kids room to use their imaginations and create people (or creatures!) to wear the clothing. Makes a wonderful gift for children!

- Summer

item.title: Modern Family, Season 1
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Today's Modern Family comes in all shapes and sizes. Just ask these three families.
Jay recently married Gloria. Now Jay is trying hard to keep up with his much younger and hotter Colombian wife, along with her passionate pre-teen son, Manny. Claire is having a hard time raising her own family. Her husband Phil is great, except that he thinks he's "down" with their three kids, much to all their embarrassment. And, Mitchell and his enthusiastic partner Cameron have just made a major life change by adopting a Vietnamese baby named Lily.
Who doesn't think their family is the strangest one out there? So, when we heard executive producers Steve Levitan (Just Shoot Me) and Christopher Lloyd (Frasier) were taking on what it means to grow up or be a parent in this day and age, we knew we found a modern comedy we could relate to.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
No other TV show makes me laugh as much as “Modern Family.” It is so clever, week after week. Ed O'Neill – best known as Al Bundy from “Married with Children” – is Jay Pritchett, patriarch of a complex, multigenerational family. The family contains a mix of ages, sexual orientations, nationalities – it truly is a modern family! If only my own family were consistently this hilarious...

- Summer

item.title: Hush
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: "New York Times" bestselling author and "Cosmopolitan"'s editor-in-chief returns with a sizzling, page-turning thriller in which an ordinary woman flees the scene of a murder–and realizes it's not just the law that's hunting her.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Cosmopolitan editor-in-chief has penned another glamorous, spine-tingling page turner. Newly divorced, 40-something Lake Warren's ex-husband is suing for full custody of their kids and her lawyer has advised her to not even date until after the case is settled. After she gives in to a passionate night with a sexy doctor, the stakes take a deadly turn. The combination of family issues with a murder mystery is so compelling. I couldn't put this suspense thriller down for a second!

- Summer

item.title: This Is Where I Leave You
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The death of Judd Foxman's father marks the first time that the entire Foxman clan has congregated in years. There is, however, one conspicuous absence: Judd's wife, Jen, whose affair with his radio- shock-jock boss has recently become painfully public. Simultaneously mourning the demise of his father and his marriage, Judd joins his dysfunctional family as they reluctantly sit shiva-and spend seven days and nights under the same roof. The week quickly spins out of control as longstanding grudges resurface, secrets are revealed and old passions are reawakened. Then Jen delivers the clincher: she's pregnant.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Judd Foxman's marriage has flamed out spectacularly (and publicly) and his father has died. But the worst part is that his father's final request was that his family sit shiva for the full, traditional seven days. Seven days with Judd's dysfunctional family would test anyone's endurance -- toss in the unraveling marriages and it's a disaster waiting to happen. What I found surprising is how hilarious the Foxman family foibles can be, and how sharply Tropper renders even the most minor of characters in this sweet, funny novel.

- Summer

item.title: What Should I Do with My Life?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The bestselling author of Bombardiers and The First $20 Million Is Always the Hardest traveled the world in search of people who had found meaningful answers to one of life's greatest questions: What should I do with my life?"

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
While it's not a self-help book like the title might make you think – this book won't guide you through the steps to find your perfect job – it does offer amazing, inspiring stories from real people looking, and sometimes finding, fulfilling careers. The book probably won't give you an answer to its titular question, but it can point you in the right direction to discover your own.

- Summer

item.title: I Love Your Style
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The former muse and creative director for designer label Tuleh, and author of the blog In Her Eyes for Men′s Vogue, Amanda Brooks is a lifelong fashion chameleon with an unerring eye for the elements of personal style. Smart, glamorous, media-savvy and remarkably practical, Amanda has spent her entire life constructing a unique, eclectic and intimately personal sense of style. With classic roots, bohemian flair, a taste for designer luxuries, and a love for bargains everywhere, Amanda has looked to every imaginable source of fashion inspiration-from high-fashion runways and magazines, to thrift stores and classic movies, to her neighbors in downtown New York and old family photo albums. In I Love Your Style, Amanda helps women of all ages begin to cull through the frighteningly vast world of fashion, from its staid basics to its trendiest moments.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Amanda Brooks is a well-known fashion muse and tastemaker who dispenses thoughtful advice in this essential style book. Brooks combines gorgeous photos of well-dressed people from the past and present with her own personal dress history and musings on being stylish, rather than just fashionable. It lets you be you but with a little “how-to” guidance.

- Summer

item.title: The Overnight Socialite
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: From the author of the media sensation Because She Can, a modern retelling of classics My Fair Lady and Pygmalion, The Overnight Socialite tells a timeless story of transformation and unlikely love set against the glittering backdrop of contemporary Manhattan.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Even if you know the tale of Pygmalion – and the movie My Fair Lady – by heart, you'll be captivated by this modern retelling. Lucy Jo is a Minnesota girl new to New York City, with a dream of becoming a fashion designer. Wyatt Hayes is the city's most eligible bachelor. Wyatt has the bright idea of taking a female nobody and transforming her into an “overnight socialite,” then writing a book about his experiment. Lucy Jo takes Wyatt up on his offer and soon changes from country girl to popular It girl. We all know the original story, but this version is full of fresh twists and lots of romance.

- Summer

item.title: The Little Prince Pop-Up
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: After being stranded in a desert after a crash, a pilot comes in contact with a captivating little prince who recounts his journey from planet to planet and his search for what is most important in life. For over sixty-five years Antoine de Saint-Exupery's classic, "The Little Prince," has captured readers' hearts. The whimsical story with a fairy tale feel has sold over 3 million copies in all formats. This exciting pop-up edition includes the complete original text accompanied by Saint-Exupery's beautiful illustrations brought to life through paper engineering. Perfect for longtime fans and those meeting the little prince for the first time

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The beloved, timeless tale of the Little Prince gets a delightful update with this pop-up edition. I have read this book so many times I have practically committed it to heart, but the pop-ups featuring the author's original illustrations added another dimension to this treasured story.

- Summer
Antoine de Saint-Exupery and Richard Howard

item.title: The Great Gatsby
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Literary Book Club June 2007 Selection: The exemplary novel of the Jazz Age, F. Scott Fitzgeralds' third book, The Great Gatsby (1925), stands as the supreme achievement of his career. T. S. Eliot read it three times and saw it as the "first step" American fiction had taken since Henry James; H. L. Mencken praised "the charm and beauty of the writing," as well as Fitzgerald's sharp social sense; and Thomas Wolfe hailed it as Fitzgerald's "best work" thus far. The story of the fabulously wealthy Jay Gatsby and his love for the beautiful Daisy Buchanan, of lavish parties on Long Island at a time when, The New York Times remarked, "gin was the national drink and sex the national obsession," it is an exquisitely crafted tale of America in the 1920s that resonates with the power of myth. A novel of lyrical beauty yet brutal realism, of magic, romance, and mysticism, The Great Gatsby is one of the great classics of twentieth-century literature.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Fitzgerald's masterpiece is the great American novel, the sparkling story that forever defined the time in which it was written. It's a novel about the American Dream -- a rags-to-riches story about a poor man who re-invents himself as a mysterious millionaire in hopes of winning the heart of the beautiful rich girl he has loved forever. I first read and loved The Great Gatsby as a teenager, and have read it many times since then; I'm still as captivated by the characters and as devastated by the ending.

- Summer

item.title: The Old Man and the Sea
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Hemingway's triumphant yet tragic story of an old Cuban fisherman and his relentless, agonizing battle with a giant marlin far out in the Gulf Stream combines the simplicity of a fable, the significance of a parable, and the drama of an epic.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
I've lost count of how many times I've read this one – it's a favorite. Hemingway's spare, unsentimental style was never better than in this classic tale of an old fisherman and his final, greatest catch. An incredible tale of human fortitude everyone can admire.

- Summer

item.title: The Girl Who Played with Fire
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Mikael Blomkvist, crusading journalist and publisher of the magazine "Millennium, " has decided to run a story that will expose an extensive sex trafficking operation between Eastern Europe and Sweden, implicating well-known and highly placed members of Swedish society, business, and government. But he has no idea just how explosive the story will be until, on the eve of publication, the two investigating reporters are murdered. And even more shocking for Blomkvist: the fingerprints found on the murder weapon belong to Lisbeth Salander--the troubled, wise-beyond-her-years genius hacker who came to his aid in The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo, and who now becomes the focus and fierce heart of The Girl Who Played with Fire. As Blomkvist, alone in his belief in Salander's innocence, plunges into an investigation of the slayings, Salander herself is drawn into a murderous hunt in which she is the prey, and which compels her to revisit her dark past in an effort to settle with it once and for all.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This sequel to Larsson's The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo is page-turning, edge-of-your-seat fiction that will have you up reading long past your bedtime. The novel picks up a year after the events of the first book, and doesn't miss a beat.

- Summer

item.title: The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: An international publishing sensation, Stieg Larsson's Girl with the Dragon Tattoo combines murder mystery, family saga, love story, and financial intrigue into one satisfyingly complex and entertainingly atmospheric novel. Harriet Vanger, a scion of one of Sweden's wealthiest families disappeared over forty years ago. All these years later, her aged uncle continues to seek the truth. He hires Mikael Blomkvist, a crusading journalist recently trapped by a libel conviction, to investigate. He is aided by the pierced and tattooed punk prodigy Lisbeth Salander. Together they tap into a vein of unfathomable iniquity and astonishing corruption.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Mikael Blomkvist, a muckraking financial journalist, and Lisbeth Salander, a 24-year-old genius hacker (the tattooed girl of the title) investigate a decades-old disappearance and uncover more than they bargained for. This Swedish murder mystery hooks you from the first page and won't let go.

- Summer

item.title: Me Talk Pretty One Day
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: David Sedaris' collection, Me Talk Pretty One Day, tells a most unconventional life story. It begins with a North Carolina childhood filled with speech-therapy classes ("There was the lisp, of course, but more troubling than that was my voice itself with its excitable tone and high, girlish pitch") and unwanted guitar lessons taught by a midget. From budding performance artist ("The only crimp in my plan was that I seemed to have no talent whatsoever") to "clearly unqualified" writing teacher in Chicago, Sedaris's career leads him to New York (the sky's-the-limit field of furniture moving) and eventually, of all places, France.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Dark, hilarious and touching, Sedaris unflinchingly skewers his offbeat family and himself.  There are plenty of laugh-out-loud moments, including the one where his French class attempts to explain Easter to a Moroccan Muslim student.

- Summer

item.title: Into The Wild
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In April 1992 a young man from a well-to-do family hitchhiked to Alaska and walked alone into the wilderness north of Mt. McKinley. His name was Christopher Johnson McCandless. He had given $25,000 in savings to charity, abandoned his car and most of his possessions, burned all the cash in his wallet, and invented a new life for himself. Four months later, his decomposed body was found by a moose hunter. How McCandless came to die is the unforgettable story of Into the Wild.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
In April 1992, Chris McCandless was a promising young college graduate who left his family and friends, and most of his material possessions, to set out on an odyssey to the Alaskan wilderness. Four months later, his emaciated body was discovered. Was he an idealistic adventurer, or just reckless and irresponsible? Krakauer explores what motivates Chris and other dreamers like him.

- Summer

item.title: The Art Of Racing In The Rain
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A heart-wrenching but deeply funny and ultimately uplifting look at the wonders and absurdities of human life . . . as only a dog could tell it.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Written from the perspective of a wise dog named Enzo, on the eve of his death. Enzo believes that he will come back as a human after he dies. A heartbreaking and compassionate look at the nature of family, loyalty and love.

- Summer

item.title: Change of Heart
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The acclaimed #1 New York Times bestselling author presents a spellbinding tale of a mother's tragic loss and one man's last chance at gaining salvation. Can we save ourselves, or do we rely on others to do it? Is what we believe always the truth?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Told from the viewpoints of four people – a Catholic priest, a mother who has lost her daughter and husband, a convicted murderer, and an ACLU lawyer – the novel explores themes of religion, capital punishment, guilt, innocence and forgiveness.

- Summer

item.title: When You Are Engulfed in Flames
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Once again, David Sedaris brings together a collection of essays so uproariously funny and profoundly moving that his legions of fans will fall for him once more. He tests the limits of love when Hugh lances a boil from his backside, and pushes the boundaries of laziness when, finding the water shut off in his house in Normandy, he looks to the water in a vase of fresh cut flowers to fill the coffee machine. From armoring the windows with LP covers to protect the house from neurotic songbirds to the awkwardness of having a lozenge fall from your mouth into the lap of a sleeping fellow passenger on a plane, David Sedaris uses life's most bizarre moments to reach new heights in understanding love and fear, family and strangers. Culminating in a brilliantly funny (and never before published) account of his venture to Tokyo in order to quit smoking, David Sedaris's sixth essay collection will be avidly anticipated.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Sedaris can make even the most awkward or embarrassing situation hilarious, and he proves that in his sixth book. This time around, Sedaris regales us with tales of foul-mouthed airline passengers, befriending a Normandy neighbor who happens to be a pedophile and being forced to give back scratches to a grotesque babysitter. Even in his most epic tales of humiliation, the author’s empathy for human imperfection shines through.

- Summer

item.title: Shantaram
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: "It took me a long time and most of the world to learn what I know about love and fate and the choices we make, but the heart of it came to me in an instant, while I was chained to a wall and being tortured." So begins this epic, mesmerizing first novel set in the underworld of contemporary Bombay. Shantaram is narrated by Lin, an escaped convict with a false passport who flees maximum security prison in Australia for the teeming streets of a city where he can disappear. Accompanied by his guide and faithful friend, Prabaker, the two enter Bombay's hidden society of beggars and gangsters, prostitutes and holy men, soldiers and actors, and Indians and exiles from other countries, who seek in this remarkable place what they cannot find elsewhere. As a hunted man without a home, family, or identity, Lin searches for love and meaning while running a clinic in one of the city's poorest slums, and serving his apprenticeship in the dark arts of the Bombay mafia. The search leads him to war, prison torture, murder, and a series of enigmatic and bloody betrayals. The keys to unlock the mysteries and intrigues that bind Lin are held by two people. The first is Khader Khan: mafia godfather, criminal-philosopher-saint, and mentor to Lin in the underworld of the Golden City. The second is Karla: elusive, dangerous, and beautiful, whose passions are driven by secrets that torment her and yet give her a terrible power. Burning slums and five-star hotels, romantic love and prison agonies, criminal wars and Bollywood films, spiritual gurus and mujaheddin guerrillas---this huge novel has the world of human experience in its reach, and a passionate love for India at its heart. Based on the life of the author, it is by any measure the debut of an extraordinary voice in literature.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This lushly written adventure set in India is the semi-autobiographical story of a man who escapes prison in Australia and flees to Bombay. There, he starts a free health clinic in the slums, apprentices for the Bombay mafia and falls in love with the enigmatic Karla, a woman with the inability to love him back. The characters are vividly drawn and, even at over 900 pages, you will race through this book.

item.title: The House on Mango Street
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Acclaimed by critics, beloved by readers of all ages, taught everywhere from inner-city grade schools to universities across the country, and translated all over the world, The House on Mango Street is the remarkable story of Esperanza Cordero. Told in a series of vignettes – sometimes heartbreaking, sometimes deeply joyous – it is the story of a young Latina girl growing up in Chicago, inventing for herself who and what she will become. Few other books in our time have touched so many readers.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Esperanza is a Mexican-American girl whose family moves to a house on Mango Street in a Chicago neighborhood. Esperanza is a girl caught in the middle: between girlhood and womanhood, her Mexican heritage and American culture, and the traditional roles of women and her own dreams. We see her neighborhood through her eyes as she begins to come into her own as a young woman.

- Summer

item.title: I'm So Happy for You
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Wendy's best friend, Daphne, has always been dependably prone to catastrophe. And Wendy has always been there to help. If Daphne veers from suicidal to madly in love, Wendy offers encouragement. But when Daphne is suddenly engaged, pregnant, and decorating a fabulous town house in no time at all, Wendy is...not so happy for her. Caught between wanting to be the best friend she prides herself on being and crippling jealousy of flighty Daphne, Wendy takes things to the extreme, waging a full-scale attack on her best friend-all the while wearing her best, I'm-so-happy-for-you smile-and ends up in way over her head.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Wendy, a 30-something editor, is obsessed with having children and with her ne'er-do-well husband finding a job. Meanwhile, her drama queen best friend Daphne – who is normally a walking disaster – has found Mr. Right and is soon pregnant and living the life Wendy so desperately wants. As Daphne's life gets better and better, Wendy's jealousy over her friend's new-found happiness reaches a fever pitch. A darkly comic social satire about skin-deep “friendships,” marriage and competition among women.

- Summer

item.title: Half Broke Horses
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: "Those old cows knew trouble was coming before we did." So begins the story of Lily Casey Smith, in Jeannette Walls' magnificent, true-life novel based on her no-nonsense, resourceful, hard working, and spectacularly compelling grandmother. By age six, Lily was helping her father break horses. At fifteen, she left home to teach in a frontier town–riding five hundred miles on her pony, all alone, to get to her job. She learned to drive a car ("I loved cars even more than I loved horses. They didn't need to be fed if they weren't working, and they didn't leave big piles of manure all over the place") and fly a plane, and, with her husband, ran a vast ranch in Arizona. She raised two children, one of whom is Jeannette's memorable mother, Rosemary Smith Walls, unforgettably portrayed in The Glass Castle.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Walls, author of the wildly successful memoir The Glass Castle, set out to learn more about her mother Rosemary, but ended up telling the tale of her grandmother, Lily. A tough cookie who was breaking horses at 6, running her family's ranch at 12 and an itinerant teacher traveling 500 miles to school at 15, Lily Casey Smith is a bullheaded, independent, no-nonsense woman. If you loved The Glass Castle, you will thoroughly enjoy meeting Walls' amazing grandmother.

- Summer

item.title: Sunflowers
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
From a talented new author comes a poignant and haunting novel of creation and desire, passion and madness, art and love.
A young prostitute seeking temporary refuge from the brothel, Rachel awakens in a beautiful garden in Arles to discover she is being sketched by a red-haired man in a yellow straw hat. This is no ordinary artist but the eccentric painter Vincent van Gogh–and their meeting marks the beginning of a remarkable relationship. He arrives at their first assignation at No. 1, Rue du Bout d'Arles, with a bouquet of wildflowers and a request to paint her–and before long, a deep, intense attachment grows between Rachel and the gifted, tormented soul.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
You probably know the story: brilliant, mad Van Gogh cut off an ear and presented it to a prostitute. In this tenderly told tale, the author takes a character who was a minor historical footnote – the prostitute, Rachel – and sees the last two years of Van Gogh's life through her eyes. A passionate novel of love and art, and their often tragic intersection.

- Summer

item.title: The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: January 1946: writer Juliet Ashton receives a letter from a stranger, a founding member of the Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society. And so begins a remarkable tale of the island of Guernsey during the German occupation, and of a society as extraordinary as its name.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Mary Ann Shaffer and Annie Barrows

In 1946 London, journalist Julie Ashton is rebuilding her life after the war. An unexpected letter from a man in Guernsey – one of Britain's Channel Islands, the only British soil to be occupied by the Nazis during WWII – captures her imagination and gives her an idea for a book. Her correspondence with the Guernsey “Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society” is by turns hilarious and moving. A charming tale about the magic of books and enduring friendships.

- Summer

item.title: The Lacuna
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In her most accomplished novel, Barbara Kingsolver takes us on an epic journey from the Mexico City of artists Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo to the America of Pearl Harbor, FDR, and J. Edgar Hoover. "The Lacuna" is a poignant story of a man pulled between two nations as they invent their modern identities.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Kingsolver's most ambitious novel to date follows Harrison Shephard, son of a Mexican mother and American father born in the early 20th century. He doesn't truly feel at home in either country, though his formative years are spent in Mexico where he meets Diego Rivera, Frida Kahlo and their “guest” Leon Trotsky. In the book's latter half, Shephard is a successful novelist in America and then his past catches up with him. Kingsolver's portrait of Mexico in the 1930s is mesmerizing, and the entire book is a demanding read with a definite payoff.

- Summer

item.title: The Postmistress
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
It is 1940. France has fallen. Bombs are dropping on London. And President Roosevelt is promising he won't send our boys to fight in "foreign wars."
But American radio gal Frankie Bard, the first woman to report from the Blitz in London, wants nothing more than to bring the war home. Frankie's radio dispatches crackle across the Atlantic ocean, imploring listeners to pay attention–as the Nazis bomb London nightly, and Jewish refugees stream across Europe. Frankie is convinced that if she can just get the right story, it will wake Americans to action and they will join the fight.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The Postmistress grabbed and kept my attention with a story of three wonderfully interesting women in the years 1940-41. Iris is the "postmistress" of the title, in small town Franklin, Massachusetts; Emma is the wife of the town's doctor; and Frankie is an American journalist reporting from London. In unexpected ways, the lives of these three women will become intertwined as war rages in Europe. The author uses rich descriptions that transport the reader in time – she really did her research with this book and makes this period of history come alive.

- Summer

item.title: The Catcher in the Rye
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: J.D. Salinger's classic of adolescent angst is now available for the first time in trade paperback. Holden Caulfield, knowing he is to be expelled from school, decides to leave early. He spends three days in New York City and tells the story of what he did and suffered there.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
In honor of the recent passing of legendary author J.D. Salinger, I must include The Catcher in the Rye as one of my all-time favorites. Since its publication almost 60 years ago, The Catcher in the Rye has been the masterpiece to which all other coming-of-age stories are compared. It's a novel many of us read as teenagers, when we truly felt we knew and understood Holden Caulfield. We could relate to his struggles to swim against the current, and his scorn for the "phonies." Read it again as an adult, and marvel at how well Salinger understood the mind of a not-quite-average teenager.

- Summer

item.title: Scribbles Coloring Book
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This is no ordinary coloring book With playful drawings, funny scenarios and fun-to-follow instructions, this book is not just for coloring, but for doodling, drawing, imagining and thinking.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This huge, 360-page coloring book is not your typical coloring book. With prompts like “draw flowers” or “this man needs a mustache,” kids get a kick start into coming up with their own creative ideas. Hours and hours of fun for kids (and adults!), plus it's educational, too.

- Summer

item.title: Wreck This Journal
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: For anyone who's ever wished to, but had trouble starting, keeping, or finishing a journal or sketchbook comes "Wreck This Journal," an illustrated book that features a subversive collection of prompts, asking readers to muster up their best mistake- and mess-making abilities to fill the pages of the book (and destroy them). Acclaimed illustrator Keri Smith encourages journalers to engage in "destructive" acts-poking holes through pages, adding photos and defacing them, painting with coffee, and more-in order to experience the true creative process. Readers discover a new way of art and journal making-and new ways to escape the fear of the blank page and fully engage in the creative process.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
I like to keep my books and journals in pristine condition, so this journal was a great challenge! The idea behind it is to “wreck” it – writing prompts on the pages encourage readers to fling it against the wall, tear pages, write on photos you've added, drag it around town – and nothing could be more fun or liberating. By engaging with your journal, and not just writing in it, you'll open up all sorts of creative possibilities.

- Summer

item.title: Doodles Coloring Book
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Renowned children's book illustrator Taro Gomi invites kids of all ages to not only color, but also draw, imagine, and create. Unfinished pictures and intriguing prompts foster children's powers of visualization, and at nearly 400 pages, this book provides plenty of room to stretch the imagination.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This almost 400-page book will engage and delight kids – and probably a more than a few adults -- for many, many hours. The book encourages children to come up with their own creative ideas on each page – drawing different scenes for each of the seasons, filling in words for a comic strip, completing the wonderful unfinished illustrations and much more.

- Summer

item.title: Private Lives of Pippa Lee
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Pippa Lee has just such a life in place at age fifty, when her older husband, a retired publisher, decides that they should move to a retirement community outside New York City. Pippa is suddenly deprived of the stimulation and distraction that had held everything in place. She begins losing track of her own mind; her foundations start to shudder, and gradually we learn the truth of the young life that led her finally to settle down in marriage–years of neglect and rebellion, wild transgressions and powerful defiance.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Pippa is 50 and married to Herb Lee, 30 years her senior. When Herb announces he wants to move to a retirement community in Connecticut, Pippa finds her life changing in ways she can't control. Pippa is adored by everyone and seems to have a charmed life, so her life's unraveling is a surprise. What's even more surprising is Pippa's turbulent past – and how it's shaped the woman she's become. I was intrigued and moved by this intelligent, witty, complex character study of a woman who could be Everywoman.

- Summer

item.title: Envirosax® Bags
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Envirosax® reusable shopping bags are spreading the eco-friendly message with style!
Chic, inexpensive and compact, Envirosax® environmentally friendly shopping bags carry the message of re-use to a world ready to embrace a brighter ecological future.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
These reusable bags are lightweight, waterproof, tough and pretty. They are stylish enough to carry to the grocery and out on the town. A small step that does a world of good.

- Summer

item.title: Listography: Your life in lists
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: List-makers rejoice! This quirky and imaginative guided journal is the ultimate tool for creating a unique autobiography entirely in list form. Some lists are obvious (greatest accomplishments, best friends, favorite food), others obscure (guiltiest pleasures, greatest acts of kindness, personal fashion trends), and each list is accompanied by hilarious illustrations. Listography is perfect for getting down all the details of a life less ordinary.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
If you're a compulsive list-maker, or know someone who is, this guided journal is a must-have! A great tool for self-exploration, it's fun to buy a copy for a friend to fill in at the same time and compare notes.

- Summer

item.title: Tuesdays with Morrie
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Maybe it was a grandparent, or a teacher, or a colleague. Someone older, patient and wise, who understood you when you were young and searching, helped you see the world as a more profound place, gave you sound advice to help you make your way through it.
For Mitch Albom, that person was Morrie Schwartz, his college professor from nearly twenty years ago.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Albom spent every Tuesday for 14 weeks with his beloved former college professor, Morrie Schwartz, who was dying. Morrie's lessons on living a meaningful life at the end of his own life are timeless and wise, and Albom's moving tribute to his mentor is a must read.

- Summer

item.title: The Glass Castle
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In The Glass Castle, Walls chronicles her upbringing at the hands of eccentric, nomadic parents, Rose Mary, and Rex, her. As Rose Mary and Rex, motivated by whims and paranoia, uprooted their kids time and again, the youngsters (Walls, her brother and two sisters) were left largely to their own devices. But while Rex and Rose Mary firmly believed children learned best from their own mistakes, they themselves never seemed to do so, repeating the same disastrous patterns that eventually landed them on the streets. Walls describes in fascinating detail what it was to be a child in this family, from the embarrassing to the horrific. Though Walls has well earned the right to complain, at no point does she play the victim. In fact, Walls' removed, nonjudgmental stance is initially startling, since many of the circumstances she describes could be categorized as abusive (and unquestioningly neglectful). But on the contrary, Walls respects her parents' knack for making hardships feel like adventures, and her love for them--despite their overwhelming self-absorption--resonates from cover to cover.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
In gossip columnist Jeannette Walls' memoir, she details her unconventional childhood growing up with an alcoholic father and a frustrated artist mother, who uprooted the family time after time to ever deeper hardship. Despite her tragic childhood, Walls never plays the victim and recognizes that her parents – however misguided – gave her a life of independence and adventure. Completely engrossing.

- Summer

item.title: You Better Not Cry: Stories for Christmas
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: You've eaten too much candy at Christmas...but have you ever eaten the face off a six-foot stuffed Santa? You've seen gingerbread houses...but have you ever made your own gingerbread tenement? You've woken up with a hangover...but have you ever woken up next to Kris Kringle himself? Augusten Burroughs has, and in this caustically funny, nostalgic, poignant, and moving collection he recounts Christmases past and present--as only he could. With gimlet-eyed wit and illuminated prose, Augusten shows how the holidays bring out the worst in us and sometimes, just sometimes, the very, very best.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
If you scratch the surface of all the dysfunction, you'll find the warmth in this collection of Christmas stories. Darkly funny and often quite moving, Burroughs' stories are reminders that the holidays aren't always all sweetness and light.

- Summer

item.title: Rosetta Stone Spanish (Spain)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Communicate and connect with the world. Build a foundation of fundamental vocabulary and essential language structure. Develop the Spanish (Spain) language skills to enjoy social interactions such as travel and shopping and learn to share your ideas and opinions in Spanish (Spain).

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Rosetta Stone is the best way to learn any language. Instead of the usual way of rote memorization of words and phrases, this program actually immerses you in an environment where the language comes naturally.

- Summer

item.title: Futurama Mini Figures
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Kidrobot has teamed with series creators Matt Groening and David X. Cohen to bring the fan-favorite characters of the beloved cult animated series to vinyl in a series of 3" tall figures. Collectors will find all of their favorites - Philip J. Fry, Dr. Zoidberg, Bender, Leela, Dr. Farnsworth, Zapp Brannigan, and six others, including 2 chase figures - in these blind mystery boxes hand-delivered by Planet Express.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The supremely weird characters of the hit animated show Futurama are even cuter in miniature form. Each of the twelve iconic characters comes in a colorful box and the fun part is you don’t know which one you’ll get until you open it.

- Summer

item.title: Super Mini Kid Robot Keychains
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Doctor? Astronaut? Fireman? Punk rocker? Get ready for 17 blind boxed, quasi-professionals and 2 loafing chases, one of which is an insanely rare Huck Gee. Attach these 1.5-inchers to your keys, but be warned, these workaholics have a tendency to become an occupational hazard...

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
These insanely cool 1.5 inch keychains feature Kidrobot's signature style all grown up – sort of. The collection includes characters such as an astronaut, pirate, doctor and punk rocker and are super collectible.

- Summer

item.title: Animals Around the World Journal
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This flexi-journal features the delightful, irresistible and playful animal artwork of mutli-talented Japanese artist Junzo Terada.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The playful, whimsical illustrations of Japanese artist Junzo Terada enliven the pages of this beautiful journal. Bound with thread, the pages lie flat and are blank, lined or have a grid for ease of use. It makes a wonderful baby journal. I’ve given this journal as gifts to new mothers many times.

- Summer

item.title: Simpsons Mini-Figure
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Kidrobot has teamed with Simpsons creator Matt Groening to bring your favorite Springfield citizens to vinyl in their biggest mini-figure series yet. From Homer to Bart to Sideshow Bob, 24 iconic animated characters, including 3 chase figures, can be yours! Each figure stands 3" tall.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The Simpsons has been on the air for 20 years and its cast of wacky characters have become pop culture icons. From Maggie and Homer to Moe, Duffman and Mr. Burns, these 3-inch vinyl figures are all adorable and collectable – but I think Marge is my favorite. The figures are blind boxed, so part of the fun is not knowing which one you'll get until you open the box.

- Summer

item.title: Santika Stationery Sets
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Santika Stickable Note Portfolio gives you a stylish way to jot down an important reminder to yourself or leave a quick note for others. Seven varying sizes of stickable notes ensure you get the message conveyed with flair. Perfect for both home or office
The Santika Stationery Gift Set makes the perfect gift for a friend or colleague or a nice treat for yourself. Each set contains a generous assortment of stationery necessities. Beautiful tri-fold notecards are a thoughtful way to keep in touch with loved ones while mini notecards can be used for a quick note or as a gift tag. Two sizes of envelope seals are included to coordinate with each of the cards. Stickable notes keep reminders nearby.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The intricate, vibrant pattern on these gift sets make me feel creatively inspired. And who wouldn't want to receive a note on one of these gorgeous cards? The stationery set includes a keepsake box with 16 patterned note cards and coordinating envelopes, 16 cute mini note cards with matching envelopes, 50 decorative envelope seals and 100 sheets of small stickable notes. The stickable note portfolio includes seven sizes of stickable notes in a variety of patterns that make jotting down quick notes more stylish than the usual sticky notes.

- Summer

item.title: Moleskine Passions Wellness Journal
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The Wellness Journal from Moleskine features 6 themed sections to be filled in, 6 blank sections to be personalized, food facts, conversions and measurements, blank pages and 202 adhesive labels for further personalize the notebook. It also features acid-free paper and an expandable double inner pocket.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
With this very portable journal, a healthy lifestyle can be fun, too. I love the food calendar that shows what's in season each month, and the food info section includes helpful details on things like calories and fat in common foods (plus space to fill in your favorites). With sections for personal goals, diet and exercise, this journal takes out all the guesswork of getting and staying fit, even when you’re on the go.

– Summer

item.title: Christian Lacroix Sketchbook
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Compact, lay-flat notebook. A Christian Lacroix couture sketch graces the front- and back-covers of this purse-sized notebook. Illustrated end papers and title page. Black-and-white striped grosgrain ribbon to mark the page. Lined pages, 3.5x5".

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
French couturier Christian Lacroix brings high-fashion to this chic notebook. The front and back covers are adorned with a masterful Lacroix sketch and the spine features another Lacroix pattern for an extra-luxe touch. I believe that anything I write in this journal is more creative than what I write elsewhere – of course, that could just be because I love showing off this gorgeous notebook.

- Summer

item.title: Love & Toast Hand Crémes
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Happy hydration. Natural super-softeners Shea Butter, Macadamia Nut & Olive Fruits team up with pore pleasing Avocado & Sunflower Oils. Add to the mix a botanical perfume blend and now you've got your perfect dream cream: a lightweight & luxurious lotion.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
I love everything about these amazing hand creams – the colorful packaging, the light but luxurious moisturizing and the to-die-for scents: Mandarin Tea, Sugar Grapefruit and Pomme Poivre. The scents are light and sophisticated, and the hand creams are made with all-natural ingredients. Trust me, once you try these you will become obsessed.

- Summer

item.title: LePen
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The Le Pen delivers smooth writing with micro-fine plastic point and a sleek barrel design. Ink is acid-free, smudgeproof and nontoxic.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
One of the things I love about Le Pen is how smoothly it writes – it feels like an expensive pen, but it's not. But the best part about Le Pen is the variety of colors. Sure, there's standard black or even red, but why not write in Periwinkle, Oriental Blue or Burgundy? At this price, why not buy them in all of your favorite colors?

- Summer

item.title: Moleskine Passions Film Journal
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The Film Journal from Moleskine features alphabetized tabs to list and annotate all favorite films, 6 tabbed sections to be personalized, an international film festivals list, blank pages and 202 adhesive labels to further personalize the notebook. It also features acid-free paper throughout and a double expandable inner pocket.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: For movie buffs, this journal is a dream come true! Jot down favorite movie quotes, observations and memories. Sections include a list of movie festivals around the world, alphabetized sections for writing down reviews and an index page so you can easily find your films. Carry this journal along to your next film festival – even if it's in your own living room – and capture all the details you want about the movies you love.

item.title: Moleskine Passions Music Journal
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Whether you're a music buff or a performer, this book makes it easy to capture and organize your inspiration. Log your favorite artists, genres, albums, songs, lyrics, playlists, set lists, concerts, and more. Keep your love of music at your fingertips. Each themed Music Review/Log Section allows you to capture Artists, Genre, Albums, Songs, Lyrics, Playlists, Concerts and more.
Use the Lyrics themed section to capture song, genre, album/year/artist, lyrics/favorite lines, impressions and notes. Use the Playlists themed section to capture titles, notes, track, artist, and time. Use the Concerts themed section to capture concerts, artist(s), when, where, with, review/key moments and notes. Use the My Life in Music themed section to capture song/artist/music, mood/emotions/memories sections to capture your experience. Use the Music Map themed section to write, draw or store your songs, people, moments, places, discoveries, experiences and tickets.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Whether you're a musician or just an avid music fan, this journal will inspire you. Take notes on your favorite artists, genres, albums, songs, lyrics, playlists and concerts in the tabbed review sections. Handy pockets at the back of the journal can hold ticket stubs or programs, which I love. For musicians, the journal even includes music paper for jotting down a song.

- Summer

item.title: Eat, Pray, Love
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This beautifully written, heartfelt memoir touched a nerve among both readers and reviewers. Elizabeth Gilbert tells how she made the difficult choice to leave behind all the trappings of modern American success (marriage, house in the country, career) and find, instead, what she truly wanted from life. Setting out for a year to study three different aspects of her nature amid three different cultures, Gilbert explored the art of pleasure in Italy and the art of devotion in India, and then a balance between the two on the Indonesian island of Bali. By turns rapturous and rueful, this wise and funny author (whom Booklist calls “Anne Lamott’s hip, yoga- practicing, footloose younger sister”) is poised to garner yet more adoring fans.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
With honest, candid prose, Gilbert takes us on a journey from depression and despair to a full, balanced life. To find peace again after a painful divorce, Gilbert embarks on a journey of self-discovery. First, she heads to Italy for a culinary expedition (eat), then to a spiritual retreat at a temple in India (pray), and finally to Indonesia for a search for balance with the help of an elderly medicine man (love).

- Summer

item.title: Holidays on Ice
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: David Sedaris's beloved holiday collection is new again with six more pieces, including a never before published story. Along with such favorites as the diaries of a Macy's elf and the annals of two very competitive families, are Sedaris's tales of tardy trick-or-treaters (Us and Them); the difficulties of explaining the Easter Bunny to the French (Jesus Shaves); what to do when you've been locked out in a snowstorm (Let It Snow); the puzzling Christmas traditions of other nations (Six to Eight Black Men); what Halloween at the medical examiner's looks like (The Monster Mash); and a barnyard secret Santa scheme gone awry (Cow and Turkey). No matter what your favorite holiday, you won't want to miss celebrating it with the author who has been called "one of the funniest writers alive" (Economist)."

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Holidays on Ice is a collection of six darkly funny short stories all wrapped up in a black bow. Sedaris is a master of the absurd little details that turn an ordinary story into something extraordinarily funny. My favorite is SantaLand Diaries, which recounts the author's experiences working as an elf at Macy's during Christmas – it makes me laugh until I cry. David Sedaris is in fine form in this collection, so don't wait until the holidays to own it.

- Summer

I got this for my nieces a few years ago and it is still a huge hit. They delight in waking up each morning to discover where the little elf may be hiding, knowing that each night the elf reports back to Santa whether they’ve been naughty or nice.

- Summer

item.title: Alice I Have Been
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Few works of literature are as universally beloved as Alice's Adventures in Wonderland. Now, in this spellbinding historical novel, we meet the young girl whose bright spirit sent her on an unforgettable trip down the rabbit hole-and the grown woman whose story is no less enthralling.
A love story and a literary mystery, Alice I Have Been brilliantly blends fact and fiction to capture the passionate spirit of a woman who was truly worthy of her fictional alter ego, in a world as captivating as the Wonderland only she could inspire.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This is the fictionalized account of Alice Pleasance Liddell Hargreaves, the real girl who inspired Alice's Adventures in Wonderland. As a child, Alice urged family friend Charles Dodgson (who wrote under the pseudonym Lewis Carroll) to write down a whimsical story he had told to her and her sisters. Little did she know how Wonderland would come to affect her life – for better and for worse. Benjamin's skillful account provides a rich and engaging perspective on a famous literary duo. You'll never look at Alice's Adventures in Wonderland in quite the same way again.

- Summer

item.title: Celebration Dolls
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Momiji (or Celebration Dolls) are hand painted resin message dolls. Turn them upside down...inside every one there's a tiny folded card for your own secret message. Momiji is inspired by friendship and little kindnesses. It's about filling life with memories and messages.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Momiji dolls are these adorable little Japanese friendship dolls, each with her own unique personality. And they're not just for kids – I've given these cuties to everyone from nieces to colleagues and everyone loves them. The doll base holds a tiny note for your recipient. The newest addition to the Momiji line are these dolls created by French illustrator and textile designer Adolie Day. Blanche, Pious Chou and Douce have the signature Japanese quirky style with a French twist.

- Summer

item.title: Mini Munny
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The world's greatest do-it-yourself toy just shrunk! Kidrobot labs has squeezed MUNNY's endless world of possibilities into a miniature, 4-inch frame. Paint, draw, or scribble; pierce, pose or clothe.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
These little four-inch high figures are hot, hot, hot. Like the original Munny, the miniature Munny can be designed and transformed into whatever you want it to be. Includes a marker, a mystery accessory and a sticker.

- Summer

item.title: Yummy Breakfast Keychains
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: From the crafty mind of Heidi Kenney (My Paper Crane) comes yet another delightfully delicious keychain series. Heidi expands beyond the donut food group and dishes up an assortment of tasty treats for your keychain. Whether waffles float your boat or you're more of a pizza person, this series hosts a buffet of morning time munchies.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
From smiley toast to a crying hard boiled egg, each tasty treat is a tiny collectible from artist Heidi Kenney. You never know which keychain you'll get in the box, but they're all cute and friendly.

- Summer

item.title: Hot and Hot Fish Club Cookbook
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The Hot and Hot Fish Club Cookbook contains more than 200 creative and delicious recipes that are organized to reflect the seasonal nature of local ingredients. It features profiles of dozens purveyors who supply the restaurant with the freshest ingredients. With more than 50 full-color photographs, lifestyle menus complete with wine and beer pairings, and a sourcing section, The Hot and Hot Fish Club Cookbook is your guide to preparing exquisite, fresh cuisine from the hottest restaurant in the South.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Birmingham, Alabama's Hot and Hot Fish Club Restaurant is one of the best restaurants in the South, and one of my all-time favorites. Chef Chris Hastings creates mouthwatering masterpieces using only the finest and freshest ingredients the restaurant can find. With more than 200 recipes, gorgeous color photographs and a handy sourcing section to getting the best ingredients, The Hot and Hot Fish Club Cookbook is a treat for home cooks.

- Summer
Chris Hastings and Idie Hastings and Katherine Cobbs

item.title: Polaroid Notes
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Polaroid film may have been discontinued, but its dreamy evocative spirit lives on in this covetable keepsake box of notecards. Jenifer Altman, compiler of these notecards, is a commercial and fine art photographer specializing in food, lifestyle, and still-life. Her photography is held in public and private collections across the globe, and her work has been published in several collaborative art books.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
As much as I love my digital camera, I always thought there was something magical about Polaroid images. This set of 20 notecards with envelopes perfectly captures that retro, dreamy feeling. The images are so lovely and intimate, you may want to keep as many as you send.

- Summer

item.title: Smorkin’ Labbits 1.5″
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
These labbits are multiplying like, well..., labbits.
Tongue firmly planted in cheek, these stumpy 1.5-inch minis pose as patriots, hoity Brits, jazzersicsts, robots, jailbirds, and more, with strict orders to infiltrate society and spread their nicotine-fueled brand of irony to the masses.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
These wonderfully naughty bunnies come straight from the delightfully demented imagination of legendary toy designer Frank Kozik. The 1.5-inch minis are a worldwide obsession with collectors, and each is blind boxed to further the mystery, which I love. You'll love these tiny troublemakers and their variety of poses, costumes and attitudes.

- Summer

item.title: Moleskine Passions Recipe Journal
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Do you have a passion for cooking and a flair for entertaining? If you answered yes, then this book is a necessity. Archive everything from favorite family recipes to your own inventive culinary discoveries. Document, organize, and plan all upcoming occasions or reflect upon your past successes. This fun and useful tool helps you capture every need: appetizers, first course, main dishes, side dishes, wine pairings, desserts and cocktails along with prep time ingredients and difficulty. It even includes a calendar for ingredients that are in season. And for the health conscious, it includes quick reference for calories, protein, fat, and carbs. Don't let your culinary brilliance go to waste, keep all your tricks at your fingers tips. Let's get cookin!
Size: 5 X 8.25 inches Pages: 240 (120 leaves) Cover Style: Hardcover

item.title: Moleskine Passions Book Journal
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
<!-- Anno goes here -->A book lover's delight, this journal is a place to keep track of all your tomes. Reflect on what you're currently reading, reminisce about past favorites, and capture your list of future ones so they don't fall through the cracks. The Book Journal inspires you to gather information about the book such as the title, date read, author, quotes, the book's original language and awards that it may have received. Plus, there's a space for your opinion and rating. Have fun organizing your book reviews with 202 adhesive labels to personalize your journal inside and out. It's easy and gratifying to log the books you've read, whether for reference, personal kudos, or recommendations to friends - a must-have for the avid reader.
Pages: 240 pages (120 leaves) Size: 5 by 8.25 inches (13 x 21 cm) Cover Style: Hard Cover

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
I read a lot of books. A lot of books. So when I first spied this handy journal for book-lovers, I snapped up several at once. With a section for planning book events like bookclub meetings, 155 pages for recording information on books I've read and 6 tabbed sections I can customize, this journal is like having my own mini-library. The compact size also means I can drop it in my bag and have it wherever I go.

- Summer

item.title: Christian Lacroix Notecards
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Boxed Note Cards – Beautiful die-cut note cards, designed by Christian Lacroix. Each lace-cut card has a different fashion illustration and a coordinated pastel-colored interior. Eight cards and matching envelopes, 2/each of 4 designs. A set of embossed 18th century-style sealing wax stickers close the envelopes. Gift Box, with gold Christian Lacroix logo sticker.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The fashion sketches of French designer Christian Lacroix's haute creations elevate these notecards from functional to fabulous. Even the envelopes are gorgeous – laser-cut and in coordinating interior colors. Impress your friends with a note on these or just keep them for yourself!

- Summer

item.title: Christian Lacroix Notebooks in Fuchsia and Absinthe
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In two colors – Fuchsia and Absynthe. A beautiful embossed sketchbook, covered in fabric – great for note-taking or quick sketches. Durable hardbound construction. Black-and-white striped grosgrain ribbon to mark the page. All about the color– end papers, portrait printed on paper and acetate overlay, plus a French/English poem by Christian Lacroix about the charms of the color. Unlined pages.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Legendary fashion designer Christian Lacroix is known for his use of brilliant color, and these journals are no exception. These gorgeous hard-cover journals will inspire your creative muse, and you'll feel glamorous just taking one from your bag. Each notebook includes a French/English poem about the notebook's color, a lovely ode that I enjoy re-reading every time I use the journal.

- Summer

item.title: Moleskine Passions Wine Journal
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The Wine Journal from Moleskine features 6 themed sections to be filled in, 6 tabbed section to be personalized, a wine glossary, measures and conversions, blank pages and 202 adhesive labels to further personalize the notebook. Also featured is acid-free paper and a double expandable inner pocket.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
I often go to wine tastings or dinner parties where I'll try a wonderful new wine, only to promptly forget its name the next time I'm at the store picking up a bottle. With this elegant little journal, wine lovers can keep the information on their favorite vintages right at their fingertips. Includes 6 themed sections you can fill in with information, plus 6 more sections you can personalize. The wine glossary is also helpful when you're searching for something new to try.

- Summer

item.title: My Listography
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This quirky journal will inspire young list-makers to create an entire autobiography in list form Covering everything from favorite books and movies to secret wishes and dreams for the future, each list also comes with a comical illustration-perfect for hours of list-making fun.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This creative journal provides hours of fun for kids as they create their life in lists. I've given this journal to my young relatives who sat for many contented hours filling out the lists and sharing their favorites. With lists like “list all the great things about yourself,” the journal is also a great self-esteem builder.

- Summer

item.title: Buckyballs™
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Tired of desk toys that only do one thing? Puzzled by puzzles that are hard to figure out? Frustrated by magnets that refuse to pull their own weight? Brace yourself, a whole new breed of adult toy is on the way. Featured in Rolling Stone, People Maxim, Esquire Magazine...the world can't stop talking about Buckyballs.
Each set contains 216 powerful Rare Earth magnets that can be shaped, molded, torn apart and snapped together in unlimited ways. Make sculptures, puzzles, patterns, shapes, stick stuff to the fridge, invent a new game—trying to find something more useful is useless.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
A great gift for a friend, co-worker or yourself. Buckyballs bring out your creativity and keeps you wondering what will be your next cool design. It’s the perfect desk accessory.

- Summer

Two heads are definitely better than one – now I don't have to move the light around on the page. It's a simple but ingenious booklight that will absolutely thrill all the readers in your life.

- Summer

This creative game makes poetry a fun group activity. Roll the dice and craft your poetic masterpiece from the words that come up.

- Summer

Not just for gifts, these labels and stickers featuring the designs of Lotta Jansdotter can beautifully embellish just about anything. I like to use the labels for embellishing my envelopes, and to give handwritten cards a bit more oomph.

- Summer

This modern, Swiss-made pen hides a super-sized ink cartridge for years of smooth writing. And yes, it is guaranteed to last seven years.

- Summer

I like to add a personal touch to gifts with these gold trimmed stickers. It makes each package look a little more special.

- Summer

Some people show up to parties with wine or pie, I bring Jenga. It’s my absolute most favorite game and it’s always a hit.

- Summer

item.title: Imperfect Birds
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A powerful and redemptive novel of love and family, from the author of the bestselling "Blue Shoe, Grace (Eventually)," and "Operating Instructions." Rosie Ferguson is seventeen and ready to enjoy the summer before her senior year of high school. She's intelligent-she aced AP physics; athletic-a former state-ranked tennis doubles champion; and beautiful. She is, in short, everything her mother, Elizabeth, hoped she could be. The family's move to Landsdale, with stepfather James in tow, hadn't been as bumpy as Elizabeth feared. But as the school year draws to a close, there are disturbing signs that the life Rosie claims to be leading is a sham, and that Elizabeth's hopes for her daughter to remain immune from the pull of the darker impulses of drugs and alcohol are dashed. Slowly and against their will, Elizabeth and James are forced to confront the fact that Rosie has been lying to them-and that her deceptions will have profound consequences.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Powerful and honest, Lamott's latest novel explores themes of love, family, the yearning for connection with one another – and the all-too-human ways we stumble in the process. I was riveted by the story of seemingly perfect Rosie, her mother Elizabeth, and her stepfather James. When Rosie's true life comes to light, Elizabeth must make some ultimately painful choices that will affect all their lives. Another stellar work from one of the best writers of our time.

- Summer

item.title: Let the Great World Spin
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In the dawning light of a late-summer morning, the people of lower Manhattan stand hushed, staring up in disbelief at the Twin Towers. It is August 1974, and a mysterious tightrope walker is running, dancing, leaping between the towers, suspended a quarter mile above the ground. In the streets below, a slew of ordinary lives become extraordinary in bestselling novelist Colum McCann's stunningly intricate portrait of a city and its people.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
In 1974, tightrope walker Philippe Petit walked – and ran, and skipped along – a wire between the World Trade Center towers, to the amazement of scores of New Yorkers below. McCann's book focuses on those people on the ground, the ones who looked up that fateful morning and whose lives were forever changed. McCann weaves a thread among various characters – two Irish brothers, prostitutes in the Bronx, a group of women who have lost their sons to Vietnam – that winds its way all the way through September 11, 2001 and beyond. A beautifully understated and unique novel that attempts to make sense of tragedy, ending on a note of hope.

- Summer

item.title: Fireworks Over Toccoa
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: An unexpected discovery takes eighty-four-year-old Lily Davis Woodward to 1945, and the five days that forever changed her life. Married for only a week before her husband was sent to fight in WWII, Lily is anxious for his return, and the chance to begin their life together. In honor of the soldiers' homecoming, the small Georgia town of Toccoa plans a big celebration. And Jake Russo, a handsome Italian immigrant, also back from war, is responsible for the elaborate fireworks display the town commissioned. But after a chance encounter in a star-lit field, he steals Lily's heart and soul--and fulfills her in ways her socially-minded, upper-class family cannot. Now, torn by duty to society and her husband--and the poor, passionate man who might be her only true love--Lily must choose between a commitment she's already made and a love she's never known before.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Chancing upon a museum artifact connected to her life, elderly Lily Davis Woodward tells the story of herself as a young bride in Toccoa, Georgia, during World War II. Lily is awaiting the return of her husband Paul who was shipped off to war two weeks after their marriage. Lily wonders how Paul has changed, as she has changed and matured while they've been apart. Then, while waiting for Paul to come home, fireworks bring Jake into her life and Lily must choose between duty and true love. In his lyrical debut novel, Stepakoff has woven a story both joyous and heartbreaking, with characters that became like family to me. This is one of those rare books you just don't want to end, and when you reach the last page you must say goodbye to people you've grown to love.

- Summer

item.title: The Comfort Table
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Food has a nostalgic power. Just like hearing a favorite song, cooking and eating can transport us to a moment in time: Sunday family suppers or brunch with friends, a Fourth of July barbecue or a Chrismukkah feast.
