Katie Lee grew up in a small West Virginia town where her grandmother's kitchen was not far away, and her warmest memories are of being around the table with loved ones. In "The Comfort Table: Recipes for Everyday Occasions," she brings her roots in southern hospitality to the table with year-round menus for occasions big and small.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This beautiful cookbook of easy, creative recipes, party ideas and menu suggestions for every occasion is my go-to entertaining guide. You'll be inspired by the delicious recipes and suggestions for music, hostess gifts, wine pairings and other tips are just the icing on the cake. With Katie's stress-free ideas, you'll want to make every single day a special occasion to celebrate with friends.

- Summer

item.title: Men and Dogs
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: When Hannah Legare was 11, her father went on a fishing trip in the Charleston harbor and never came back. And while most of the town and her family accepted Buzz's disappearance, Hannah remained steadfastly convinced of his imminent return. Twenty years later Hannah's new life in San Francisco is unraveling. Her marriage is on the rocks, her business is bankrupt. After a disastrous attempt to win back her husband, she ends up back at her mother's home to "rest up," where she is once again sucked into the mystery of her missing father. Suspecting that those closest are keeping secrets–including Palmer, her emotionally closed, well-mannered brother and Warren, the beautiful boyfriend she left behind–Hannah sets out on an uproarious, dangerous quest that will test the whole family's concepts of loyalty and faith.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
When Hannah Legare was 11, her father went fishing and never came back. Now Hannah is in her 30s and her life in San Francisco is unraveling. She returns home to Charleston to recover, where family secrets and the mystery of her missing father make her take a closer look at her past. Darkly funny, sassy and heartfelt, this lively read gripped my attention from the first page. Hannah is a flawed but sympathetic heroine you'll want to cheer on.

- Summer

item.title: The Girl Who Fell from the Sky
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This debut novel tells the story of Rachel, the daughter of a Danish mother and a black G.I. who becomes the sole survivor of a family tragedy. With her strict African-American grandmother as her new guardian, Rachel moves to a mostly black community, where her light brown skin, blue eyes, and beauty bring mixed attention her way. Growing up in the 1980s, she learns to swallow her overwhelming grief and confronts her identity as a biracial young woman in a world that wants to see her as either black or white. In the tradition of Jamaica Kincaid's “Annie John” and Toni Morrison's “The Bluest Eye,” here is a portrait of a young girl—and society's ideas of race, class, and beauty. It is the winner of the Bellwether Prize for best fiction manuscript addressing issues of social justice.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Rachel is the lone survivor of a horrific family tragedy, but that is not the only struggle she faces in this gorgeous debut novel. Rachel is biracial — half Danish, half African-American — and is sent to live with her African-American grandmother in Portland. As Rachel grows up, she must work through the complexities of racial identity while she searches for answers to what happened on that fateful day her whole life changed. With themes of race, gender, identity and loss, this book packs an emotional punch. Don't miss it!

- Summer

item.title: Girl in Translation
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: When Kimberly Chang and her mother emigrate from Hong Kong to Brooklyn squalor, she quickly begins a secret double life: exceptional schoolgirl during the day, Chinatown sweatshop worker in the evenings. Disguising the more difficult truths of her life—like the staggering degree of her poverty, the weight of her family's future resting on her shoulders, or her secret love for a factory boy who shares none of her talent or ambition—Kimberly learns to constantly translate not just her language but herself back and forth between the worlds she straddles.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
I was amazed by this debut novel that combines the classic coming-of-age story with an immigrant's tale. Kimberly Chang and her mother are Chinese immigrants who migrate to Brooklyn, only to live in a rundown apartment and work long hours at her aunt's sweatshop. At first Kimberly struggles to learn English, but soon her scholastic abilities have her at the head of the class — and she realizes the only way out of poverty for her and her mother is through education. I loved the strong bond between mother and daughter and I was so inspired by Kimberly's journey to the American dream.

- Summer

item.title: Bourbon
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Straight up, mixed in a cocktail, poured into a punch, or whipped into a recipe, bourbon is an old favorite that's new again. Thompson lays out the history, legends, recipes, and helpful tips and tricks—all accompanied by full-color photos.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Bourbon can intimidate those who aren't connoisseurs of this American distilled spirit. This book will change all that. Filled with history, tips and beautiful photos, the book is a treat. Recipes are broken down into classics, updated “newfangled” drinks, coffee and iced drinks, bourbon for a crowd and cooking with bourbon. I'm partial to the chapter on “The Classics,” including Manhattans and Old Fashioneds, but I'm intrigued by the modern recipes. Mint Julep Sorbet? Yes, please!

- Summer

item.title: Awkward Family Photos
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Based on the hit website, AwkwardFamilyPhotos.com, this full color book features never-before-seen photos and hilarious personal stories covering everything from uncomfortable moments with relatives, teen angst, sibling rivalry, and family vacations from hell. Cringe at the forced poses, bad hair, and matching outfits—all prompting us to look at our own families and celebrate the fact that we're not alone. Nothing says awkward better than an uncomfortable family photograph

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
My sister and I used to talk about creating a book from all the hilarious Christmas cards we've received over the years, only to find out there was something better — Awkward Family Photos! In the book based on the internet phenomenon, we get even more of these hilarious family mementos plus deliriously funny commentary and short stories from some of the subjects. You will die laughing at these unbelievable shots sent in from people all over the world!

- Summer

item.title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet’s Nest
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The stunning third and final novel in Stieg Larsson's internationally best-selling trilogy Lisbeth Salander–the heart of Larsson's two previous novels–lies in critical condition, a bullet wound to her head, in the intensive care unit of a Swedish city hospital. She's fighting for her life in more ways than one: if and when she recovers, she'll be taken back to Stockholm to stand trial for three murders. With the help of her friend, journalist Mikael Blomkvist, she will not only have to prove her innocence, but also identify and denounce those in authority who have allowed the vulnerable, like herself, to suffer abuse and violence. And, on her own, she will plot revenge–against the man who tried to kill her, and the corrupt government institutions that very nearly destroyed her life. Once upon a time, she was a victim. Now Salander is fighting back.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
I couldn't wait to get my hands on the final book in Larsson's Millennium trilogy -- and The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest did not disappoint. Once again our girl of action, Lisbeth Salander, is entangled in a complicated situation of family dramas, conspiracy theories and non-stop intrigue. I couldn't sleep until I reached the ultimate, incredibly satisfying ending.

- Summer

item.title: Anthropology of an American Girl
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Self-published in 2003, Hilary Thayer Hamann's Anthropology of an American Girl touched a nerve among readers, who identified with the sexual and intellectual awakening of its heroine, a young woman on the brink of adulthood. A moving depiction of the transformative power of first love, Hamann's first novel follows Eveline Auerbach from her high school years in East Hampton, New York, in the 1970s through her early adulthood in the moneyed, high-pressured Manhattan of the 1980s.
Centering on Evie's fragile relationship with her family and her thwarted love affair with Harrison Rourke, a professional boxer, the novel is both a love story and an exploration of the difficulty of finding one's place in the world. As Evie surrenders to the dazzling emotional highs of love and the crippling loneliness of heartbreak, she strives to reconcile her identity with the constraints that all relationships–whether those familial or romantic, uplifting to the spirit or quietly detrimental–inherently place on us. Though she stumbles and strains against social conventions, Evie remains a strong yet sensitive observer of the world around her, often finding beauty and meaning in unexpected places.
Newly edited and revised since its original publication, Anthropology of an American Girl is an extraordinary piece of writing, original in its vision and thrilling in its execution.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
One of my favorite books is this poetic, philosophical coming-of-age story. The first half of the story covers Eveline Auerbach’s last years of high school while the second half follows her rather unconventional college years and growing up in New York. Evie is raw, sensitive and wryly observant about her life – she is an authentic "American girl" you can't help but love. A poignant, profound and beautifully written book about being an independent woman in our shallow society.

- Summer

item.title: One Day
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
It's 1988 and Dexter Mayhew and Emma Morley have only just met. They both know that the next day, after college graduation, they must go their separate ways. But after only one day together, they cannot stop thinking about one another. As the years go by, Dex and Em begin to lead separate lives–lives very different from the people they once dreamed they'd become. And yet, unable to let go of that special something that grabbed onto them that first night, an extraordinary relationship develops between the two.
Over twenty years, snapshots of that relationship are revealed on the same day–July 15th–of each year. Dex and Em face squabbles and fights, hopes and missed opportunities, laughter and tears. And as the true meaning of this one crucial day is revealed, they must come to grips with the nature of love and life itself.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Emma and Dexter meet on July 15, 1988, on the last day of school at the University of Edinburgh. They feel an immediate attraction, although they don't act on it. The story follows Emma and Dexter on every July 15 for the next 20 years, dropping in on the highs and lows of their lives. It's a funny, heartbreaking, astonishingly realistic love story with two main characters who became quite dear to me. After finishing the book, I immediately wanted to read it again so I could immerse myself in their lives -- I missed reading about Dexter and Emma!

- Summer

item.title: The Selby Is in Your Place
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: "The Selby Is in Your Place" was conceived when fashion and interiors photographer Todd Selby began taking portraits of dynamic and creative people--authors, musicians, artists, and designers--in their home environments and posting them on his web site. Nosy by nature, he wanted to see how personal style was reflected in private spaces. Lucky for us, he found his answer in the color-rich and eclectic quarters of a diverse group of subjects, including Simon Doonan and Jonathan Adler, Faris Rotter, Andre Walker, and Olivier Zahm, in New York, Los Angeles, Paris, Tokyo, Sydney, and London. Each profile is accompanied by Selby's watercolor portraits of the subjects and objects from their homes, and illustrated questionnaires, which Selby asks each sitter to fill out. This book consists of over thirty profiles, many of which have never-before-seen, selected exclusively for the book. The result is a collection of unique spaces bursting with energy and personality that together create a colorful hodgepodge of inspirational interiors.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Photographer and illustrator Todd Selby took fresh portraits of his eclectic friends and assorted famous people in their own homes for his website project, The Selby. "The Selby Is in Your Place" is a curated selection of some of Selby's portraits of influential creative types all over the world. The interiors are spectacular, but I really felt I was seeing a moment captured in time, a portrait of a person surrounded by the things they treasured. I loved getting a peek into the lives of so many diverse, dynamic people.

- Summer

item.title: The Quickening Maze
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A visionary novel by "one of the most talented writers of his generation" ("The Times Literary Supplement")-shortlisted for the Man Booker Prize Based on real events, "The Quickening Maze" won over UK critics and readers alike with its rapturous prose and vivid exploration of poetry and madness. Historically accurate yet brilliantly imagined, this is the debut publication of this elegant and riveting novel in the United States.
In 1837, after years of struggling with alcoholism and depression, the great nature poet John Clare finds himself in High Beach- a mental institution located in Epping Forest on the outskirts of London. It is not long before another famed writer, the young Alfred Tennyson, moves nearby and grows entwined in the catastrophic schemes of the hospital's owner, the peculiar Dr. Matthew Allen, his lonely adolescent daughter, and a coterie of mysterious local characters. With lyrical grace, the cloistered world of High Beach and its residents are brought richly to life in this enchanting book.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This beautifully written novel is based on real events that took place in Britain's Epping Forest in the 19th century. The main character is John Clare, a great pastoral poet of the time who wrote some of his finest poetry while in an institution. The characters – including Alfred Tennyson – are vividly drawn, and I was engrossed by the novel's poetic imagery – fitting, since the author is also an award-winning poet.

- Summer

item.title: Husband and Wife
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In this new novel by the celebrated author of "The Myth of You and Me," a young mother discovers that her husband's novel about infidelity might be drawn from real life.
Sarah Price is thirty-five years old. She doesn't feel as though she's getting older, but there are some noticeable changes: a hangover after two beers, the stray gray hair, and, most of all, she's called "Mom" by two small children. Always responsible, Sarah traded her MFA for a steady job, which allows her husband, Nathan, to write fiction. But Sarah is happy and she believes Nathan is too, until a truth is revealed: Nathan's upcoming novel, "Infidelity," is based in fact.
Suddenly Sarah's world is turned upside down. Adding to her confusion, Nathan abdicates responsibility for the fate of their relationship and of his novel's publication--a financial lifesaver they have been depending upon--leaving both in Sarah's hands. Reeling from his betrayal, she is plagued by dark questions. How well does she really know Nathan? And, more important, how well does she know herself?
For answers, Sarah looks back to her artistic twenty-something self to try to understand what happened to her dreams. When did it all seem to change? Pushed from her complacent plateau, Sarah begins to act--for the first time not so responsibly--on all the things she has let go of for so long: her blank computer screen; her best friend, Helen; the volumes of Proust on her bookshelf. And then there is that e-mail in her inbox: a note from Rajiv, a beautiful man from her past who once tempted her to stray. The struggle to find which version of herself is the essential one--artist, wife, or mother--takes Sarah hundreds of miles away from her marriage on a surprising journey.
Wise, funny, and sharply drawn, Leah Stewart's "Husband and Wife" probes our deepest relationships, the promises we make and break, and the consequences they hold for our lives, revealing that it's never too late to step back and start over.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
While getting ready for a friend's wedding, Sarah Price learns that her husband's novel "Infidelity" is not entirely fiction – he has been unfaithful to her. The story follows how this devastating revelation affects Sarah as it leads her on a journey of self-discovery. Who was she before she became a devoted wife and mother? I found Sarah's quest to reclaim her personal identity incredibly empathetic and realistic. Stewart's beautiful prose gets to the heart of Sarah and Nathan's marriage with fresh insight.

- Summer

item.title: A Visit from the Goon Squad
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Jennifer Egan's spellbinding interlocking narratives circle the lives of Bennie Salazar, an aging former punk rocker and record executive, and Sasha, the passionate, troubled young woman he employs. Although Bennie and Sasha never discover each others pasts, the reader does, in intimate detail, along with the secret lives of a host of other characters whose paths intersect with theirs, over many years, in locales as varied as New York, San Francisco, Naples, and Africa.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
An audacious novel that reads like a collection of short stories -- really, really amazing short stories. The chapters skip forward and back through time, with characters in the music industry who are all connected to each other in some way. Despite the number of people introduced throughout the novel, each one feels three-dimensional, rich and complex. I felt I really knew each character within just a few pages. I don't want to give away too much about this one, just go read it. It's brilliant.

- Summer

item.title: I’d Know You Anywhere
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: An edgy, utterly gripping tale of psychological manipulation that will leave readers racing to the final page, "I'd Know You Anywhere" is a virtuoso performance from acclaimed, award-winning author Lippman that is sure to be her biggest hit yet.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Eliza Benedict is a stay-at-home mom with a successful husband and two kids. Her seemingly perfect life changes when she receives a letter from a man on death row -- from the man who kidnapped and raped her when she was 15. Lippman goes beyond the standard crime novel with characters who are often ambiguous, with inner conflicts and murky motivations. I found it incredibly difficult to put this novel down for a second – it's chilling, suspenseful and so compelling.

- Summer

item.title: Little Bee
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
We don't want to tell you too much about this book!
It is a truly special story and we don't want to spoil it. Nevertheless, you need to know something, so we will just say this: It is extremely funny, but the African beach scene is horrific. The story starts there, but the book doesn't. And it's what happens afterward that is most important. Once you have read it, you'll want to tell everyone about it. When you do, please don't tell them what happens either. The magic is in how it unfolds.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This novel will make you stop and think about the world and how a single decision can change the course of your life forever. From the beaches of Nigeria to a British Immigration Center and then to UK Suburbia, you will follow “Little Bee” as her life intermingles into that of a British couple. I would hate to spoil this remarkable tale by saying anymore – this is a political story of triumph that is all heart. Not to be missed.

- Summer

item.title: Russian Winter
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: "Tender, passionate, and moving, Daphne Kalotay's debut novel about ballet, jewels, love and betrayal is also a delicious form of time travel. I loved it."–Jenna Blum, New York Times-bestselling author of Those Who Save Us.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
I loved the mix of history and mystery in this gorgeous novel. A story about a former Russian ballerina, beautiful jewels, the auction world – this is the kind of novel you stay up late to read because the story is just so intriguing. A fantastic read from beginning to end.

- Summer

item.title: Sh*t My Dad Says
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: After being dumped by his longtime girlfriend, twenty-eight-year-old Justin Halpern found himself living at home with his seventy-three-year-old dad. Sam Halpern, who is "like Socrates, but angrier, and with worse hair," has never minced words, and when Justin moved back home, he began to record all the ridiculous things his dad said to him.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Just try to read this book without thinking "why didn't I think of that?" The reason is probably because your dad is not as hilarious and cantankerous as Justin Halpern's dad, who became a star on Twitter with Sh*t My Dad Says. Now you can have all of Justin's dad's wit and wisdom, plus some touching stories from Justin that provide context.

- Summer

item.title: The Art of Simple Food
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Hailed as one of Americas most influential chefs, Waters shares the simple yet flavorful dishes that have made Chez Panisse a can't miss stop on America's culinary road map.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The Art of Simple Food by Alice Waters is the bible of cookbooks. Recipes don't need to be complicated to be delicious; it’s all about fresh, local & simple in the opinion of this esteemed kitchen maverick.

- Summer

item.title: Ape House
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Sam, Bonzi, Lola, Mbongo, Jelani, and Makena are no ordinary apes. These bonobos, like others of their species, are capable of reason and carrying on deep relationships--but unlike most bonobos, they also know American Sign Language.
Isabel Duncan, a scientist at the Great Ape Language Lab, doesn't understand people, but animals she gets–especially the bonobos. Isabel feels more comfortable in their world than she's ever felt among humans...until she meets John Thigpen, a very married reporter who braves the ever-present animal rights protesters outside the lab to see what's really going on inside.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
An endearing and magical tale about the Bonobo Apes based on Sara Gruen's (Water for Elephants) personal experiences with these fascinating creatures. You get the chance to look into the souls of these human-like animals  as the story between their trainer, Isabel, and the apes unfolds in their utopian life at the Great Ape Language Lab. A horrible incident endangers Isabel and her beloved Apes, and she, with the help of her journalistic friend John Thigpen, goes on a mission to get them back.

- Summer

item.title: Freedom
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: From the National Book Award-winning author of The Corrections, a darkly comedic novel about family. Patty and Walter Berglund were the new pioneers of old St. Paul–the gentrifiers, the hands-on parents, the avant-garde of the Whole Foods generation. Patty was the ideal sort of neighbor, who could tell you where to recycle your batteries and how to get the local cops to actually do their job. She was an enviably perfect mother and the wife of Walter's dreams. Together with Walter–environmental lawyer, commuter cyclist, total family man–she was doing her small part to build a better world. But now, in the new millennium, the Berglunds have become a mystery. Why has their teenage son moved in with the aggressively Republican family next door? Why has Walter taken a job working with Big Coal? What exactly is Richard Katz--outre rocker and Walter's college best friend and rival--still doing in the picture? Most of all, what has happened to Patty? Why has the bright star of Barrier Street become "a very different kind of neighbor," an implacable Fury coming unhinged before the street's attentive eyes?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This book is the real deal. Freedom is the best book I have read in a decade, and Jonathan Franzen proves to be the greatest writer of these times. A great American novel if I've ever read one. Don't waste another minute, start reading it today!

- Summer

Edgy, glamorous, and sexy–Some of American's greatest fashion designers welcome the world into their homes and reveal how they incorporate the couture of the runways into their living spaces.

- Summer

item.title: Thirty-Six Views of the Eiffel Tower
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Thirty-Six Views of the Eiffel Tower is an eminently giftable tribute to the greatest sight in the City of Light. A gorgeous re-creation of Henri Riviere's original 1902 volume offers a stunning view of turn-of-the-century Paris. Sometimes looming in the foreground, sometimes a tiny detail on the horizon, the tower is always present: piercing the sky above a teeming street scene; populated with daring construction workers far above the earth; and peacefully distant above a tranquil Seine. Published in association with the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, this enchanting collection is sure to be cherished by Francophiles the world over.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Paris, je t’aime. The Eiffel Tower is an ever-present part of the Parisian skyline, and these remarkable photos show it to its best advantage. This gorgeous recreation of the original 1902 book by Henri Rivière makes me crave a visit to Paris every time I open it.

- Summer

item.title: Room
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
To five-year-old Jack, Room is the entire world. It is where he was born and grew up; it's where he lives with his Ma as they learn and read and eat and sleep and play. At night, his Ma shuts him safely in the wardrobe, where he is meant to be asleep when Old Nick visits.
Room is home to Jack, but to Ma, it is the prison where Old Nick has held her captive for seven years. Through determination, ingenuity, and fierce motherly love, Ma has created a life for Jack. But she knows it's not enough...not for her or for him. She devises a bold escape plan, one that relies on her young son's bravery and a lot of luck. What she does not realize is just how unprepared she is for the plan to actually work.
Told entirely in the language of the energetic, pragmatic five-year-old Jack, ROOM is a celebration of resilience and the limitless bond between parent and child, a brilliantly executed novel about what it means to journey from one world to another.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Narration in the voice of a five-year-old doesn’t diminish the fact that a little boy and his mother have been held hostage in a tiny room for years.  Sweet and tender, yet sad and dark, this book will take you through the gamut of emotions, but ultimately you'll discover, its essence is the love story between a mother and her son.

- Summer

item.title: Goodnight Moon
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In a great green room, tucked away in bed, is a little bunny. "Goodnight room, goodnight moon." And to all the familiar things in the softly lit room–to the picture of the three little bears sitting in chairs, to the clocks and his socks, to the mittens and the kittens, to everything one by one–he says goodnight.
In this classic of modern children's literature, beloved by generations of readers and listeners, the quiet poetry of the words and the gentle, lulling illustrations combine to make a perfect book for the end of the day.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
I loved this book as a child when it was read to me and now I’m reading it to my daughter.  It’s a beautiful classic that everyone should have in their library, even if you don’t have kids, because it’s a delightful reminder of how uncomplicated life once was.

- Summer

item.title: Street Sketchbook : Journeys
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Fans of the hit graffiti title Street Sketchbook will delight in this new volume dedicated to the journeys-both geographical and imaginative-of street artists. Twenty-six of the hottest new artists working worldwide today have opened up their sketchbooks to share their impressions as they travel on road trips, trek halfway across the globe, and explore internal landscapes. From widely diverse backgrounds, these cutting-edge artists share one crucial decision: to bypass conventional routes for the creative road less taken, the urban streets and alleyways. From doodles on a bus in Central America to fully realized murals spanning the Israel-Palestine border, Street Sketchbook: Journeys is an engrossing travelogue of visual free expression.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The face of art has changed and is no longer confined to the hallowed halls of galleries and museums.  Manco pulls back the veil on graffiti and removes the derelict stigma attached to this urban art form, showing the creative process from the very simple doodle in a sketchbook to profound murals on city buildings around the world. I enjoyed this book because it opened my eyes to a new world of art.

- Summer

item.title: Allure
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Legendary fashion maven Diana Vreeland at the urging of her editor Jackie O authored a classic volume in the 1980s on the quality of "allure" in fashion and in life. Now back in print, this new edition features a foreword from the incomparable fashion designer Marc Jacobs. Throughout Allure, Vreeland lends her famous knack for turning a phrase to an astonishing array of fashion, celebrity, and fine art photographs. Featuring images of such luminaries as Maria Callas, Gertrude Stein, and Marilyn Monroe shot by superstar photographers such as Man Ray, Cecil Beaton, and Richard Avedon Allure is poised to deliver Vreeland's unparalleled point of view to a whole new generation.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
An essential classic from the best fashion editor who ever lived (Apologies, Anna). Diana Vreeland was a matchless style icon, who made Vogue magazine the fashion bible it is today. The stunning visuals in this must-own book are paired with Vreeland’s signature wisdom – a virtual instruction manual on how to be truly chic.

- Summer

item.title: Humanity
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This stunning treasury of color and black-and-white photographs was sourced from a major international photography competition to find extraordinary and geographically diverse photographs that celebrate humanity's moments of intimacy, laughter, and kinship. Featuring 150 images from around the world, and complemented by heartwarming and inspiring quotes, Humanity is a touching tribute to our most treasured relationships.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
You’ll want this book featured on your coffee table; not to impress your guests or because it looks pretty. Bound within the cover is a stunning collection of photographs depicting life’s simplest moments and they will move you every time you turn its pages. It will remind you to appreciate the most precious gift of life.

- Summer

item.title: Barefoot Contessa How Easy Is That?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The bestselling cookbook author and star of "Barefoot Contessa" on Food Network, is back with her easiest recipes ever, proving that it doesn't take complicated techniques, special equipment, or stops at more than one grocery store to make wonderful dishes for family and friends.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Ina Garten, aka “Barefoot Contessa,” is my favorite celebrity chef for one reason: she never steers me wrong. In her latest, Ina takes the stress out of creating fabulous meals by emphasizing fool-proof techniques and essential kitchen tools.

- Summer

item.title: Guess How Much I Love You
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Guess how much I love you, says Little Nutbrown Hare. Little Nutbrown Hare shows his daddy how much he loves him: as wide as he can reach and as far as he can hop. But Big Nutbrown Hare, who can reach farther and hop higher, loves him back just as much. Well then Little Nutbrown Hare loves him right up to the moon, but that's just halfway to Big Nutbrown Hare's love for him.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
A sweet and sincere bedtime conversation between father and son has become one of the most beloved children's books of all time. With lovely watercolor illustrations and a timeless story of unconditional love, it's no wonder this book has become a treasured keepsake to so many parents and their kids. I love this book to the moon and back!

- Summer

item.title: Heliopolis
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Born in a So Paulo shantytown, Ludo is rescued and raised by a plutocrat and finds himself entrenched in the gated, guarded community of the super-rich. By turns darkly humorous and poignant, Scudamore's Booker Prize-nominated novel is a highly original take on the rags-to-riches story.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Sao Paulo, a city of polluted greatness, where the dividing line between rich and poor is very distinct. Out of this slum comes the tale of a boy who began in one world and was transported to one very different. Heliopolis is the favela where Ludo was born and soon after whisked away with his mother to work on the farm of a wealthy businessman and his philanthropic wife. We meet Ludo in his mid-twenties struggling with the label of 'slum kid made good' at his posh advertising job and the semi-incestuous affair he is carrying on with Melissa, his adoptive sister. This novel travels easily between Ludo's current crisis and his memories of the curious upbringing that brought him to it.

- Summer

item.title: Life
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The long-awaited autobiography of the guitarist, songwriter, singer, and founding member of the Rolling Stones. Ladies and gentleman: Keith Richards. With the Rolling Stones, Keith Richards created the songs that roused the world, and he lived the original rock and roll life.
Now, at last, the man himself tells his story of life in the crossfire hurricane. Listening obsessively to Chuck Berry and Muddy Waters records, learning guitar and forming a band with Mick Jagger and Brian Jones. The Rolling Stones' first fame and the notorious drug busts that led to his enduring image an outlaw folk hero. Creating immortal riffs like the ones in "Jumping Jack Flash" and "Honky Tonk Women." Falling in love with Anita Pallenberg and the death of Brian Jones. Tax exile in France, wildfire tours of the US, isolation and addiction. Falling in love with Patti Hansen. Bitter estrangement from Jagger and subsequent reconciliation. Marriage, family, solo albums and Xpensive Winos, and the road that goes on forever.
With his trademark disarming honesty. Keith Richard brings us the story of a life we have all longed to know more of, unfettered, fearless, and true.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Ever fearless, guitarist and Rolling Stones founding member Keith Richards lets loose with some explosive revelations in his much-anticipated autobiography.  Keith is a legend in rock history – and who has lived life fuller than Richards?  Perfect for the feral creature in us all.

- Summer

item.title: Unbearable Lightness
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Known for her roles on the hit TV shows Ally McBeal and Arrested Development, de Rossi delivers a revelatory and searing account of the years she spend secretly suffering from bulimia, all the while living under the glare of Hollywood's bright lights. 8-page b&w photo insert.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Portia De Rossi bears her soul in a way that will leave you astounded. This is the journey of an Aussie-child come Hollywood starlet and the eating disorder that plagued her all the way through. It's a story of triumph and I love a happy ending.

- Summer

item.title: The Widower’s Tale
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A rich and suspenseful novel from the award-winning author of Three Junes and I See You Everywhere. In a quirky farmhouse outside Boston, seventy-year-old Percy Darling enjoys a vigorous but mostly solitary life–until, in a complex scheme to help his oldest daughter through a crisis, he allows a progressive preschool to move into his barn. The abrupt transformation of Percy's rural refuge into a lively, youthful community compels him to reexamine the choices he's made since his wife's death, three decades ago, in a senseless accident that haunts him still. No longer can he remain aloof from his neighbors, his two grown daughters, or, to his shock, the precarious joy of falling in love. Meanwhile, Percy's beloved grandson Robert, a premed student at Harvard, joins his visionary roommate in a series of environmental "actions" targeting the well-to-do; they begin as pranks but escalate insidiously, with dire consequences for Robert's family and the people around them, including a Guatemalan gardener and a gay preschool teacher, whose lives intersect fatefully with those of the Darlings. With equal parts affection and satire, Julia Glass spins a powerful tale about the multigenerational loyalties, rivalries, and secrets of a family, inhabitants of a complacently prosperous world where no one is immune to unexpected change. Yet again, she plumbs the human heart brilliantly, dramatically, and movingly.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Julia Glass gifts her readers with a stunning tale, a tale that encompasses multigenerational relationships, love and self-forgiveness, family loyalty and betrayal, the meaning of parenthood, and the intricate web of human connections. An intricately woven immensely character driven masterpiece. Not to miss.

- Summer

item.title: This Is NPR
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: "Always put the listener first" has been NPR's mantra since its inception in 1970. Now celebrating its 40th anniversary, NPR's programming attracts over 27 million listeners every week. This beautifully designed volume chronicles NPR's storied history, featuring dozens of behind-the-scenes photos, essays and original reporting by a who's who of NPR staff and correspondents, transcripts of memorable interviews, and an audio CD of the most memorable programming throughout the decades. Beyond an entertaining and inspiring tribute to NPR's remarkable history, this book is an intimate look at the news and stories that have shaped our world, from the people who were on the ground and on the air. With contributions from Steve Inskeep, Neal Conan, Robert Siegel, Nina Totenberg, Linda Wertheimer, Scott Simon, Melissa Block, P.J. O'Rourke, David Sedaris, Sylvia Poggioli, Paula Poundstone, and many more, this is the perfect book for any NPR supporter, fan, or devotee.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
A treasure for your library. Broadcasting history is memorialized in print with this wonderful collection of some of NPR’s finest moments. If you love NPR like I do, it’s a must have.

- Summer

item.title: Hue
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Kelly Wearstler is the ultimate trendsetter in interior design. Hue by Kelly Wearstler builds upon the success of her first monograph, Modern Glamour, and includes recent, unpublished projects, including her home in Beverly Hills, celebrity residential projects as well as some of her latest hotel projects. Hue celebrates the power of color in Kelly's work and the possibilities of color in interior design and decorating. A must-have for amateurs and professionals seeking design inspiration America's top interior designer.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This book is dazzling eye candy that will inspire you to use color in more unexpected ways.

- Summer

item.title: The Ellements of Personal Style
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: America's hottest fashion magazine blends expert advice with in-depth studies of twenty-five unique style icons, from Diane Von Furstenberg to Dita Von Teese to Alicia Keys, for personal style inspiration.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
I love getting a peek into the closets of some of the world's most fashionable women. Icons like Diane Von Furstenberg and Angelica Huston, along with lesser known but equally chic women, give us a glimpse into what makes their personal style. The authors then translate that style into doable ideas for even the most fashion clueless. A great handbook for updating your wardrobe.

– Summer

item.title: A Very She & Him Christmas CD
item.dc:creator: admin

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The ever adorable and charming Zooey Deschanel also has an absolutely amazing voice. If you're not already familiar with the folksy pop duo of She and Him, this album of nostalgic Christmas favorites is a great place to start. And if you're already a fan, you know the treat you're in for. Fresh, fun and a little jazzy, A Very She and Him Christmas is about to be your favorite holiday album.

-Summer

item.title: Jonathan Adler Agendas
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Who needs a Blackberry? Writing on this seventeen month calendar, starting August 2010, is way more fun than typing to-dos and hot dates into your phone. These agendas are packed full of fun tidbits and patterns to make your year all about Jonathan Adler! Here are some of the great features in each agenda: August 2010 through 2011 calendars, holiday List, month at a glance, week spreads, address & number section, coordinating sticker sheets, blank pages for notes and interior pocket for storing notes.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Breakaway from the dull boring screen of your Blackberry or iPhone calendar because function no longer rules over form. Like many of you, I had given up on my daily planner, but passé they are no more. The new agendas from designer Jonathan Adler make it fashionable to once again write your dates, tasks and appointments in your calendar. Featuring three graphic designs, you’re sure to find a pattern that expresses your personality.

- Summer

item.title: Interior Portraits
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The first book to survey the work of this iconic designer, known for her serene "new American classic" look. One of today's most influential designers, Victoria Hagan exploded onto the scene in 1988 when New York magazine devoted the cover of its design issue to one of her rooms. Since then she has become renowned for her intelligent integration of architectural and interior design, her refined use of materials, her sophisticated color palette, and her strong silhouettes. Always looking to the view, Hagan effortlessly makes a close connection of interior spaces to the surrounding landscape. The houses profiled–ranging from elegant urban residences to casual weekend retreats–reveal Hagan's unerring attention to what Proust called "the unexpected detail," which makes her interiors beautiful as well as timeless. Throughout, Hagan discourses on the spirit of cherished objects--a print of birds in flight, a vintage star-shaped mirror, or a chair with an unusual silhouette--that add soul and modernity. With stunning photography and personal insights into Hagan's design philosophy, Victoria Hagan: Interior Portraits is an artful and inspiring collection of this design superstar's oeuvre.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Influential interior designer Victoria Hagan is a master of comfortable elegance. Here, Hagan's airy, refined interiors are beautifully displayed, with informative details on Hagan's creative process. Nobody does sophisticated simplicity like Hagan, and this book is a gorgeous testament to her genius.

– Summer

item.title: The House of the Spirit
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Here, in an astonishing debut by a gifted storyteller, is the magnificent saga of proud and passionate men and women and the turbulent times through which they suffer and triumph. They are the Truebas. And theirs is a world you will not want to leave, and one you will not forget.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The debut novel of master storyteller Isabel Allende is one of my favorites. This epic, complex, magical novel explores the highs and lows of multiple generations of the Latin American Truebas family. Allende's characters blaze with life and you'll find at least one to love, and others to despise. This is a modern masterpiece everyone should read.

- Summer

item.title: Yoshitomo Nara: Nobody's Fool
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Created in partnership with Asia Society Museum in conjunction with a major retrospective, this is the first comprehensive monograph on the work of art superstar Yoshitomo Nara. It assembles 20 years worth of paintings, sculptures, photographs, and drawings that map the evolution of one of the most influential and internationally renowned artists working today. The book and exhibition will draw connections between Nara's work and the sensibilities of youth subcultures worldwide, focusing on themes of alienation and rebellion, particularly in relation to rock and punk music, the inspiration and subject of many of Nara's works. Featuring artworks that have never before been exhibited and playlists selected by the artist, this is the book Nara's legion of devoted followers have been waiting for.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Melissa Chiu, Miwako Tezuka, Midori Matsui and Michael Wilson

The art of Japanese artist Yoshitomo Nara art embodies the spirit of childhood set to a rock and punk soundtrack. I am enamored of his illustrations of devilish little girls with a gleam in their eyes. This spectacular book includes photographs of the recent exhibition of his work at the Asia Society in New York City, as well as essays, blog posts from Nara himself and his own favorite playlists. You'll fall in love with the work of one of the most imaginative artists working today.

– Summer

item.title: The Elegance of the Hedgehog
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: We are in the center of Paris, in an elegant apartment building inhabited by bourgeois families. RenA(c)e, the concierge, is witness to the lavish but vacuous lives of her numerous employers. Outwardly she conforms to every stereotype of the concierge: fat, cantankerous, addicted to television. Yet, unbeknown to her employers, RenA(c)e is a cultured autodidact who adores art, philosophy, music, and Japanese culture. With humor and intelligence she scrutinizes the lives of the building's tenants, who for their part are barely aware of her existence.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This philosophical tale of class and personalities affects the heart as well as the mind. Two misfits –one a 50-something concierge and the other a precocious 12-year-old girl – hide their true natures from society in a posh apartment building in Paris. When a dapper Japanese man moves in, all three lives become intertwined. A complex, thought-provoking, big-hearted novel I won't soon forget.

– Summer

item.title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Celebrated painter and filmmaker Julian Schnabel's third feature finds him reaching new artistic heights with this audacious and personal biopic, based on the best-selling memoir of the same name. The film tells the remarkable tale of Jean-Dominique Bauby (Mathieu Amalric), the world-renowned editor of French ELLE magazine, who suffered a stroke and was paralyzed by the inexplicable "locked in" syndrome at the age of 43. Bauby's only way of communicating with the outside world was by blinking with one eye, and after several dedicated helpers--a string of impossibly beautiful women (Emmanuelle Seigner, Marie-Josee Croze, Olatz Lopez Garamendia, Anne Consigny)--helped him to speak through this seemingly irrelevant gesture, he began to produce the words that would form his memoir. Along the way, as he swam in and out of consciousness, memories from his past swelled into the present, resulting in a cinematic experience that is at once heartbreaking and hopeful. Schnabel somehow manages to convey Bauby's internal life with remarkable clarity, employing first-person perspective, striking cinematography (by the always great Janusz Kaminski), and Amalric's pained, life-affirming monologues. The result is a wholly original experience, a painful and tender portrait of a life that is made all the more exhilarating because of its close proximity to death.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This breathtaking film lets us see the world through the single, blinking eye of Jean-Dominique Bauby, a brilliant fashion editor paralyzed except for his left eye. Though he is trapped inside his body, Bauby's mind overflows with memories, dreams and fantasies. A deeply moving and inspiring film about the unbreakable human spirit.

– Summer

item.title: Who Is Harry Nilsson (And Why Is Everybody Talkin' About Him)?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Although he never became the kind of international superstar someone with his remarkable skills should have, Harry Nilsson was arguably the most respected singer, songwriter, and record maker of the '70s, winning a pair of Grammys for his covers of "Everybody's Talkin'," and "Without You." This documentary features archival footage of the quirky performer, and copious new interviews with contemporaries who discuss his outrageous behavior and his formidable talent.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Harry Nilsson was a great musician and songwriter, a man who was sometimes called “the fifth Beatle.” But he was also a self-destructive, wildly unpredictable genius. This fascinating documentary answers the question “Who is Harry Nilsson?” just beautifully, with amazing interviews and archival footage and incredible music.

– Summer

I fell for this band the first time I saw them live. Indie Rock gods Arcade Fire have cranked out yet another wildly successful album, concreting them among the legendary.

– Summer

item.title: Josh Ritter: So Runs the World Away
item.dc:creator: admin

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
So Runs the World is a collection of songs packed with deeply moving lyrics and grand instrumentation. This is Josh Ritter’s comeback album after a long spell of writer’s block and it was worth the wait.So Runs the World is sensational.

– Summer

Every song on Contra is an instant energizer – it's one of my favorite CDs to play to get a party loosened up. The album has a peppy, summery vibe that will make you want to listen again and again.

– Summer

item.title: Sunset Park
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Sunset Park follows the hopes and fears of a cast of unforgettable characters brought together by the mysterious Miles Heller during the dark months of the 2008 economic collapse.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
After a terrible accident, Miles Heller flees his comfortable life to live in an abandoned Brooklyn farmhouse with other troubled twenty-somethings. Set immediately after the economic recession began in 2008, Sunset Park cuts to the heart of contemporary American struggles, while still looking for a silver lining in the gathering clouds. Miles is an interesting, sympathetic character I really loved reading about.

–Summer

Wildly creative, this band’s first album is making a magnificent crescendo in the music world. A must listen.

– Summer

item.title: The Social Network
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Director David Fincher (FIGHT CLUB, SEVEN) teams with screenwriter Aaron Sorkin (THE WEST WING) to explore the meaning of success in the early 21st century from the perspectives of the technological innovators who revolutionized the way we all communicate. The year was 2003. As prohibitively expensive technology became affordable to the masses and the Internet made it easy to stay in touch with people who were halfway across the world, Harvard undergrad and computer programming wizard Mark Zuckerberg (Jesse Eisenberg) launched a website with the potential to alter the very fabric of our society. At the time, Zuckerberg was just six years away from making his first million. But his hearty payday would come at a high price, because despite all of Zuckerberg's wealth and success, his personal life began to suffer as he became mired in legal disputes, and discovered that many of the 500 million people he had friended during his rise to the top were eager to see him fall. Chief among that growing list of detractors was Zuckerberg's former college friend Eduardo Saverin (Andrew Garfield), whose generous financial contributions to Facebook served as the seed that helped the company to sprout. And some might argue that Zuckerberg's bold venture wouldn't have evolved into the cultural juggernaut that it ultimately became had Napster founder Sean Parker (Justin Timberlake) not spread the word about Facebook to the venture capitalists from Silicon Valley. Meanwhile, the Winklevoss twins (Armie Hammer and Josh Pence) engage Zuckerberg in a fierce courtroom battle for ownership of Facebook that left many suspecting the young entrepreneur might have let his greed eclipse his better judgment. THE SOCIAL NETWORK was based on the book THE ACCIDENTAL BILLIONAIRES by Ben Mezrich.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Destined to be the big winner, The Social Network isn't just Hollywood's pick. Movie watchers everywhere have proclaimed it as a must see. It's the story of Facebook creator Mark Zuckerburg's battle to maintain ownership of his social media idea. What began as a communication medium for Harvard students, exploded into a phenomenon around the globe. But as Facebook grew in popularity, so did Zuckerburg's legal woes. So even if you haven't updated your status in a while, you're sure to "Like" this movie.

– Summer

item.title: The Fates Will Find Their Way
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Sixteen-year-old Nora Lindell is missing. And the neighborhood boys she's left behind are caught forever in the heady current of her absence.
As the days and years pile up, the mystery of her disappearance grows kaleidoscopically. A collection of rumors, divergent suspicions, and tantalizing what-ifs, Nora Lindell's story is a shadowy projection of teenage lust, friendship, reverence, and regret, captured magically in the disembodied plural voice of the boys who still long for her.
Told in haunting, percussive prose, Hannah Pittard's beautifully crafted novel tracks the emotional progress of the sister Nora left behind, the other families in their leafy suburban enclave, and the individual fates of the boys in her thrall. Far more eager to imagine Nora's fate than to scrutinize their own, the boys sleepwalk into an adulthood of jobs, marriages, families, homes, and daughters of their own, all the while pining for a girl–and a life–that no longer exists, except in the imagination.
A masterful literary debut that shines a light into the dream-filled space between childhood and all that follows, The Fates Will Find Their Way is a story about the stories we tell ourselves–of who we once were and may someday become.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Sixteen year old Nora Lindell is missing. That’s the only truth we know for sure. Speculations of what really happened to her run wild amongst a tight-knit group of boys in her class. Her disappearance has a profound effect of these boys and marks a point in their lives when everything changed; when they suddenly realized life had limits. The Fates Will Find Their Way reminds me of another favorite, The Virgin Suicides--both revolve around a tragedy and are told through the clever use of collective first person narration, giving you a sense of participation in the story. I found this a quick and easy read—enjoyable from beginning to end.

– Summer

item.title: The Other Life
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Quinn Braverman has a secret. Every time she makes a major life decision, she knows an alternate reality exists in which she has made the opposite choice–not only that, she knows how to cross over. Quinn hasn't been tempted to slip through–until she receives devastating news about the baby she's carrying.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Absolutely intriguing. This book left me wondering what it would be like to escape to an alternate reality where mistakes, misfortune and poor decisions could be avoided. Quinn Braverman’s secret leaves us to question, what is life without the mystery of what could have been? And are you really living if you don’t have to be accountable for your decisions?

– Summer

item.title: Exit the Actress
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: "A triumph" says Philippa Gregory, of this debut novel about the life of the legendary 17th century actress and mistress of Charles II, Nell Gwyn.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Told through diary entries, newspaper clippings and letters, Exit the Actress is a fresh, original take on historical fiction. I loved this rags to riches tale about Nell Gwyn, a poor girl who eventually becomes one of England's greatest theater stars, and the mistress of Charles II.

– Summer

Fans of the much-lamented Domino, take heart! Lonny, an online magazine launched by a former Domino editor, fills the chic-but-livable void that the magazine left behind. Filled with fantastic photography, gorgeous interiors, great design advice and must-have new products, Lonny has a pretty, modern aesthetic that's both inspirational and attainable.

– Summer

Visit Lonny Magazine Online!

Vince and his childhood buddies are riding the wave of his success in Hollywood. They discover staying on the A-list in LA isn’t easy, even with his powerhouse agent Ari Gold. I used to countdown the days until the next episode, but with Entourage on DVD and I can get my fix any time I choose.

– Summer

item.title: Friday Night Lights: The First Season
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Football is one of the most popular sports in America, but in Texas it's closer to religion. The first season of this award-winning show uses the game as focal point for each episode's structure, but the gridiron often takes the backseat to the more pressing issues of life in Middle America. The real star of the show is the fictional town of Dillon, a place that represents the struggle of hard-working-yet-flawed human beings getting through another year of life in a small community. The town's team, the Panthers, may be headed for the top, but can their coach (EARLY EDITION's Kyle Chandler) and the players keep it together as the pressure of their personal lives threatens to knock them down?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
In Dillon, Texas, there’s one thing everyone can agree on - the affinity for football. And while the show’s foundation is based on the sport, the storylines are strong and dramatic covering real-life high school and small town events that go far beyond the gridiron. Without exception, it’s some of the best acting you’ll find on television today.

– Summer

item.title: Alphabet
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: From the bestselling creator of "Tails" and "Dog" comes an alphabet book that will tickle and delight. The grand finale spread is a feat of novelty mastery bursting with 26 individual pop-ups of every letter of the alphabet.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Matthew Van Fleet introduces imaginative and amazing stories to kids in fun, innovative ways, and his touch-and-feel books are full of delightful illustrations and surprises. A must-own for every child’s library!

– Summer

item.title: Catfish
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Love and identity become twisted across the lines of the Internet in this documentary from filmmakers Henry Joost and Ariel Schulman. Nev Schulman is a photographer who one day received a surprising e-mail message – Abby, an eight-year-old girl in Michigan, had seen his picture in a newspaper and wanted permission to paint a portrait from it. Nev gave his OK, and when he was given a copy of the painting, he was struck by how good it was, assuming that the girl was either a genius or a fraud. Nev tried to contact Abby's family, and somehow ended up in contact with Megan, Abby's sexy 19-year-old sister. As Nev fell into an increasingly complicated on-line relationship with Megan, he decided it was time to meet her in person, but when he traveled to Michigan and tracked her down, Nev learned that Abby and Megan's family were not at all what he expected them to be. Ariel Schulman, Nev's brother, began filming his brother's adventures from his first contact with Abby, and in CATFISH he and Henry Joost tell this strange story from beginning to end. CATFISH received its world premiere at the 2010 Sundance Film Festival.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This artful documentary was the surprise hit of 2010, and with good reason. Love, lies and identity are all wrapped up in a suspenseful story that I won't spoil for you. You definitely need to see this little gem of a film for yourself.

–Summer

Launched earlier this year, Matchbook is like your fun, stylish friend who knows a little about everything. Matchbook features stories on fashions for you and your home, beauty, travel, trivia tidbits and vivid personalities galore. The magazine has a smart but casual vibe that is so appealing.

– Summer

Visit Matchbook Magazine Online

item.title: I Am Love
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This lavish, sprawling drama from filmmaker Luca Guadagnino has drawn numerous comparisons to the films of Luchino Visconti for the grace with which it plumbs the inner workings of the Italian upper crust. Edoardo Recchi Sr. (Gabriele Ferzetti) is the aging patriarch of a Milanese clan that has amassed a significant fortune over the years through shrewd investments in the textile business. Edoardo Sr. has a beautiful wife, Allegra (Marisa Berenson), and the two have a reliable and dependable son, Tancredi (Pippo Delbono). Years ago, Tancredi met, fell in love with, and then married a woman named Emma (Tilda Swinton) amid a trip to Russia, and brought her back home to Milan; their children include sons Edoardo Jr. (Flavio Parenti) and Gianluca (Mattia Zaccaro), and artist daughter Elisabetta (Alba Rohrwacher). The family gathers for a reunion at Edoardo Sr. and Allegra's villa in Milan, but the happy gathering takes a somber turn when Edoardo suddenly dies not long after having lunch with his family. But the death is far from the only pivotal event that occurs that day: Edoardo Jr. also introduces his mother to a chef, Antonio (Edoardo Gabbriellini), with whom he plans to open a restaurant, and Emma finds herself drawn to the culinary artist. Meanwhile, Emma learns that Elisabetta is a lesbian, and though initially startled by this news, she takes the liberation of her daughter as inspiration for her own liberation from confining nuptials. On impulse, Emma travels to San Remo, catches sight of Antonio, and finds herself helplessly drawn to him. Meanwhile, as Emma and Elisabetta undertake their life-changing journeys, all of the men in the Recchi clan outside of Edoardo Jr. feel bound to profit-driven motives -- the commercialism of a class that has long ago shucked responsibility for its workers. This critically acclaimed film constituted Swinton's second collaboration with Guadagnino; they first worked together on the 1999 feature THE PROTAGONISTS.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Tilda Swinton is breathtaking in this gorgeous saga about the wealthy Recchi family in Milan. Tilda plays Emma, the Russian-born wife of Tancredi Recchi, whose father has just passed the family textile business onto him. The story beautifully illustrates the friction between old and new tradition and following your heart while the impeccable cinematography and styling make I Am Love a feast for the eyes.

– Summer

Who doesn’t love balloon animals? Now you can help your kids whip up their own amazing creations. The kit includes 24 balloons and a pump so Mom and Dad won’t have to do all the work.

– Summer

Show up at your next party incognito, disguised behind this ultra-cool mustache. My favorite feature, it’s bendable, so you can go from Fu Manchu to handlebar with just a little twist.

– Summer

These handy little zodiac pockets papers make perfect birthday gifts. Each is colorfully illustrated and contains a quote that really captures the essence of the sign with a wink.

– Summer

Sometimes simple is best. These elegant journals in gold and silver feature soft leather covers and ivory acid-free lined paper. I love how sturdy this journal feels, like a book. It makes everything I write seem novel-worthy.

– Summer

Stop jotting down your great ideas on napkins and paper scraps – elevate them with the Idea Log! This ingenious little journal keeps all my ideas, brainstorms, sketches, and projects in one place.

– Summer

These amazing old school composition books are so special. The cover art is based on a comic strip from the late 1920’s to early 1930’s and the inside covers feature the practical – a class schedule, metric conversion chart, multiplication tables and a little bit of magic with the inclusion of a poem.

– Summer

item.title: It's Kind of a Funny Story
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Adapted from Ned Vizzini's 2006 novel, IT'S KIND OF A FUNNY STORY tells the story of burnt-out teenager Craig (Keir Gilchrist), who checks himself into a mental health clinic citing exhaustion, and finds himself placed in the adult ward due to the fact that the youth ward has been shut down. Taken under the wing of fellow patient Bobby (Zach Galifianakis), the stressed-out 16-year-old attempts to endure his mandatory five days' stay without completely losing his mind. His predicament is made somewhat more tolerable by the presence of Noelle (Emma Roberts), another teenage patient who's struggling to sort out her thoughts. Academy Award nominee Viola Davis, Lauren Graham, and Jim Gaffigan co-star.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Craig Gilner, a high-achieving Brooklyn high school student, checks himself into a psychiatric hospital to avoid killing himself. What he finds is not what one expects, but an enormous wealth of hilarity and life lessons from his fellow patients. A poignant tale that is not to be missed.

– Summer

item.title: She Walks in Beauty
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: She Walks in Beauty is Kennedy's selection of poetry that tells the story of a woman's life including first love and lasting love; marriage, motherhood, and work; times of silence and solitude, and times of awe. She has written introductions to each of the book's sections, highlighting the joys and struggles that are part of every woman's journey.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This carefully selected collection of poems touches on all stages of a woman’s existence and is interspersed with Caroline Kennedy's reflections on her own life. Some of my all-time favorite poems are included, and I was delighted to read them again in such a personal collection.
– Summer

item.title: Thousand Cranes Notecard
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The design is a simple motif that is made up of many origami cranes. Senbazuru - or one thousand cranes - is a tradition of folding 1,000 origami cranes to grant a wish, such as wishing for a speedy and solid recovery. This is the hope for the people in Japan as they have experienced such a devastating tragedy. 100% proceeds will be donated to the American Red Cross to support disaster relief efforts to help those affected by the earthquake in Japan and tsunami throughout the Pacific.
Set includes 4 letterpress flat cards (2 designs) that are 4.25 x 5.5 inches with matching-size envelopes. Back side is blank for you to write on. The cards are printed on 100% cotton Crane's Lettra paper.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
An ancient Japanese legend says that folding 1,000 origami cranes can grant a wish. As we wish the people of Japan strength and hope as they recover and rebuild, I can't think of a better design for these beautiful letterpress notecards. 100% of the proceeds will be donated to the Red Cross relief efforts in Japan.
– Summer

item.title: Come to the Edge
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: When Christina Haag was growing up on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, John F. Kennedy, Jr., was just one of the boys in her circle of prep school friends, a skinny kid who lived with his mother and sister on Fifth Avenue and who happened to have a Secret Service detail following him at a discreet distance at all times. A decade later, after they had both graduated from Brown University and were living in New York City, Christina and John were cast in an off-Broadway play together. It was then that John confessed his long-standing crush on her, and they embarked on a five-year love affair. Glamorous and often in the public eye, but also passionate and deeply intimate, their relationship was transformative for both of them. With exquisite prose, Haag paints a portrait of a young man with an enormous capacity for love, and an adventurous spirit that drove him to live life to its fullest. A haunting book, Come to the Edge is a lasting evocation of a time and a place—of the indelible sting of the loss of young love, and of the people who shape you and remain with you, whether in person or in spirit. It is about being young and full of hope, with all the potential of your life as yet unfulfilled, and of coming of age at a moment in New York’s history when the city at once held danger, magic, and endless possibilities for self-discovery.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Get a glimpse of private and intimate moments shared with a very public man as Christina Haag reveals details of her relationship with John F. Kennedy, Jr. Beautifully told in a heartfelt fashion—timeless, gracious and romantic. You must experience this exquisite love story.

– Summer

Need to break the ice or just get the party started on the right foot? Nothing gets conversation flowing faster than Table Topics to Go. There are tons of versions for any situation so go ahead and ask away!

– Summer

Have a difficult decision to make? Make it easier with this clever pad. I especially like the little box at the bottom you can check when your problem is solved. How satisfying is that?

– Summer

Think of this handy pad as a modern recipe file. Keep all the lists and notes you need to make successful recipes, even tasting notes and what you paired it with. I like to experiment in the kitchen, so I'll be buying lots of these.

– Summer

Instead of little bottles, this “minibar” is filled with thought-provoking questions, reading material and a notepad to jot down your dreams and fears. The custom box is beautifully designed, and the pencils are adorned with quotes from great writers. A feast for the eyes and the mind.

– Summer

item.title: Heads You Lose
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: New York Times-bestselling author Lisa Lutz conspires with-or should we say "against"?-coauthor David Hayward to write an original and hilarious tag-team crime novel. Meet Paul and Lacey Hansen: orphaned, pot-growing twentysomething siblings eking out a living in rural Northern California. When a headless corpse appears on their property, they can't exactly dial 911, so they move the body and wait for the police to find it. Instead, the corpse reappears, a few days riper . . . and an amateur sleuth is born. Make that two. When collaborators Lutz and Hayward (former romantic partners) start to disagree about how the story should unfold, the body count rises, victims and suspects alike develop surprising characteristics (meet Brandy Chester, the stripper with the Mensa IQ), and sibling rivalry reaches homicidal intensity. Think Adaptation crossed with Weeds. Will the authors solve the mystery without killing each other first?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
A hilariously fresh take on the 'murder mystery.' Writers and former romantic partners Lisa Lutz and David Hayward collaborated on this story about two pot growing siblings living in Northern California. Paul and Lacey live a seemingly quiet existence in this sleepy small town until a headless corpse shows up on their doorstep one night. From there, a slew of off-beat characters come out of the woodwork to make this novel deeply funny and entertaining. A great beach read!

– Summer

To the market, to the market to get...now what was it I needed again? You'll never forget the milk again with this chic little tablet that keeps your grocery needs stylishly organized.

– Summer

Feeling overwhelmed by all the things that need fixing at your place? As the cover says, "Make a list -- you'll feel better." This handy notepad keeps all your household tasks and chores at your fingertips. There are few things as satisfying as checking that little box that says "all done" at the bottom of the page.

– Summer

item.title: GREENBERG
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Hollywood meets the mumblecore indie movement in this film starring TROPIC THUNDER’s Ben Stiller and HANNAH TAKES THE STAIRS’ Greta Gerwig. Stiller plays Roger Greenberg, a man who falls for his brother’s assistant (Gerwig) while he is going through a life crisis. Directed by Noah Baumbach, GREENBERG also stars Rhys Ifans, Jennifer Jason Leigh, and mumblecore regular Mark Duplass.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Ben Stiller plays the title character, but don't expect a Gaylord Focker screw-ball sort. Greenberg is a not-so-likable former musician who's trying to recover from a mental breakdown. In his diminished state, he begins an awkward relationship of sorts with his brother's assistant, Florence, played by Greta Gerwig. She, like Greenberg, is adrift in her life; always looking to make a connection, but missing every time. I enjoyed this movie for many reasons, but mostly because it was different from what has recently flooded the market.

– Summer

The fashion forward ikat print gives these journals a touch of the exotic. Unlined paper gives you free reign to write, sketch or doodle and the handy pocket size slips neatly into a coat pocket or handbag. I just love the rich colors. A colorful journal leads to more colorful ideas!

– Summer

Alexa Pulitzer is a New Orleans designer whose stationery is inspired by her home city's genteel sophistication. The gorgeous designs have a touch of whimsy, but look so elegant your correspondents will swear they're custom-made.

– Summer

These T-shirts do more than make you look smart (you already are anyway!) For each shirt sold Out of Print will donate a book to a community in need through Books for Africa. How could you not buy one?

– Summer

item.title: Country Strong
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A fallen country star (Gwyneth Paltrow) strives to resurrect her ailing career with a little help from her supportive husband (Tim McGraw), an ambitious young songwriter (Garrett Hedlund), and an emerging country artist (Leighton Meester) with a rapidly growing fan base.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Gwyneth Paltrow surprised me with her moving, honest portrayal of a fallen country singer losing her battle with addiction. The rest of the cast, including Leighton Meester as a rising star and Tim McGraw as her husband and manager are all fabulous. This one was severely underrated by the critics in my opinion!

– Summer Says

item.title: Girls in Trucks
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Sarah Walters, the narrator of GIRLS IN TRUCKS, is a reluctant Camellia Society debutante. She has always felt ill-fitted to the rococo ways of Southern womanhood and family, and is anxious to shake the bonds of her youth. Still, she follows the traditional path laid out for her. This is Charleston, and in this beautiful, dark, segregated town, established rules and manners mean everything.
But as Sarah grows older, she finds that her Camellia lessons fail her, particularly as she goes to college, moves North, and navigates love and life in New York. There, Sarah and her group of displaced deb sisters try to define themselves within the realities of modern life. Heartbreak, addiction, disappointing jobs and death fail to live up to the hazy, happy future promised to them by their Camellia mothers and sisters.
When some unexpected bumps in the road--an unplanned birth, a family death--lead Sarah back home, she's forced to take another long look at the fading empire of her youth. It takes a strange turn of events to finally ground Sarah enough to make some serious choices. And only then does she realize that as much as she tried to deny it, where she comes from will always affect where she ends up. The motto of her girlhood cotillion society, "Once a Camellia, always a Camellia," may turn out to have more wisdom and pull to it than she ever could have guessed.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Full of Southern charm, this debut novel is a great beach read. The characters are so entertaining, especially Sarah, the ex-debutante who moves to the city and tries to put her cotillion past behind her. If you love reading about the South and its quirky characters, you'll love this fun novel!

– Summer

item.title: The Tiger’s Wife
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: When The New Yorker ran an excerpt of The Tiger's Wife in its 2009 Fiction issue, it was clear an astonishing new talent had arrived in the world of contemporary fiction... The time: the present. The place: a Balkan country ravaged by years of conflict. Natalia, a young doctor, is on a mission of mercy to an orphanage when she receives word of her beloved grandfather's death far from their home under circumstances shrouded in confusion. Remembering childhood stories her grandfather once told her, Natalia becomes convinced that he spent his last days searching for "the deathless man," a vagabond who claimed to be immortal. As Natalia struggles to understand why her grandfather, a deeply rational man, who go on such a farfetched journey, she stumbles across a clue that leads her to the extraordinary story of the tiger's wife. An involving mystery, an emotionally riveting family story, and a wondrous evocation of an unfamiliar world, The Tiger's Wife is a brilliant novel.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The Tiger’s Wife is a magical tale of a granddaughter's love for her grandfather. Natalia, a young doctor, learns that her grandfather has died mysteriously in a remote village in Eastern Europe. As she tries to piece together what happened, the novel takes you on a folkloric journey through the Balkans during wartime and paints a picture of her grandfather in his younger days. This book is pure magic! Tea Obreht has been named one of the 20 best writers under 40. I am in awe of this young woman and the staggering talent she possesses.

– Summer

item.title: The Summer Without Men
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Mia Fredrickson, the wry, vituperative, tragic comic, poet narrator of The Summer Without Men, has been forced to reexamine her own life. One day, out of the blue, after thirty years of marriage, Mia's husband, a renowned neuroscientist, asks her for a "pause." This abrupt request sends her reeling and lands her in a psychiatric ward. The June following Mia's release from the hospital, she returns to the prairie town of her childhood, where her mother lives in an old people's home.
