Alone in a rented house, she rages and fumes and bemoans her sorry fate. Slowly, however, she is drawn into the lives of those around her–her mother and her close friends, "the Five Swans," and her young neighbor with two small children and a loud angry husband–and the adolescent girls in her poetry workshop whose scheming and petty cruelty carry a threat all their own. From the internationally bestselling author of What I Loved comes a provocative, witty, and revelatory novel about women and girls, love and marriage, and the age-old question of sameness and difference between the sexes.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Poet Mia Frederickson finds herself in a mental hospital after her husband of thirty years of marriage asks for a 'pause.' She pulls herself together and returns home to a small Minnesota town for the summer to be with her elderly mother. Mia also gets involved in the lives of her neighbor, a young mother of two with an angry husband and her mother's group of friends at the nursing home, 'the five swans.' It is through these relationships with women young and old that Mia begins to heal. A beautifully written and delightful read.

– Summer

item.title: He’s My Brother, She’s My Sister CD
item.dc:creator: admin

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
He's My Brother, She's My Sister is an eclectic group that includes a brother and sister on vocals, a tap dancing percussionist and a cellist. Their sound is folksy but with lots of swing, and their lyrics are original and funny. When I listen to this album, I'm fascinated by that old-fashioned sound that somehow seems so fresh and new. Each track on this album is absolutely perfect – and I can't wait for the next!

– Summer

item.title: Silver Sparrow
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Tayari Jones unveils a breathtaking story about a man's deception, a family's complicity, and two teenage girls caught in the middle. Set in Atlanta in the 1980s, the novel revolves around James Witherspoon's two families-the public one and the secret one. When the daughters from each family meet and form a friendship, only one of them knows they are sisters. It is a relationship destined to explode when secrets are revealed and illusions shattered. As Jones explores the backstories of her rich yet flawed characters–the father, the two mothers, the grandmother, and the uncle–she reveals the joy, as well as the destruction, they brought to one another's lives. At the heart of it all are the two lives at stake, and like the best writers, she portrays the fragility of these young girls with raw authenticity as they seek love, demand attention, and try to imagine themselves as women.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Silver Sparrow starts with a bang: "My father, James Witherspoon, is a bigamist." You'll read this magnificent novel as fast as you can to see the train wreck this man has set up for himself and his two families. Imagine growing up with a 'sometimes' father. He must pretend you and your mother don’t exist, because he has another family that he doesn't keep secret from the world.

- Summer

Travel is always exciting, but it's no fun to get to the hotel and realize you forgot your swimsuit. Make a list and check it twice with this essential notebook.

–Summer

I like to fill the cheery yellow “Accomplish” tablet with all those pesky daily errands. It's nice to get to check the “accomplished” box at the bottom of each page!

– Summer

item.title: The First 1,000 Days : A Baby Journal
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Nikki McClure's beautifully detailed illustrations divide this lovely baby journal into sections celebrating the first 1,000 days of life, from the story of birth to jumping into her first mud puddle. Modeled after the journal the author started when her son was born, the sections focus on recording a child's interaction with the natural world, including baby's first tree, moon, and garden.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This beautifully illustrated baby journal is so much more personal than other baby books I've seen. The journal style is perfect for recording all the things that happen as your little one grows and experiences the world. I'll be giving this lovely book as a gift to all my friends who are mothers-to-be.

– Summer

item.title: My Father's Daughter
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The Academy-Award winning actress and avid foodie shares a sumptuous collection of recipes and gorgeous photographs celebrating the joy of preparing food for loved ones, a passion she learned from her beloved father. As an actress, author, trendsetter, creator of goop.com, and host of the popular PBS series, Spain: On the Road Again, Gwyneth Paltrow is an icon of style and good taste around the world. As a young girl eating and cooking with her father, Bruce Paltrow, she developed a passion for food that has shaped how she lives today and strengthened her belief that time with family is a priority. Now in MY FATHER'S DAUGHTER, Paltrow shares her favorite family recipes along with personal stories of growing up with her father, Bruce Paltrow. She discusses how he has influenced her in the food she loves, how she involves her kids in cooking, and how she balances healthy food with homemade treats. And, for the first time, Paltrow offers a glimpse into her life as daughter, mother and wife, sharing her thoughts on the importance of family and togetherness. Complete with 150 delicious ideas for breakfast, sandwiches and burgers, soups, salads, main dishes, sides, and desserts, this beautifully illustrated book includes full-color photos throughout, many featuring Paltrow at home with her family and friends. MY FATHER'S DAUGHTER is a luscious collection that will inspire readers to cook great food with the people who mean the most to them.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Gwenyth isn't just a celebrity and style icon – she's a fantastic cook and her love of food is evident on every page. I especially enjoyed the touching anecdotes from her childhood about the impact her father had on her life. The simple, delicious recipes and beautiful stories and photos make this cookbook a standout.

– Summer

item.title: The Paris Wife
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A deeply evocative story of ambition and betrayal, The Paris Wife captures a remarkable period of time and a love affair between two unforgettable people: Ernest Hemingway and his wife Hadley. Chicago, 1920: Hadley Richardson is a quiet twenty-eight-year-old who has all but given up on love and happiness—until she meets Ernest Hemingway and her life changes forever. Following a whirlwind courtship and wedding, the pair set sail for Paris, where they become the golden couple in a lively and volatile group—the fabled “Lost Generation”—that includes Gertrude Stein, Ezra Pound, and F. Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald. Though deeply in love, the Hemingways are ill prepared for the hard-drinking and fast-living life of Jazz Age Paris, which hardly values traditional notions of family and monogamy. Surrounded by beautiful women and competing egos, Ernest struggles to find the voice that will earn him a place in history, pouring all the richness and intensity of his life with Hadley and their circle of friends into the novel that will become The Sun Also Rises. Hadley, meanwhile, strives to hold on to her sense of self as the demands of life with Ernest grow costly and her roles as wife, friend, and muse become more challenging. Despite their extraordinary bond, they eventually find themselves facing the ultimate crisis of their marriage—a deception that will lead to the unraveling of everything they’ve fought so hard for. A heartbreaking portrayal of love and torn loyalty, The Paris Wife is all the more poignant because we know that, in the end, Hemingway wrote that he would rather have died than fallen in love with anyone but Hadley.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The scene is Paris in the Roaring '20s. The soon-to-be-legendary Hemingway is making his mark on the literary scene with his wife, Hadley, in tow. They struggle to keep their feet on the ground as they navigate the free-wheeling, hard-drinking life of the times. As I read this mesmerizing novel, I thought of Ernest and Hadley as pioneers, blazing their own trail through notoriety, wealth and all the beautiful people, places and things that go along with them. This book is a heartbreaking tale about true love and its intricacies. How does something so pure and strong stray from that perfectly set path and how does one move on after it's all said and done? But then, is it ever really all said and done?

– Summer

item.title: Blood, Bones & Butter
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Before Gabrielle Hamilton opened her acclaimed New York restaurant Prune, she spent twenty fierce, hard-living years trying to find purpose and meaning in her life. Above all she sought family, particularly the thrill and the magnificence of the one from her childhood that, in her adult years, eluded her. Hamilton’s ease and comfort in a kitchen were instilled in her at an early age when her parents hosted grand parties, often for more than one hundred friends and neighbors. The smells of spit-roasted lamb, apple wood smoke, and rosemary garlic marinade became as necessary to her as her own skin. Blood, Bones & Butter follows an unconventional journey through the many kitchens Hamilton has inhabited through the years: the rural kitchen of her childhood, where her adored mother stood over the six-burner with an oily wooden spoon in hand; the kitchens of France, Greece, and Turkey, where she was often fed by complete strangers and learned the essence of hospitality; the soulless catering factories that helped pay the rent; Hamilton’s own kitchen at Prune, with its many unexpected challenges; and the kitchen of her Italian mother-in-law, who serves as the link between Hamilton’s idyllic past and her own future family—the result of a difficult and prickly marriage that nonetheless yields rich and lasting dividends. Blood, Bones & Butter is an unflinching and lyrical work. Gabrielle Hamilton’s story is told with uncommon honesty, grit, humor, and passion. By turns epic and intimate, it marks the debut of a tremendous literary talent.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
I can't say it any better than Mario Batali does: "Gabrielle Hamilton has changed the potential and raised the bar for all books about eating and cooking. Her nearly rabid love for all real food experience and her completely vulnerable, unprotected yet pure point of view unveils itself in both truth and inspiration. I will read this book to my children and then burn all the books I have written for pretending to be anything even close to this. After that I will apply for the dishwasher job at Prune to learn from my new queen."

– Summer

item.title: Before I Go to Sleep
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Author S.J. Watson makes his powerful debut with this compelling, fast-paced psychological thriller, reminiscent of Shutter Island and Memento, in which an amnesiac who, following a mysterious accident, cannot remember her past or form new memories, desperately tries to uncover the truth about who she is - and whom she can trust.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Christine suffers from a form of amnesia that leaves her with no memory of the horrific night when she was nearly strangled to death. Worse, she's unable to retain memories of her daily life since. Watson keeps you on the edge of your seat with the way he unfolds this riveting psychological thriller. You are going to love this one!

- Summer

Keep your summer style effortless with these chic totes and scarves. The scarves give any outfit from tees and jeans to a summer dress the perfect accent. And I love these adorable totes adorned with sea creatures!

- Summer

item.title: The American Heiress
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Be careful what you wish for. Traveling abroad with her mother at the turn of the twentieth century to seek a titled husband, beautiful, vivacious Cora Cash, whose family mansion in Newport dwarfs the Vanderbilts’, suddenly finds herself Duchess of Wareham, married to Ivo, the most eligible bachelor in England. Nothing is quite as it seems, however: Ivo is withdrawn and secretive, and the English social scene is full of traps and betrayals. Money, Cora soon learns, cannot buy everything, as she must decide what is truly worth the price in her life and her marriage.
Witty, moving, and brilliantly entertaining, Cora’s story marks the debut of a glorious storyteller who brings a fresh new spirit to the world of Edith Wharton and Henry James.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
A little bit Edith Wharton a little bit Jane Austen. Set at the turn of the 20th century, this novel is a fun journey through lavish mansions, dark English halls and dreamy landscapes as wealthy American Cora Cash (or rather her mother on her behalf) seeks a titled European husband.

– Summer

item.title: Maine
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Three generations of women converge on the family beach house in this wickedly funny, emotionally resonant story of love and dysfunction from the author of the bestselling debut novel Commencement.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
A summer read about three generations of Kelleher women who have little in common, except that they happen to be family and have convened at their family summer home in Maine for decades.

Catholic guilt mixed with strong drinks and strong women, plus plenty of sibling rivalry, makes for an entertaining read.

item.title: The State of Wonder
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Ann Patchett raises the bar with State of Wonder, a provocative and ambitious novel set deep in the Amazon jungle. Research scientist Dr. Marina Singh is sent to Brazil to track down her former mentor, Dr. Annick Swenson, who seems to have disappeared in the Amazon while working on an extremely valuable new drug. The last person who was sent to find her died before he could complete his mission. Plagued by trepidation, Marina embarks on an odyssey into the insect-infested jungle in hopes of finding answers to the questions about her friend's death, her company's future, and her own past. Once found, Dr. Swenson is as imperious and uncompromising as ever. But while she is as threatening as anything the jungle has to offer, the greatest sacrifices to be made are the ones Dr. Swenson asks of herself, and will ultimately ask of Marina. State of Wonder is a world unto itself, where unlikely beauty stands beside unimaginable loss. It is a tale that leads the reader into the very heart of darkness, and then shows us what lies on the other side.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
A pharmaceutical researcher, Dr. Marina Singh, lands in a 'Heart of Darkness' style ethical Amazonian jungle to investigate and hopefully find a colleague of hers who has turned up mysteriously dead. While there she uncovers an unorthodox cure for infertility and adventure ensues! A must read for summer.

– Summer

item.title: Faith
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: One woman's search for the truth after scandal rocks her family, and the explosive family secrets she uncovers, in this complex, moving fourth novel from a bestselling and award-winning author.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The Irish-American McGann family of Boston is rocked by scandal when gentle brother Art, a beloved Catholic priest, is accused of molesting a child. Art's sister sets out to find the truth and begins to discover long-buried family secrets. An elegantly written book you will not want to put down.

– Summer

item.title: Bill Cunningham New York
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Bill Cunningham is a fashion photographer, but unlike most in his profession, he rarely spends a day in a photo studio. Cunningham's work has been a long-time fixture in The New York Times; in his "Evening Hours" column, he presents pictures he's snapped of the wealthy and influential and what they're wearing to social events, while "On the Street" documents bold and individual looks worn by everyday people on the sidewalks of New York City. Cunningham captures the glamorous lives of others and has been hailed as one of the most important men in New York fashion, yet he prefers to live a simple life – he rides a bicycle around town, makes his home in a modest apartment, has his film processed at a corner store, and keeps his personal life to himself. Filmmaker Richard Press offers a look into the life and art of this influential and enigmatic figure in the documentary BILL CUNNINGHAM NEW YORK, which follows him as he works and tries to reveal what makes this unique artist tick. BILL CUNNINGHAM NEW YORK was an official selection at the 2010 Silverdocs Documentary Film Festival.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
There never was a soul like Bill Cunningham. Famed for his candid fashion photography for The New York Times, Cunningham loves fashion and people so much he said, "Never take money doing what you love, that way no one can tell you what to do."

He's an icon of the fashion world and one can't but help fall in love with him, fashion and New York after seeing this film. Pure joy!

– Summer

item.title: Untold Story
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: When Princess Diana died in Paris's Alma tunnel, she was thirty-seven years old. Had she lived, she would turn fifty on July 1, 2011. Who would the beloved icon be if she were alive today? What would she be doing? And where? One of the most versatile and bold writers of our time, Monica Ali has imagined a different fate for Diana in her spectacular new novel, Untold Story.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This book asks, what if Princess Di faked her death and was still alive today? Where would she be and why did she do it?

"The People's Princess" was humiliated in her personal life from the start of her marriage yet fiercely adored by the public. The contradictions of her life seemed to push her to behave recklessly, especially at the end of her life – or at least what we believe to be the end of her life. A fascinating page-turner.

item.title: Swamplandia!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The Bigtree alligator wrestling dynasty is in decline, and Swamplandia!, its island home and gator-wrestling theme park, is swiftly being encroached upon by a competitor. To save her family, Ava must journey on her own to a perilous part of the swamp called the Underworld.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Meet the Bigtree clan: A family of 5 inhabiting a tiny island (Swamplandia!) in the forgotten Everglades of Florida. They run an alligator wrestling park for tourists (the matriarch Hilola is the star wrestler) and live by their own rules. When tragedy hits the island, it's up to each of the 3 children to try and make sense of it – which leads to some wild adventures on and off Swamplandia!

– Summer

An intricately woven tale of love and loss that centers around an antique desk once owned by Federico García Lorca. Lorca was a great poet and dramatist who was one of thousands executed by Fascists in 1936, when the Spanish Civil War began. This book examines how we respond to loss and tragedy, and it calls up memories of how we were treated as children and how we treat our own.

– Summer

Kevin Wilson is fast becoming my favorite Southern Writer. You will fall in love with the dysfunctional “Fang” Family and all the eccentric schemes they produce. This book is a work of brilliance and unsurpassed imagination.

– Summer

Operating Instructions is one of the funniest books I've ever read -- and I've read quite a few books! This is the most honest, open account of what having a newborn is like, with a self-depricating humor that had me literally in tears from laughter. Lamott also touches on single parenthood, cancer and religion. If you've ever had a child, or hope to one day, do not miss this book.

– Summer

A raw tale of a family that doesn't have much. With their mother's death 9 years ago Esch, Randall, Skeetah and Junior live in the tiny coastal Mississippi town of Bois Sauvage with their hard drinking father who offers little in the way of parental guidance, money or concern. They rely on their friends, talents and schemes to get them through life. As Katrina barrels through, they realize the importance of their family and community. Ward gives a fascinating account of the days 12 days before, during and after the storm that will stay with you long after you've read this book.

-Summer

A wonderful book loosely based on author Flannery O'Connor and her Georgia hometown where she returned due to her illness. Cookie Himmel and Flannery grew up together. Cookie was everything Flannery was not: beautiful, popular and engaged to a wealthy New Yorker who moved back to town with her to start their life. An unlikely (and unwelcome) friendship evolves between Cookie's fiancé and Flannery that will bring along consequences you could never imagine. This book illuminates how living life true to ourselves, and second chances, are possible even if we think they're not.

-Summer

Design*Sponge is one of my favorite blogs and one of the most popular home design sites ever. Now blogger/design guru Grace Bonney is giving her fans even more inspiration in this much-anticipated book. Chock-full of home interior tours, projects and tutorials, this is the home décor bible for the DIY generation.

-Summer

The morning after a particularly dramatic marital spat, the family's live-in maid awakens to an empty house -- except for the two little boys she barely knows, whose parents are unreachable. This beautifully written book calls attention to modern issues like immigration and examines the consequences of trying to “keep up with the Joneses" and rising from the class you were born in. A social satire of the ages, West Coast style.

-Summer

Preserve your favorite vintage with these colorful stoppers. The stoppers form an airtight seal that won't leak, even if you lay your bottles down in the fridge. Stock up on these for your next party!

-Summer

You’ll love this innovative mousepad. Write a shopping list or jot down a reminder with this elegant notepad mousepad by New Orleans designer Alexa Pulitzer.

-Summer

Based on the hilarious website Awkward Family Photos, this game is non-stop party fun. First you'll laugh at the photos, and then you'll laugh at the open-ended question on the back of the card. And if your friends are anything like mine, the answers will have you crying tears of laughter. So much fun and a great icebreaker!

-Summer

I love charades, but this game takes the classic diversion to a whole new level. Teams act out as many words as possible in one minute, while one player guesses. Fun for all ages!

-Summer

Beanie Babies don't get any cuter than this tiny version of the classic sock monkey we all grew up with. A great gift for the young and young at heart.

-Summer

Kids say the darnedest things! With this handy journal, parents can jot down all the funny little sayings their children come up with, or remember questions or conversations that warm the heart. This wonderful keepsake makes a great gift for any parent.

-Summer

A mysterious old hermit, Felix "Bush" Breazeale, in 1930's Tennessee decides to throw his own funeral while he's still alive. Anticipation runs high before the big funeral as Felix is raffling off all his land, but the real reason for the funeral is to give him a chance to reveal a secret he's kept for 40 years. Robert Duvall, Sissy Spacek and Bill Murray make up the amazing cast.

-Summer

British filmmaker Mike Leigh delivers another brilliant and shockingly honest film about ordinary people in this dramatic comedy about an older couple, their friends, family and coworkers.

-Summer

Enjoy a Scandinavian tradition with these clever whiskey stones. Freeze the stones, then drop three in your dram of whiskey to slightly chill it without diluting the spirit.

-Summer

Jonathan Adler's iconic patterns and colors give these agendas a fresh, modern feel. Even if you're permanently tethered to your iPhone or Blackberry, you'll want to keep one of these colorful agendas tucked in your handbag or desk.

-Summer

Who could resist these cute owl paperweights? An antique copper finish gives them a vintage feel, and they have a nice heft – perfect for keeping that pile of papers on your desk stylishly contained or simply adding some whimsy to a room.

-Summer

Stressed out at work? Put down that stress ball and pick up the amazing Buckycubes, a cool little desk toy you can bend, twist and shape into whatever you can dream up. Made of 125 rare-earth magnets, the chrome Buckycubes look stylish on your desk, plus they're great fun. My new favorite time waster!

-Summer

Buck Brannaman is a true cowboy, a man whose spirit is as big as the West. Buck is the inspiration for The Horse Whisperer, and his way with troubled animals (and their owners) is amazing. This beautiful documentary follows Buck as he gives clinics all over the country, and talks to him about his horrific past and how he became the man he is today. A must-see film that will inspire you!

-Summer

British sensation Adele's second album is nothing short of breathtaking. After winning a Grammy for her debut album 19, Adele follows up that performance with an album filled with soon-to-be classics. With influences from soul, R&B, country, blues and more, this album transcends genre. This is music that every generation can listen to and love.

-Summer

As you would expect from the writer and star of 30 Rock, this memoir is filled with funny stories. Tina's wholesome-but-hilarious childhood, her years with comedy troupe Second City and a behind-the-scenes look at her famous take on Sarah Palin are all hilarious. But Bossypants is also surprisingly moving when she talks about family and friends, and even wise when she dispenses career advice. If you're a fan of Tina Fey, you must read this book. If you're not a Tina Fey fan, you'll become one after reading this book!

-Summer

Satisfy a sweet tooth calorie-free with these adorable dessert keychains. From the always delightful line of Yummy sculptures, these keychains feature googly eyes and sweet grins. The keychains are blind boxed, meaning you won't know which one you've got until you open the box – you'll want to collect them all!

-Summer

From the man who brought us The Virgin Suicides and Middlesex comes a novel based on the love triangle of three Brown University students. Touching on topics like sexual equality, pre-nups and divorce, this book examines what it's like to be fresh out of college and making adult decisions about career, love and life when you're not truly ready or equipped. Great read and another success by Eugenides.

-Summer

Libbie Summers knows her way around every cut of pork. In this imaginative, witty cookbook, Summers shares recipes for everything from homemade sausage (so worth it) to creative ways with pork belly, all accompanied by beautiful photography. It’s so good, you'll want to read it cover to cover – and cook snout to tail, too.

-Summer

For over 120 years, Vogue has been the first word in fashion, setting the standard for what's chic – beginning with the very cover of the magazine. This gorgeous book is filled the best Vogue covers, many of them iconic, all of them revolutionary. Featuring the work of such artists as Irving Penn, Richard Avedon and Herb Ritts, Vogue: The Covers is an essential book for lovers of art and fashion.

-Summer

In January 1964, mere months after the assassination of her husband, Jacqueline Kennedy sat down with distinguished historian Arthur Schlesinger to record her thoughts on her late husband's life and legacy. These intimate interviews are astonishing in their scope and detail, covering everything from JFK's reading habits to Vietnam and the Cuban Missile Crisis. Moving and awe-inspiring, the book is a must-read for students of history and fans of the indomitable Jacqueline Kennedy.

-Summer

After taking a year-long break from music, Feist is back with a great new album. Metals is a rougher, more subdued album than her previous ones. This indie artist is one of the most talented on the scene.

-Summer

This book about an extramarital affair examines how the forces of attraction can send your life into mayhem against your own better judgment. Enright sets this novel in her native Ireland and parallels the infidelity with her country's recent economic situation. Her novel The Gathering won the Man Booker Prize in 2007 and she brings the same honest writing to her latest work.

-Summer

No other museum contains as many famous painting masterpieces as the Louvre, and no other book has ever attempted to contain them all – until now. This historic book features all 3,022 paintings in the museum's permanent collection, beautifully photographed and fully annotated. Even better, the book includes a DVD-ROM that allows you to “browse” the collections as if you're walking through the Louvre room by room. The next best thing to a trip to Paris.

-Summer

Kevin Kline plays George, a divorced architect who has drifted away from his family and is unhappy with his life. Then George gets some unexpected news and decides he needs to get his life in order. He tears down the old shack his father willed to him and builds a new house, all while attempting to rebuild the relationship with his son. A masterpiece of storytelling, with brilliant acting from Kline and Hayden Christensen as his son Sam.

-Summer

Ewan McGregor winningly plays Oliver, a sensitive artist dealing with the death of his father, who, following the death of his wife of 45 years, decided to come out of the closet. Oliver's struggle with commitment, and his complicated but loving relationship with his father, are seen through flashbacks, and take the viewer on a journey of the many facets of love. What is love, what does it look and feel like? And is love worth the struggle or not? An excellent cast, led by the estimable Christopher Plummer as Hal, and a moving script based on real-life events in the director's life make this one of the best films of 2011.

-Summer

Paul Rudd – possibly the most charming actor of his generation – is at his best in this quirky comedy. Playing the “idiot brother” Ned of the title, Rudd conveys an authentic sweetness as he trips up the ordered lives of his three sisters. Ned's interactions with his sisters (Elizabeth Banks, Emily Mortimer and Zooey Deschanel) are some of the best scenes in the movie. A great film that demonstrates believing the best in people is actually rather wise.

-Summer

Edwards Burns wrote, directed and stars in this insightful look at a couple attempting a "conflict-free" marriage. Shot on a miniscule budget with a tiny crew, the film's documentary style feels incredibly intimate, and the insights into the nature of relationships are bittersweet. Burns has always been favorite actor of mine, and this indie gem proves he's a star at writing and directing, too.

-Summer

The comedian and actress Ali Wentworth's hilarious memoir is filled with laugh-out-loud moments. Ali shares funny, intimate accounts of her very interesting life, from growing up a natural performer in a family of WASPs (her mother was Reagan's social secretary) to working with some colorful characters in LA. Reading Ali's uproarious tales is like hearing stories from a friend -- your funniest and most outrageous friend.

-Summer

A wedding is usually a joyous celebration, but not if you're a member of this dysfunctional family. Lynn's estranged son is getting married, and when the whole family gathers for the occasion, long-held grievances threaten to destroy the day (and the rest of Lynn's sanity). Lynn is played by the amazing Ellen Barkin, who gives an Oscar-worthy performance, but the entire cast -- including Demi Moore, Thomas Haden Church and Ellen Burstyn -- is sensational.

-Summer

In this captivating debut novel, Erin Morgenstern has woven a tale of wonder and magic that you'll find impossible to put down. Celia and Marco are competitors in a mysterious game that neither of them know the rules to, and the circus is their arena. Can their love withstand the dangers of the game? The enchanting world of The Night Circus will enthrall you with tales of the circus and a host of colorful characters. A delight from beginning to end!

-Summer

The prolific singer-songwriter is back in top form with this album of quieter, mellower music.

-Summer

Since the late 19th century, London-based Liberty has been designing some of the world’s most iconic textiles. Send an unforgettable note with these notecards embellished with some of Liberty’s fabulous prints.

-Summer

Store your great ideas – or just those important documents – on this quirky portable flash drive. Housed in a soft, adorable monkey with a handy key ring, this is one flash drive you won’t misplace.

-Summer

Beyond the retro-cool factor, this handset is comfortable to use and gives calls a crystal clear quality. The Pop Phone works with all mobile phones as well as your computer and is the new 'it' accessory to have.

-Summer

Let your little one's imagination run wild with this ingenious activity book. Would she rather solve a mystery or go on an adventure? Would he rather be a wizard of magician? These "this or that" choices soon have your child writing and thinking creatively -- and having fun while doing it! Super cute illustrations and loads of stickers add to the fun.

-Summer

The Shins’ much-anticipated latest album will be overjoyed with this stellar effort. Though the band has replaced some original members, the razor-sharp lyrics and infectious hooks are still there. A playful but complex album.

-Summer

Story Cubes are an award-winning way to learn language or express yourself creatively. Like the original Story Cubes, the nine Actions Cubes dice feature unique icons in place of words. Just roll the dice and tell your story! The Actions Cubes are a great add-on to the original Story Cubes set for more engaging language play.

-Summer

Bold prints from international textiles designer Liberty adorn these slim journals. Tuck one in your bag for jotting down notes in style.

-Summer

Put yourself or your favorite know-it-all to the test with the Pocket IQ Test! The kit includes two sets of questions with answers and a scoring system. Challenge someone to a battle of wits, or just challenge yourself with the 60 unique Q&A cards.

-Summer

Season 3 of the multiple award-winning Mad Men left viewers with a shocking cliffhanger. With Season 4, we get to watch the dapper Don Draper suffer for his mistakes (and we suffer along with him). Meanwhile, the brilliant Peggy is coming into her own and Joan continues to dazzle. Mad Men just gets better every season, and Season 4 proves once again why it’s the best show on television.

-Summer

Julia Win’s influential lawyer father disappears without a trace shortly after her law school graduation. After receiving a box of her father’s papers -- including a mysterious love letter that leads her to his homeland of Burma – Julia is determined to find him. What Julia finds in Burma is pure magic, a captivating love story that transcends time and country. Without a doubt one of the most fantastically romantic novels I’ve ever had the pleasure of reading.

-Summer

item.title: A Lady Cyclist's Guide to Kashgar
item.dc:creator: admin

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
A fascinating story that alternates between two times and places. Take an amazing journey through the desert wilds of western China in the 1920's with a missionary and two sisters, one on a religious journey and the other along for the adventure. The second plot follows Frieda, a modern career woman in London whose life changes when she inherits the heirlooms of a dead woman she never knew. To add to the intrigue, a homeless Yemeni immigrant shows up at her doorstep and becomes an unlikely friend. The historical narrative and the contemporary storyline are woven together flawlessly in this highly original book.

-Summer

The story of Bit, a child born in a hippie commune in upstate New York, will stay with you for a very long time. We follow Bit from childhood to middle age, while the commune reaches its heyday and its eventual demise. Along the way is a rich, poignant story – a story that really forces you to slow down and truly see the world through Bit’s eyes. One of the best books I’ve read in years!

-Summer

The luminous Michelle Williams pulls off some Hollywood magic as she plays – no, she embodies – the most beloved screen goddess of all time. Williams creates a believable, empathetic portrait of Marilyn without ever resorting to impersonation. One of the greatest performances of the year!

-Summer

The ever-amazing George Clooney plays Matt King, a real estate attorney in Hawaii whose wife is in a coma from a boating accident. Matt attempts to connect with his two willful young daughters, who he hasn’t had much time for. But when Matt finds out his wife had a devastating secret, he and his daughters embark on a quest of sorts, one that is by turns tragic and funny. An understated character study that is quietly powerful and completely unforgettable.

-Summer

item.title: Hotel on the Corner of Bitter and Sweet
item.dc:creator: admin

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
I was immediately hooked on the story of Henry Lee, a 50-something Chinese-American man who comes upon what might be a lost relic from his past. Henry grew up in Seattle as the world was going to war. Henry develops a sweet friendship with Keiko, a Japanese girl at his school, despite Henry’s father’s hatred of the Japanese. As Henry struggles against the cultural divide and his own father, love and friendships are formed that can never be broken. A lovely story of humanity in a dark period of our country.

-Summer

There is nothing sexier than a tomboy and this book celebrates women who have 'borrowed from the boys' across the decades and made us all swoon. Rebels, sophisticates, prepsters and adventurers are just a few types celebrated in "Tomboy Style." The vintage pictures of tomboy icons like Ali Macgraw, Diane Keaton ,Caroline Bassett-Kennedy and current icons like Alexa Chung will inspire you to your re-think your wardrobe in such a way that you will be exuding confidence you didn't know you possessed.

A word of warning about Suzanne Collins' best-selling trilogy: You won't be able to sleep until you reach the thrilling conclusion! The Hunger Games is a non-stop page turner, with a captivating heroine fighting for survival in a brutal dystopian world. Do yourself a favor and buy all three - trust me, you won't be able to put them down! - Summer
The Toronto-based Afie Jurvanen is out with a great new album 'Barchords.' The whole album has an amazing sound and it's really helping me ease into my days lately. Buy and enjoy - Summer

After having her first child, Pamela Druckerman, an American journalist living in Paris, notices that French children seem better behaved and French parents much calmer than their American counterparts. Could the French mystique extend to parenting as well? In this enlightening and highly enjoyable read, Druckerman shares the wisdom of French parenting through personal observation and witty stories of her own life and those of her French friends. - Summer

Hot band Alabama Shakes are known for their energetic live shows and their debut album captures much of that Southern magic. Rootsy and cool, but with a progressive edge, “Boys and Girls” is a thrill. Singer Brittany Howard’s soulful voice will make you happy. - Summer

Commemorate Queen Elizabeth II’s amazing 60-year reign with this cheeky limited edition figure. A solar panel on her handbag keeps her waving (in her iconic way) without batteries. God save the queen! - Summer

What drew me to this book was its touchy subject matter & how if we can try to understand people, even the lepers of our society, it can help us see the world in a different light. Pedophilia will make even the desynthestized squirm & to learn that the protagonist in this novel was both a sex offender and a virgin was intriguing to me. This book is about the people in our society who have fallen through the cracks. - Summer

item.title: Paris, I Love You But You're Bringing Me Down
item.dc:creator: athompson

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This is for all you Francophiles out there. This book is a hilarious romp through Paris by a guy who hardly spoke the language and by sheer luck gets an advertising job in Paris. He packs up his Brooklyn apartment, wife in tow, to life the dream in the City of Lights. I love that this book gives you a peek into modern day France and all that is modern and traditional, hilarious and infuriating messed up, just plain wrong and oh so right. Funny and fun; 'Paris I Love You But You're Bringing Me Down' is a cultural adventure for all the lovers of Paris and who doesn't love Paris!? - Summer

This is a dizzying & magical novel, loosely based off 'A Midsummer Night's Dream.' Three heartbroken strangers, all going to the same party get caught up in San Franciso's Buena Vista Park & also become entangled in faerie uprising stirred up by Titania who is in remorse over her mortal son's death & the end of her marriage. Adrian's book is incredibly smart an imaginative- it's a wild ride! - Summer

A great summer read about the almost-love affair that begins on the Italian coast in 1962 between a beautiful American starlet and a young Italian and is rekindled in Hollywood fifty years later. - Summer

A brilliantly written novel that explores the painful awkwardness of a family vacation between two siblings trying to rebuild a relationship they've both abandoned since childhood directly following their mother's death. Richard a well-off doctor with a new wife and her mean-spirited daughter and Angela his sister, her unemployed husband and their three children together in a house in the english countryside for a week. Be prepared to become completely absorbed! - Summer

This is an extraordinary story about a little known part of history that occurred on the Hawaiian Island of Moloka'i over a century ago. Rachel Kalama, a vivacious seven year old girl, who loves her home and family, one day discovers a suspicious lesion on her skin, and then another. Her mother tries to hide these marks with clothes and shoes but its just a matter of time until she taken from her family and sent to the quarantined leprosy establishment on an island far away from everything she knows. This is a story of remarkable kindness, hope and re-birth. - Summer

Dellarobia Turnbow got married way too young for the wrong reason. She lives on her in-laws farm in small town Tennessee tied down with two small children and a passionless marriage feeling her life is slipping away. On her way to fraternize with a much younger man who is not her husband Dellarobia stumbles, literally, on a natural miracle which she takes as a sign and turns herself around and heads back to the life she was running from. The town is turned upside down & Dellarobia is thrust into spotlight as national news trucks arrive to interview the woman who stumbled upon a phenomenon. Her unconventional friend Dovey, her bitter mother in law, a powerful preacher and a sexy scientist all converge to make 'Flight Behavior' one to read. - Summer

item.title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out of the Window and Disappeared
item.dc:creator: athompson

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This book is an international sensation that has hit the states! Swedish author Jonas Jonasson has created an highly imagined and interesting book that feels like a guilty pleasure it's so good. Allan Karlsson will be your new hero as you travel through his long life Forrest Gump-style but with atom bombs and copious amounts of vodka. What more could you want in a book? - Summer

item.title: Etcetera : Creating Beautiful Interiors with the Things You Love
item.dc:creator: athompson

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: I have fallen in love with Sibella Court and all that she creates. Etcetera is pure heaven for collectors, dreamers and lovers of fancy that relates to the home. This book is about making your home very personal without spending much money by displaying things you've picked up from your travels (on the beach or a market in Morocco) or maybe a gift from an old love that will find a special place. Beautifully done and freely written, I was inspired from the start to pull out old keepsakes and pepper them around the house. - Summer

Julian Barnes won the Man Booker prize in 2011 for 'Sense of an Ending' and for good reason, what a book! Tony Webster, a careful divorced father in his 60's is piecing together his past prompted by a gift left to him by the mother of an ex-girlfriend he met only once concerning the suicide of his best friend in school, Andrian. Tony and Adrian have more in common than a tightly knit clique of adolescent friends, they also dated the same girl. What Tony remembers happening all those years ago when Adrian announces he is dating Veronica and the series of events that actually happened are quite different. Time and ego's have a way of helping shape the truth into something that's not at all that. The unexpected ending will leave you rethinking the novel and it's characters in whole new light after the last page. Bravo!

I'm not one to gravitate to a novel about sports but a good friend assured me it was a must-read. It is as much about baseball as it is about truths, relationships, dreams and college life. As we settle into fall who doesn't want to evoke a little nostalgia from those unforgettable years at university? Harbach, a first time author, has proven he has the stuff with a beautiful and poignant character driven novel. - Summer
Kids' tea time is even more fun with this cute tea set. Made from recycled milk jugs, the cups are safe to drink from and contain no BPAs, phthalates, or lead paint.

Photographer Richard Selby has taken viewers inside the homes of the rich and famous and not-so-famous, and now he turns his lens on the kitchens, gardens, restaurants and homes of the food world’s culinary darlings. Signature recipes accompany the stunning photos, which capture these creative people in settings that are a feast for the eyes. I met Eric and Mya (who grace the cover) at their restaurant Hartwood in Tulum a few years ago and the food and atmosphere were truly amazing. I went back every night I loved it so much! - Summer

Vintage covers from classic novels like Moby Dick and The Great Gatsby make these hard-bound journals a great place to write your own story. An old-style library book card inside the front cover and lined paper with actual text (you’ll probably spend some time with a magnifying glass) give these journals even more appeal. - Summer

Six-year-old Hushpuppy lives in devastated Louisiana settlement “on the wrong side of the levee” called The Bathtub. The film is told entirely from her point of view, which often blurs the line between fantasy and reality. Hushpuppy is played by Quvenzhané Wallis, a non-professional actor (like all the others in the film) and her magnetic performance is nothing short of devastating. It’s a film full of mystery and complexity that absolutely must be seen. This was my favorite film from Sundance last year. - Summer

I’ve been completely obsessed by this gorgeous British period drama since the first episode! The series has everything a costume drama needs: a stellar cast headed by the indomitable Dame Maggie Smith as the Dowager Countess (who steals every scene she’s in), beautiful costumes and scenery and plotlines concerning love, betrayal and the events of the era. If you haven’t been watching, now’s the time to find out what everyone’s been talking about.

This funny and inspiring book is an interesting take on street style. Andrea Linnett, co-founder of Lucky magazine, shares memories of growing up and the women who inspired her style through little stories about each woman. The illustrations that accompany the stories are fun, and Linnett’s writing is simple and to the point. By the end, I felt I’d read a true account from a very fashionable friend. - Summer

Made from sustainably harvested beech wood, the Micro Cubebot puzzles are as environmentally-friendly as they are cute and addictively fun. The little Cubebot can hold a variety of poses and his elastic bands protect his “muscles” from breakage. You’ll want to pilfer these from the kids, so buy some for yourself, too. - Smmer

item.title: Love Looks Not With the Eyes
item.dc:creator: athompson

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Alexander McQueen was a designer on unparalleled virtuosity, whose creations have become not just fashion but high art. Gorgeous, behind-the-scenes photographs from McQueen’s shows show the artist at work with his equally famous collaborators, crafting fashion shows that would dazzle their audience. A beautiful tribute to an icon of the industry and one of the most coveted books I own. - Summer

This year marks Vogue’s 120th anniversary, and what better time to celebrate the world’s most influential fashion magazine? In Vogue: The Editor’s Eye, we get insight into the work that goes into creating the fashion images in every issue. The book focuses on 8 of Vogue’s most legendary fashion editors, with accompanying photographs and illustrations that demonstrate the incredible creativity and influence of these visionaries. - Summer

These hats are pure ridiculousness! Each set includes 8 multicolored paper party hats with attached elastic bands. Put your hats together, then write something funny on them to get the party started. - Summer

For 50 years, the Rolling Stones have represented rock and roll in all its glory, excess and excitement. Now this magnificent book pays tribute to the Stones with over 1,000 rare photographs never before published. This lush treasure trove is a must-have for Stones fans and anyone interested in the heritage of rock music. - Summer

Write notes, doodle, draw or just go where your imagination takes you with the Boogie Board LCD tablet. This modern tablet lets you write or draw with a finger or stylus. Need to start over? Just erase with the touch of a button! The shatter-proof screen and case mean you can take this board anywhere you need to go.

Thomas Keller’s Bouchon Bakery is famous for its pastries and confections based on French technique, but with a thoroughly American sweet tooth (Keller has created his own versions of Oreos and Ho Hos). I used to get my coffee and croissant here every morning so it has a special place in my heart. Get out the flour and get ready to make tarts, breads, pastries and more that look (and taste!) like the creations of a stellar chef. - Summer

item.title: Barefoot Contessa Foolproof: Recipes You Can Trust
item.dc:creator: athompson

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Few celebrity chefs have earned the utter devotion from fans like the Barefoot Contessa Ina Garten. Her latest volume shows home cooks how to pull off “foolproof” meals featuring quality ingredients and Ina’s best kitchen secrets. Ina never disappoints and manages to help your meals be simple, seem effortless and always so tasty. - Summer

Take your favorite book to the park, the market, school, a restaurant – or wherever you may roam with these very cool tote bags. Featuring classic literary covers, the heavyweight cotton canvas bags let you declare your love for reading in a practical way. - Summer

Whether you are on the path to unconditional happiness or just wanted to live a more examined life this is the book for you. It opens up the possibility of a life lived without limitations and one where inner peace is attainable. How can we better deal with our personal struggles and the life when it gets bumpy? This book will offer a new revelation page after page; I underlined 75% of the book and continue to reference it when I need some clarity. Singer is a true genius! - Summer
These colorful little notebooks keep your notes and lists right where you need them. The matchbook-style covers feature gold lettering for some extra panache.
Shine a little light. These adorable, rechargeable flashlights fit in a pocket, purse or child’s backpack. My oldest daughter is obsessed with hers. Twist their heads and let there be light!

Following the rags-to-riches success story of David and Jackie Siegel, Queen of Versailles represents the inherent flaws of the American Dream. As the Seigels are building their 90,000 square foot dream home in Florida, which was to be the largest single- family home in America, the market comes crashing down and they are forced to make tough decisions. Equal parts sad, funny and appalling, the documentary shows the Seigels as often likable, but irresponsible, humans caught up in a cycle of wretched excess. - Summer

This book is a guilty pleasure and you won't be able stop thinking about it until you've read the last page! Gone Girl is about a marriage gone horribly wrong. From Manhattan to North Carthage, Missouri you will follow Nick and Amy's courtship, marriage and move to middle America when things start to happen that you won't believe. It gives new definition to the saying 'Love Hurts." - Summer
Charming illustrations adorn these 85-sheet desk notepads. Keep these by the phone, on your desk, or any other surface where you need paper with a bit more style. - Summer

The Art Book introduced millions of people to the greatest works of art in a fun, accessible way. Now the new edition has even more to love, with 600 artists from a variety of mediums listed A to Z. Art appreciation has never been easier, or more engrossing. This is one coffee table book that will get much love, and is a great gift for everyone you know. - Summer

A wonderful collection of short stories inspired by various newspaper articles and stories from the last four centuries, the characters from each having something in common, going . . . Astray. I started reading this solely because I loved Donoghue's debut novel, "Room" so much and I wasn’t aware Astray was a collection of short stories. I loved the macabre in each story, which reminded me of all southern gothic literature I'm such a fool for. After each story was a factual bit of newspaper or historical source which was my favorite part so I could see the origin she began crafting her stories. Fascinating! - Summer

This set contains every episode from the first season of the critically-respected series HOMELAND, starring Claire Danes as a self-destructive CIA agent who begins to suspect that a veteran, who was held as a POW, may in fact be a terrorist instead of the war hero the media has made him out to be.

A wild ride from one of Japan's most highly regarded authors. Dreamlike and surreal, this story follows a marriage on the skids and and amazing cast of bizarre characters that will keep you intrigued. - Summer
“What would you attempt if you knew you could not fail” says this elegantly minimalist pencil box. If that isn’t enough to inspire you then I don't know what will. - Summer

I dearly love this book with all my heart. I will be giving this to all my friends for Christmas and can't wait to talk with them about their thoughts. Grace Coddington's sharp whit and personality full of whimsy comes through the pages of this wonderful memoir. - Summer

Three jaded journalists decide to take a closer look into the story behind a strange classified ad -- a man seeks someone to travel back in time with him. Amazing performances by some extremely gifted actors and a heartfelt script make this indie film a must-see. A beautiful, simple and engaging movie that I guarantee you will love. - Summer

The need to believe in humanity is greater now than ever before and reading this tale about lives lived simply is so lovely. - Summer A beautiful account of a friendship between two couples that is so genuine and vivid that you feel you could have easily been one of the characters in this classic piece of literature. Wallace Stegner is a man I have only just discovered and I'm anticipating more magic to be found in his extensive list of works. - Summer

There's not a single dud on this folksy, spirited album. If you like sweet melodies with heartfelt melodies and an upbeat mood (even on the ballads!), you'll love The Lumineers. My favorites are "Flowers in Your Hair" and "Dead Sea" but every song is a gem. - Summer

This novel about an Irish boarding school in the 21st century could be defining for its generation. Moving, funny and smart, "Skippy Dies" takes you back to what it feels like to be a teenager -- one minute you're on cloud 9 and the next your world can come crashing down around you. When a novel opens with its main character dead in a doughnut shop -- yes, Skippy does die, and quickly -- you know you're reading something different. But for a novel that opens with death, this beautiful book is so full of life. This is definitely one for the top 10 lists of the year. What a read! - Summer

Mature and mellow, "Bon Iver" is a dreamy listening experience. I say "experience" because from the first track, it's clear this is a different kind of album. The often-mystical lyrics are emotional and poetic, the instruments and voices flow beautifully from song to song. If you want to hear and feel what music can really do, this is it. This is an album that will stand the test of time. - Summer

After two friends recommended 'The Language of Flowers,' I picked it up before a post-Christmas getaway. I was instantly drawn in by the story based on a troubled orphan's discovery that it's never too late to learn to trust. After 18 years in the foster care system, Victoria can only truly communicate her feelings through the language of flowers and their different meanings. A beautifully unique story. - Summer

In her first album in over six years, Beth Orton has returned to her folksy roots. As a lifelong fan of Orton, I think this is her masterpiece -- a lush album full of sweet melodies and her lovely, fragile voice. A simply captivating album I listen to again and again. - Summer

Transport yourself deep into the Moroccan desert with David, a doctor, and Jo, a children's book author. The unhappy couple, who are hoping to escape there lives in London, have accepted the invitation of old friends, Richard and Dally, to feast, get high, dance and drink the weekend at their home with a host of other interesting characters. A shocking event sets the tone for the trip. Get ready, it's an adventure. -- Summer

Vanity Fair calls this book "A gorgeous, howling coming-of-age novel that will devour your heart." It will shock you, awaken you & show that the bar for literature has just been raised. Bravo to Torres, this book is something special. - Summer

I love this album -- every single tune is catchy and worthy of repeated listens. With infectious rhythms and thought-provoking lyrics, Foster the People has made radio-friendly pop music smart again. And the sunny Southern California vibe is great fun, too. - Summer

Anger is an emotion that can crop up and be nurtured without us even realizing it and next thing we know - we are in this state too often. Thich Nhat Hanh is a vietnamese monk who gives us insight into embracing and taking care of our anger instead of ignoring it. His amazing wisdom can transform the way you view yourself, your relationships and the world. This is a powerful piece of beauty. - Summer

A wonderfully quirky story about life, the family that enriches it and all the other people along the way who make it worth living. We follow the lives of Elly and her brother Joe from the late 60s to 9/11 New York. Though the book often deals with serious themes, it's the humor and beautiful writing that will draw you in. - Summer

The Specials were a hugely influential British band of the late 70s/early 80s. The band has combines reggae beats with razor-sharp lyrics that were often political in nature. There hasn't been another band like them since. This gem will be getting a special spot in my music collection this summer. - Summer

This fascinating look at winning and losing is chockful of eye-opening insights. I was especially intrigued by gender differences and how the order of your birth affects the chances you will most likely take or not take. These and many other interesting and sometimes counterintuitive observations make "Top Dog" an absolutely engaging read. - Summer

This book is the source of the famous quote which is often misattributed to Nelson Mandela, "'Our deepest fear is not that we are inadequate. Our deepest fear is that we are powerful beyond measure. It is our light, not our darkness, that most frightens us." Recommended to me by a friend, this book is Williamson's reflections on another book, "A Course In Miracles." I have not read that book yet but it is not a prerequisite to the magic of the concepts. At it's most basic, this book is about love and how it applies to the search for inner peace. - Summer

This astonishing debut novel is a journey of discovery as grieving mother Kate pieces together why her daughter Amelia took her own life. I was completely absorbed in the lives of Kate and Amelia, well-developed characters who seemed completely real. The novel touches on heavy themes -- bullying, suicide, sexuality, identity, secrets -- but it's never heavy handed. This is one novel that won't let you sleep until you've read through to the end. Sure to be one of the most talked about novels of the year. - Summer

Cold Specks is the stage name for Al Spx, a Canadian-born, UK-based musical force. She sings with a depth that belies her 24 years. Often compared to Stevie Nicks or a female Bon Iver, she brings a rich, bluesy force to her music. I predict we'll hear much more from this talented performer. - Summer

I loved poetry as a child. Recently I've come back to it and have been searching for different poets and was excited by Mary Oliver's work. Oliver is a wonderfully talented poet who, while new to me, has been a shining star in the literary world for some time. Her latest collection, 'A Thousand Mornings' feels largely like meditations on the natural world. She has a keen sense of observation and writes simply and beautifully. A wonderfully accessible collection filled with insights and delights. - Summer

An enchanting and gripping tale, this is a book you don't want to miss. Allende enchanted me with The House of the Spirits, and she has blown me away with the story of Maya Vidal. Maya is a teenage runaway who goes from living a healthy life with her grandparents in Berkley to falling into the hands of a drug dealer in Las Vegas to finally ending up, out of necessity, hiding on a tiny island off the coast of Chile. - Summer

Matthew McConaughey delivers the performance of a lifetime in this Twain-like tale of a fugitive hiding out on an uninhibited island on the Mississippi River. After discovering Mud (McConaughey) on the island, two boys -- Ellis and Neckbone -- help Mud concoct a plan to escape safely with his girlfriend Juniper, played by Reese Witherspoon. This movie was the best combination of a perfect story and incredible acting. - Summer

An empathetic portrait of three college friends living in Manhattan in the months before 9/11. Marina, Danielle and Julius are each having a quarter life crisis, trying to come to terms with where they thought they would be at 30 and where they actually are, professionally and personally. Messud paints an interesting portrait of a generation against a backdrop of New York City, before and after 9/11. - Summer

An absolutely beautiful book about the intersecting lives of unlikely people that makes life so captivating. Quiet and unsuspecting, this book draws you into its magic and leaves you feeling better about humanity than when you began. - Summer

Z is the story of Zelda Fitzgerald, this time from her point of view. This fun and fast summer read follows Zelda and Scott to parties in New York, Paris, Hollywood and the French Riviera. Pick this one up, you will be entertained! - Summer

Vampire Weekend’s third album is at once catchy and complex, with more depth than you’d expect from an ordinary indie-pop album. But this album, with its layered arrangements and soulful vocals, proves that Vampire Weekend is far above ordinary. - Summer

I find it baffling that a 29-year-old Chinese American from Queens could have mastered the art of writing a Southern Gothic tale of epic proportion, but master it he did. Reminiscent of Tennessee Williams or Flannery O'Connor, this book made me feel as though I was entering a dream world that is both familiar and unknowable, and also a bit magical. People are talking about this book for a reason. - Summer

I saw this documentary at its Sundance premiere last winter and just fell in love with it. This movie lifts the veil off a little known or talked about world that exists behind the main act: the backup singers. For years, these women have supported The Rolling Stones, Sting, The Talking Heads, Bruce Springsteen -- the list goes on and on. Prepare to be entertained and delighted! - Summer

Another fantastic book from Haruf takes us back to the high plains town of Holt, Colorado, as we continue our journey with the characters from Plainsong. These books have stolen my heart with their exploration of the human condition in everyday life, the things that connect us all no matter what time, place or demographic we hail from. - Summer

If you like Mumford & Sons or the more bluegrass feel of Old Crow Medicine Show, prepare to fall in love with this ten-member band. Their latest record, Better Days, was created after three years of touring and it's truly amazing. - Summer

This is a book that people are talking about. . . So you might want to set aside your typical beach read and fall into the world of '& Sons.' It is a world rooted by a famous 'Salinger-esque' novelist, A.N. Dyer, it's about Upper East Side New York, Fathers & Sons, Boarding schools, drug addiction, affairs, sibling rivalries, old loves, old friendships . . . Are you intrigued? You should be & you should read this book. It's got the great American novel thing going. - Summer

This is a book that people are talking about. . . So you might want to set aside your typical beach read and fall into the world of '& Sons.' It is a world rooted by a famous 'Salinger-esque' novelist, A.N. Dyer, it's about Upper East Side New York, Fathers & Sons, Boarding schools, drug addiction, affairs, sibling rivalries, old loves, old friendships . . . Are you intrigued? You should be & you should read this book. It's got the great American novel thing going. - Summer

Gilead is a meditation on the meaning of life, religion, race, family and war. You don't need to be a religious or spiritual person to appreciate this book as I think, essentially, we all ask the same questions. John Ames is a fourth generation preacher who, at 67, believes he is dying. He is writing a letter to his seven-year-old son which softly and beautifully tells his family history, often touching upon the complicated relationships between father and son. It's short on pages but not on substance. - Summer

I’ve been completely obsessed by this gorgeous British period drama since the first episode! The series has everything a costume drama needs: a stellar cast headed by the indomitable Dame Maggie Smith as the Dowager Countess (who steals every scene she’s in), beautiful costumes and scenery and plotlines concerning love, betrayal and the events of the era. If you haven’t been watching, now’s the time to find out what everyone’s been talking about. - Summer

A story of Amina, a young woman from Bangladesh caught between two worlds: the Bengali cocoon she has known her whole life and her new life in America. Raised the only child of doting if rather unlucky parents, Amina is a young bride who met her husband, George, just 11 months before on a dating website. Amina struggles to realize her parents' aspirations for their family's future and a part of her past she doesn't want to forget. Props to my sister for recommending this engrossing read! - Summer

Nominated for the Grand Jury Prize at Sundance this year, this movie follows a family as their identities and the roles they've played as siblings reverse. Abby (Rosemary Dewitt) is a massage therapist and free spirit where her brother Paul (Josh Pais) is an uptight dentist who still lives in their deceased parents home. When Abby is overcome by a strange and sudden aversion to bodily contact which disrupts not only her career but also her passionate relationship with her boyfriend and her brother accidentally cures a patient's TMJ, the role reversal is complete. This film is so touching in the way it examines how life can completely change in one instant and how these characters stay beautifully open to the possibilities. - Summer

Six young teens bond at a camp for the arts during the summer that Nixon resigns. The Interestings follows the friends through the decades, through marriage and children and into middle age in Manhattan. I was so engrossed in this book I unreachable for days and happily so. . . - Summer

A fascinating book based on the affair of Edgar Allen Poe and Francis Osgood, his mistress and a fellow poet and member New York's social elite. Throw in Edgar's sickly wife (a first cousin and 13 years his junior) Francis's philandering husband, a portrait artist who has abandoned her and their two daughters, plus the Bartletts – the family who took Francis and her daughters in – and you have a riveting tale that will keep you up all night until you read the last word. This is historical fiction at its finest and most fun! - Summer

John Currence is an old friend of mine. I can tell you with great confidence that this man is a savant in the kitchen, smart as hell and funny as the day is long. Mix all those ingredients together and you've got yourself a damn good cookbook that is not only a pleasure to cook from but also a lively read. Pickles, Pigs and Whiskey is a delight throughout! Cheers to you John . . . - Summer

item.title: How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia
item.dc:creator: athompson

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Written in the format of a self-help book, How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia is a cleverly conceived story with a narrator who describes how to make it big by scamming people. Set in a city based on Lahore, Pakistan, this book is fascinating and transporting. Our protagonist – a young man only known as “You”—leaves his hardscrabble small town life for the big city, falls in love with a pretty girl and dedicates his life to earning enough money to get his girl. But a different life than he planned ensues. The novel charts his rise and fall and, most importantly, his exit strategy. This book is a delight! - Summer

item.title: The Art of Simple Food II
item.dc:creator: athompson

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A beautiful and simple vegetable-focused cookbook from the iconic and brilliant Alice Waters. With her natural approach to cooking, this book will get you out to the farmer's market and into the kitchen with joy. - Summer

I've enjoyed every gem in this collection of stories by Alice Munro, one of the greatest contemporary writers. Munro is a maverick at making the mundane details of life interesting through her skilled writing and imagination. Most of the stories in this book are based on or inspired by her life growing up in rural Canada in her native country, the last four stories are autobiographical. Whether this is your first Munro book or if, like me, you've worn through many a copy of her earlier works, you'll find so much to astound you again and again. - Summer

item.title: The Impossible Lives of Greta Wells
item.dc:creator: athompson

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: If you like a little time travel, you'll love this book. Slipping between the years 1985, 1941 and 1918, Greta Wells bounces between different lives that could have been hers and, in many ways, are considering her ex-lover, twin brother and beloved aunt appear in all three timelines. An interesting tale that carried me from cover to cover in no time. - Summer

item.title: The Southerner's Handbook : A Guide to Living the Good Life
item.dc:creator: athompson

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: I know Southerners don't have it all figured out, but we sure as hell have some things to contribute! As Mr. John T Edge says, "In a region bound by a tragic past, we Southerners find common purpose in shared creations. Like Music. Like Art." The same goes for food, style, sport and, our crowning jewel, drink! With pieces from my favorite Southern lady, Julia Reed, recipes from my buddy and famed chef John Currence, this little gem is a must buy, whether you’re Southern, wish you were or just want to join the party. - Summer

Sara Polley and her family did a brave and brilliant thing, digging into their family's past and bringing forth all the secrets, lies and truths to create a powerful documentary. Stories We Tell puts families, in all their fabulous, maddening and fascinating glory, under the microscope. This spellbinding film will open your heart, change your perspective on the choices we make and give you faith that the universe has a way of working things out.

A Tennessee native, Valerie June has a magical quality to her music that draws you in and keeps you listening for days. Her music has notes of gospel, bluegrass and folk with inspirations reminiscent of Nina Simone, Van Morrison, Joplin, Hendrix and Nick Drake. This is a must-own album from a stunning new talent. - Summer

Here's to an 'it's all good lifestyle,' compliments of the coolest cat in town, Pete! My children adore this book. The world would be a better place if we could all raise our kids with Pete's no-worries view on life, I'm sure of it! - Summer

Norman Rush is a National Book Award Winner, so we would expect nothing less form him than an ambitious novel. “Subtle Bodies” is an interesting portrait of what happens when a close-knit group of friends come back together again in their mid-forties. The perfect book for the literature elitist in your life. - Summer

A string of gruesome murders committed against young, attractive women in Marin County nearly thirty years ago captivated the attention of two sisters living at the base of a mountain where many of the crimes were committed. Their father, a ladies man if there ever was one, is the homicide detective assigned to crack the case that altered the course of their lives forever.
This book kept me up at all hours of the night with feelings of fear and curiosity. - Summer
Such a beautiful and deep masterpiece. If I could listen to any album under water it would be this one. I don't know how else to explain it - the music is transfixing.

item.title: This Is How You Lose Her
item.dc:creator: aldaga

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: After I read Diaz's The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao, I fell in love with his Spanglish, free-flowing, jazz like writing. These stories all center around Yunior, and irresistible rascal who opens the door to knowing what it is to be a young Dominican man. He is reckless, passionate and always on the search for L-O-V-E. - Summer

item.title: Frida Kahlo : Painting Her Own Reality
item.dc:creator: aldaga

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Frida Kahlo has always been an inspiration and I thought it high time to represent her in my collection of loves. As a painter she was able to transcend pain and heartbreak, of which she had a considerable amount of in her short life, and translate that into her paintings. Most of her work constitutes of self-portrait’s that mirror back to her 'this is who I am.' Considered one of Mexico's greatest painters she represents strength, resilience, and joie de vivre. - Summer

This one's for the boys! Classic 60's road trip anthem for the beat generation. Very American, very reckless and an adventure if nothing else. This one has to be read at some point in your life so why not now? -Summer

These adorable figurines are the new thing to be treasured and collected. You cannot help but smile when you see a Sunny Angel with their charming animal head gear. Pick up a few today, they are sure to please toddlers and adults alike! -Summer

I am notorious for being a sleepy head, I know how hard it is people, I feel your pain. CLOCKY is here to save you from losing your jobs and prevent your children from getting detention. CLOCKY blares annoying beeps and honks and rolls onto the floor with its oversized wheels requiring to get your butt out of bed which, in my opinion, is the difference between winning and losing. I have tested Clocky on the toughest of customers, my 17 year old stepson, and I can assure you it works. -Summer
Express your amazingness with these fabulous new cases from Rifle Paper. You will be showing the world your classy self while chatting away . . . . -Summer

item.title: Modern Manners : Tools to Take You to the Top
item.dc:creator: aldaga

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: by Dorothea Johnson and Liv Tyler

Being a true southerner I was sent to 'charm' school as a child and pride myself on having been taught properly how to behave in a respectful nature. Not until I read this book did realize I was in need of a refresher! In this modern age it is more important than ever to remember or manners. A wonderful gift for graduates entering college or the real world and for us parents to keep ourselves in check while continuing to pass the tradition on to our children. Liv Tyler, spawn of Steven Tyler, co-wrote it with her grandmother which reiterates . . . it's cool to be polite. - Summer

item.title: Dog Songs : Thirty-Five Dog Songs and One Essay
item.dc:creator: aldaga

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: My favorite poet touches upon one of life's greatest gifts in her latest collection of poems. This is for the dog lover in your life. Her words remind us of the sheer magic of dogs. How lucky we are for her and for them. - Summer

A poetic and beautiful account, Just Kids, follows Patti Smith and Robert Mapplethorpe as they make their way through the magic and mysterious land of New York in the late sixties and seventies. These two soul mates, barely 20 when they met, are the ultimate bohemians. It is pure ecstasy to hear about their adventures, the icons they considered friends and to journey with them as their artistic destiny unfolds. - Summer

This book is one my daughter Bea's favorites! She is a deep soul and a contemplative sort, even at the tender age of 3 and this book satiates her curious spirit! Be ready to ask yourself the BIG questions along with your child and marvel and the answers they give. Highly imaginative, this book is like nothing I've ever seen before. -Summer
Everyone has 'those' days and Dammit Dolls are just what the Doctor ordered. Smack these guys around when you are frustrated & you'll instantly feel better. - Summer

It's about time, Alexa! Alexa Chung, one of the most beloved fashion icons of the 21st century, has finally delivered a book. The cover will make any table or shelf look great and her lighthearted, stream-of-consciousness ramblings will delight you. - Summer

My amazing stepdaughter Olivia gets all the credit for this one. She turned me onto HONY last year via Instagram and Facebook and it's been making me happy every day since. This book satiates my curiosity about complete strangers and what their life might be like, what their struggles or triumphs are, their best moments, and more. Sometimes heartbreaking, sometimes funny and always poignant. This book is amazing. - Summer
